column2: RABAT, Morocco, April 2-- Morocco joined the list of Moslem countries receiving economic assistance from the United States under an agreement signed today.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- Congress and the Administration are tied up in a forlorn legal tangle over how to run the Government when a President is so disabled that he cannot transfer his duties to the Vice President.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2-- West Coast longshoremen voted today to attempt to organize the docks and warehouses in the Great Lakes area.
A lone burglar--young, cool, polite and unarmed--last night staged the third jewel theft of the last two weeks in the Park and Fifth Avenues Social Register area. Just how

For almost a week now the Hudson Tubes between Manhattan and New Jersey have been closed by a strike. As most railroad and transit walkouts go--with their millions of riders and thousands of workers --this is not a major stoppage.
TORVAIANICA, Italy, April 2 --The three judges and other personages of Italy's most sensational trial in recent years inspected this drab beach near Rome today.
WASHINGTON, April 2-- When it comes to picking the greatest Senators in history, Harry S. Truman thinks Congress should not stop at five.
BUENOS AIRES, April 2--Argentine's rebellious Air Force and Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, the Provisional President, reached a compromise tonight.

CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., April 2 (AP)--A long-range Navy bomber with engines sputtering smashed into a plowed field and exploded today, killing all eleven aboard. The accident occurred minutes after take-off in a misty drizzle from Chincoteague Naval Air Station.

LONDON, April 2--India, Japan, Norway and Yugoslavia have been invited by the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee to submit amplifications of the arms reduction proposals they have made in the past.
A "terrific bang" preceded the crash of a Northeast Airlines plane at Rikers Island last Feb. 1, a Civil Aeronautics Board panel of inquiry was told yesterday.
A PECULIAR breed among men who follow the sea are the conscientious bottletossers--officers who put Hydrographic Office papers into the ocean in whisky containers.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has recommended to President Eisenhower that United Nations forces in Korea be equipped with new weapons, particularly jet aircraft.

PARIS, April 2--France is interested in helping to build an oil pipeline across Israel from Elath, on the Gulf of Aqaba, to Haifa, on the Mediterranean, Levi Eshkol, Israeli Minister of Finance, said today.
Plans of the Hanover Bank for moving a large part of its downtown operations to the proposed Astor Plaza development at Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street was announced yesterday.
In one hour and fifty-five minutes yesterday morning, the Electric Bond and Share Company bought 200,000 shares of American and Foreign Power Comnany common stock. The

The First National City Bank of New York and the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank yesterday reported sharp increases in operating earnings for the three months ended March 31, as compared with a year earlier.
A concert of new music, the second in a series directed by Eric Simon, was given last night in the Carl Fischer Concert Hall. Composers from Europe, Cuba and the United States were represented.
The Waterfront Commission announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas Dawson as a special consultant on technical matters pertaining to the cargo-handling industry in this port.

The twenty-eighth season of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League opens Friday in the meeting between Penn and Dartmouth at Philadelphia. This will be the first of forty-five games scheduled among the ten member colleges.

Advertising of room air conditioners in this area is going to be a good deal more clear and accurate. For example, there will be no references, it is hoped, to "room area" or "tons" to describe the cooling capacity.
The backlog of pending local government borrowings was increased by $130,050,000 esterday as a result of the posting for sale of eight new bond issues.

Maj. Hans G. Hornbostel, a retired Army engineer who survived the Bataan death march and later spent three years at Carville, La., where his wife was in the leper colony, died last night in the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens. He was 76 years old last Sunday.
PARIS, April 2--United States foreign policy as applied in South Asia displays a disturbingly schizophrenic aspect. Our aspirations are clearly both benevolent and sound.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The Eisenhower Administration rallied its top talent today to defend its $71,800,000,000 budget as part of the price of a just, enduring peace.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2--Discriminations against women members of the United Nations Secretariat were charged today by a majority of the Commission on the Status of Women.
The State of Connecticut borrowed $50,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to further the permanent financing of the Connecticut Turnpike.

The P. Lorillard Company plans to introduce a long menthol-cooled filter cigarette named Newport, Lewis Gruber, president, disclosed this yesterday to some 450 stockholders at the annual meeting in the Ambassador Hotel. This attendance was the largest ever for the company.
GROTON, Conn., April 2-- Max G. Johl, retired thread manufacturer and a noted philatelist, died Sunday at his home here after a long illness. He was 56 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- Two Administration spokesmen told Congress today that the extent of Communist activity in Hawaii was no reason to deny statehood to the islands.
Belchise, a gray 3-year-old filly owned by George T. Weymouth and trained by his son Eugene, plowed through the slop at rainy Jamaica yesterday to win the featured $6,000 Greenyale Purse.

THAT was the summer Jack Haywood was 14 years old. In a lonesome corner of Alabama some thirty miles north of the Gulf of Mexico Jack lived on a farm with his father and mother and sister, Ellen, who was 17. The farm was one of several on "The...
Assurances that the schoolship John W. Brown would continue to operate were given yesterday by the New York City Board of Education.
The Government cashed in on a World War II lend-lease operation yesterday to the tune of $16,000,000.
The world-wide surge of industrialization will mean more rather than less opportunity for American business abroad, a major foreign trade gathering was told yesterday.

Commodity futures closed irregularly here yesterday. Trading was dull and featureless in most New York markets. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, rubber and tin rose, while coffee, hides and zinc declined. The price movements for sugar, potatoes, wool and copper were mixed.

Five Puerto Rican veterans of the Korean war who were injured in a 1953 airplane crash that killed twenty-two others received damage awards totaling $223,000 yesterday. The amounts were decided by a Federal Court jury here.
Imports of alcoholic beverages continued to climb last year in the face of increasing efforts by some members of the general alcoholic trade to reduce them.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- An American farm leader said today that Yugoslavia's relations with the Soviet Union were so strained that the United States should continue to aid Marshal Tito in "our own interests."

WASHINGTON, April 2--A, comprehensive survey of the professional, economic and social life of teachers was released today. It showed that 73 per cent of men teachers and 17 per cent of women had to take outside jobs to meet their needs.
ALBANY, April 2--The State Tax Commission announced today that it hoped to clarify its position on the taxability of sickness pay tomorrow.
DALLAS, Tex., April 2--A roaring tornado slashed through Dallas for forty minutes today.

WASHINGTON, April 2--Robert Murphy, Deputy Undersecretary of State, said today that passports to visit Red China would be denied to newsmen as long as the Communist regime held any Americans prisoner there.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2-- Herbert Fleishhacker, a dominant voice in San Francisco and California finance and politics for a generation, died of a heart attack today in his suite at the St. Francis Hotel. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Following is the text of a speech by President Eisenhower today before the Washington conference of the Advertising Council:
CHICAGO, April 2--Grain and soybean futures prices declined early in today's session on the Board of Trade, but a late rally lifted prices from the lows and at the close changes were mixed.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 2--The wonderfully high spirited young company of folk singers and dancers called Retablo de Maravillas is Venezuela's most distinctive theatrical asset.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 2 (AP) --Prime Minister Hussein Ala was reported today to have submitted his resignation because of the slaying of three Americans by Iranian bandits.
DALLAS, Tex., Wednesday, April 3--Amid blizzard, storm and a lethal series of tornadoes, Texas voters turned out yesterday to name Ralph Yarborough, a Democrat, to the United States Senate.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2--The company that formerly operated the Suez Canal made public today a detailed program for expanding and improving it.
DALLAS, Tex., April 2--I watched a tornado rip across this city of 600,000 today.
The United States was warned yesterday that it must speed the development of materials able to withstand the rigors of hypersonic flight.
DETROIT, April 2--Democrats scored a resounding victory yesterday in Michigan's spring election.
Sales on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday surpassed the two-million-share mark for the first time since Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Following is the State Department's record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 2-- When the Giants launch the National League season April 16 at Pittsburgh, their starting shortstop will be Andre Rodgers, a long-legged, smoothswinging, hard-throwing lad of 22. There have been others

MONTREAL, April 2--The Canadiens struck in the third period to defeat the New York Rangers tonight, 3 to 1, in the fourth game of their semi-final round series in the Stanley Cup competition for the hockey championship of the world.

Mikhail Botvinnik and Vassily Smyslov adjourned after fortythree moves yesterday in the twelfth match of their world chess title series at the Tchaikovsky Music Hall in Moscow, according to a report from Soviet news sources. Play will be resumed today.

LONDON, April 2--A neurologist testified today in the murder trial of Dr. John Bodkin Adams that the alleged victim might have died from natural causes. He said, however, that he believed narcotics had caused her death.
WASHINGTON, April 2-- Secretary of State Dulles was questioned at length today about foreign policy statements in a new book about himself.
Because of inadequate municipal budget procedures, the public gets a false impression of many, city operations, the counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission Charged yesterday.
IN "Hide and Seek," which opened at the Ethel Barry more last evening, Stanley Mann and Roger MacDougall ask one of the most disturbing questions of the century.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP)-- United States Maritime Board examiner expressed the view today that a trade route designated as essential should be established betwen the Great Lakes and the Caribbean.
WASHINGTON, April 2-- Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, announced today the union would have a public relations program to fight "antilabor legislation."

ALBANY, April 2--Governor Harriman announced his approval today of Republican-sponsored legislation raising the pay of state employes and cutting the hours of some. Actually, he signed the hills Saturday before leaving for a Florida vacation.
BUFFALO, April 2--Liberal theologians were taken to task today for what was described as their failure to preach fundamental Biblical truths.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2--The Yankees had to go right down to the wire today to gain a 1-0 triumph over the Red Sox. But to Casey Stengel, the victory meant more than had it been achieved by half a dozen runs.
NEW ORLEANS, April 2 (AP) --Robert Tallant, New Orleans author and creator of Mrs. Candy, heroine of several novels, was found dead in his apartment yesterday. His age was 47. A
TORONTO, April 2 (Canadian Press)--Noranda Mines, Ltd., had record net income last year of $18,582,000, or $14.15 a share, compared with $14,847,000, or $3.31 a share, in 1955. The in
More than $96,000,000 of corporate securities will be offered today to investors. The offerings are:
The Communist party announced yesterday that its state convention, ended Monday, had elected eleven national committee and sixteen state committee members.

A patient search for the owner of the outmoded little building at 362 Lexington Avenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, has enabled Senville Realty and Construction, Inc., to include the parcel in an enlarged site for a twenty-four-story office building. The structure will
CAIRO, April 2--President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt was reported today to have orally accepted a United Nations proposal for surcharges on tolls to pay for clearing the Suez Canal.
VIENNA, April 2--Counterterror is being carried on in Hungary, according to a former Government official who escaped to Vienna a few days ago.

In his press conference yesterday Secretary Dulles again expressed hope for a satisfactory settlement of the immediate problems of the Middle East, including firm Egyptian commitments on the Suez Canal, ...
DENVER, April 2 (AP)--The worst spring snowstorm in twenty-two years blanketed the Rocky Mountain States today with up to four feet of snow. Power and communications were disrupted.

About two months ago news came from England that British scientists had reported progress in their experiments to harness the vast energy of the hydrogen bomb for the peaceful uses of industrial civilization.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Ezra Taft Benson indicated today that he was getting ready to ask Congress to kill mandatory farm price supports.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 (AP)-- Ellis E. Patterson, former lieutenant governor of California, said today that he and two Southern California business men would undertake a Canadian pulpwood project costing between $40,000,000 and $54,000,000.
The development of big business into "giant business" is a major threat to this country, Herbert H. Lehman said here yesterday. The former Senator contended that growing con
The eyes of the nation are averted--at least for the moment--from the activities of high officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 2--A loud blast at 10:15 A. M. today shook buildings, cracked a swimming pool wall and broke windows as it was heard over a five-county area.
Two children took the afternoon air yesterday like other children by swooping down a slide and playing games. But there was an extra motion to their play that might well have upset others.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 2-- The Giants' second-line pitching, which has troubled Manager Bill Rigney all spring, bogged down today in an 11-6 defeat at the lands of the Cleveland Indians.

THE sap buckets are out on maple trees upstate and in Vermont and New Hampshire. The first trickle of the liquid that is boiled down to that distinetly American sweet syrup came in this state on Feb. 10. But only now is the season getting into full swing.
LONDON, April 2--The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions today ordered 1,700,000 strikers in the two industries to return to work Thursday.
Secretary Dulles' statement that forty-eight hours should bring some determination of the Suez Canal situation seemed to be interpreted bullishly by the stock market yesterday.
A Federal mediator last nibht ordered representatives of both sides in the Hudson Tubes strike to meet tomorrow morning in Washington in an attempt to end the six-day dispute. Francis

WASHINGTON, April 2--Secretary of State Dulles said today that "a great deal" of Egypt's future would hinge on President Gamal Abdel Nasser's response to United States proposals for operating the Suez Canal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 --The long-rumored entry of National Theatres, Inc., into the field of film production and financing of independent producers became a reality today with the formation of National Film Investments, Inc., as a wholly owned subsidiary.
A Supreme Court Justice refused yesterday to halt the City Council's public hearings on the fitness of Hugh Quinn to hold his Council seat.
BALBOA, C. Z., April 2-- John T. Ridgely, newly appointed railroad consultant to the Panama Canal Company, died of a heart ailment today in Gorgas Hospital. His age was 69.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly to close 2 points off to 3 points up yesterday. Trading was in moderate volume.
ALBANY, April 2--The state took in $7,500,000 more in cash in the fiscal year that ended Sunday than it paid out. In the previous year the excess was $32,900,000.
Daniel Gutman, counsel to Governor Harriman, said yesterday that the Parole Board had the power to change the rule that permits one member to restore a parolee to parole supervision.

Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, is a man who usually sticks by his convictions. Yesterday, however, he switched a stand that he took in June, 1954, when he became head of the Central. He has decided
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) --The Air Force vigorously denied today that it had showed "no interest" in getting a $5,000,000 refund on a contract for B-47 wings.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- The House Veterans Committee today killed an Administration bill to raise the interest rate on G.I. home loans to 5 per cent.
Laurels went yesterday to the women who are competing in arrangement classes at the International Flower Show at the Coliseum this week.
LONDON, April 2--Peter Thorneycroft, Chancellor of the Exchequer, took a moderately optimistic view today of Britain's economic prospects for this year.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2 --Both Syria and Jordan were teetering tonight on the edge of major political upheavals.

AT about 6 o'clock on the evening of Aprii 12 a num ber of men are going to rush into a number of tackle shops in the metropolitan area and demand that their flyrods be rewound and revarnished and their reels repaired by 6 o'clock on the morning of April 13, when the trout season opens.
PARIS, April 3--Premier Guy Mollet was reported today to have proposed an inquiry into the alleged mistreatment of Moslems in Algeria.

BUFFALO, April 3-A nationwide prayer rally for the success of Billy Graham's forthcoming New York crusade began here tonight. The 38 year-old evangelist will open his campaign in Madison Square Garden on May 15. It is expected to continue through the summer.
Memories mix with the present and future at the eleventh annual hobby show for older persons opening today at the American Museum of Natural History.

TAMPA, Fla., April 3--Although expert opinion continues to hold the Yankees overwhelming favorites to romp off with another American League pennant, Casey Stengel is beginning to wonder whether some slight revision in these early estimates might not be in order.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Wilbur R. McReynolds, retired, and his wife, Faye, were shot to death in their home in the Snell Isle residential section here tonight. A French war hero was arrested shortly afterward.
WASHINGTON, April 3--A firm of three Madrid architects won the first R. S. Reynolds Memorial Award for aluminum design today.

Columbia Gas System, Inc. yesterday awarded the underwriting contract on its 1,675,415share common stockholder subscription offering to a syndicate jointly managed by Lehman Brothers and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.

Jack McQuade, a right-hander, struck out nine of the eleven batters he faced in relief yesterday to lead Fordham University to a 4-2 triumph over Kings Point at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx. It was the season's opener for the Rams.

Consolidated net earnings of the Paramount Pictures Corporation last year amounted to $8,731,000, it was reported yesterday. This was equal to $4.43 a share on 1,971,316 shares outstanding and included $2.26 a share for special items, principally on the sale of films to television.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The Post Office Department said today it would drastically curtail mail service, effective Saturday, unless Congress appropriated an extra $47,000,000 to carry it until the end of the fiscal year on July 1.
Extensive plans for widening streets in lower Manhattan to absorb the constantly increasing traffic burden were outlined yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
The College Entrance Examination Board received some pointed suggestions yesterday from representatives of secondary schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3-- Rowland Roberts Hughes, Presdent Eisenhower's Director of the Budget from April, 1954, until his resignation a year later, died here last night of arteriosclerosis. His age was 61.
LONDON, April 3-The court turned down today the contention made for Dr. John Bodkin Adams that the prosecution's case should be thrown out of court.

Much of the activity and most of the gains in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange came in the first hour, when steels, rubbers and some metals were buoyant. From that point on the trend for the list as a whole was downward, a1though some specialties continued to show strength.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3 (AP)--Mrs. Ara Fitzgerald Clarke, retired actress and opera singer, died yesterday of a heart attack. She was 63 years old.
The circus opened last night with a show frankly aimed at children and at all the others who want to gasp at the aerialists, tremble at the wild animals and, especially, to laugh at the clowns.
A collection of small flesheating plants went on display yesterday before fascinated garden enthusiasts at the International Flower Show in the Coliseum.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 3-- The Giants' catching problem, a headache for Manager Bill Rigney all spring, became more acute today. Just before the Giants took the field against the ...

The use of premiums last year set a new peak. More than 90 per cent of consumer goods companies questioned in an elaborate survey used more or the same volume of such promotions in 1956 as they used in 1955, the previous record year.
A Soviet novelist who once hinted that Stalin had ordered the murder of Mikhail V. Frurize, an early Soviet War Commissar, is to be "rehabilitated."

TEHERAN, Iran, April 3 (Reuters)-Premier Hussein Ala resigned today. Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi appointed Dr. Manouchehr Eghbal, Court Minister, as Premier. He will submit his new Cabinet to the Shah tomorrow.
A mature and dynamic voluntary agency is likely to experience periods of exceptional growth followed by intervals of consolidation of the gains that have been registered.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries had a record year in 1956, according to the annual report released yesterday. The company reported the greatest volume of business and highest earnings in its history, with both consolidated and parent company net income at record highs.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The Government settled today its antitrust suit against Schenley Industries, Inc., one of the country's largest distillers. The Department of Justice an nounced that a consent decree
A small-sized stock-car Rambler taxicab about a foot shorter than average cabs went into service here yesterday shortly after meeting requirements of the Hack Bureau.
ALBANY, April 3--The heads of two state departments reported today steps they had taken to ease local problems resulting from the shutdown of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway.
Earl Isaac, a 34-year-old construction worker, believes there is a compensatory gain in life for every loss.
VICTORVILLE, Calif., April 3 (AP)-Ned Sparks, comedian known for his rasping voice and perpetual scowl, died tonight in St. Mary's Hospital of Desert Valley of an intestinal block.

LEESVILLE, La., April 3 -- Twenty-two thousand troops at Camp Polk completed a crossing of the rain-swollen Red River tonight in the second phase of Exercise King Cole. New Army concepts for the atomic age are being tested.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)Americans have deep faith in farmland as a safe and desirable long-term investment, the Agriculture Department said today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., April 3 --C. Beverley Benson of 44 Highbiridge Road, a consulting engineer on railroad problems for the Public Service Commission, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in White Plains Hospital. His age was 61.
WASHINGTON, April 3-This is National Laugh Week, by order of the National Chamber of Commerce, and Washington is doing its best to make it a success.

Cocoa futures climbed to new highs for the move yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Short covering, hedge lifting and light new buying induced stop-loss purchasing. Trade and commission house selling and light profit-taking supplied the contracts.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- President Eisenhower today branded as "the worst rot that I have heard" reports that he might resign the Presidency before his second term ended.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points off to 1 point up yesterday in light trading.

Within three hours after their arrival in this country, a husband-and-wife team of Hungarian correspondents received a special George Polk Memorial Award yesterday for "distinguished achievements in journalism."

The Babcock Wilcox Company, maker of boilers, tubular products and refractories, had a loss of $2,400,000 in its atomic energy business last year, Alfred Iddles, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
Pacific Gas and Electric Company chalked up a record year in 1956, according to the annual report released yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --The National Broadcasting Company has purchased a new filmed Western series titled "Sixshooter" as part of next fall's programing armament.

WASHINGTON, April 3-The Eisenhower Administration has been politely but pointedly warned that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee looks with anxiety on some of the President's appointments to high diplomatic posts abroad.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 3--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies offered today some caustic reflections on the Middle East situation in an address to undergraduates at Melbourne University.
A shopping center to be built in Palm Beach, Fla., has been designed to complement the community's famous Worth Avenue store district.
Directors of the Raymond Concrete Pile Company placed the common stock on a $2 annual basis with the declaration yesterday of an increased quarterly dividend of 50 cents.
DETROIT, April 3--An expert estimated today that Americans donated $6,519,000,000 last year to charities.

BALTIMORE, April 3--Forecasts that the 1957 sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation would approach a record $2,000,000,000 and that its earnings would be between $3.50 and $4 a share were made today at the concern's seventy-first annual stockholders' meeting.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 3 (AP)--George Breen opened the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming and diving championships with a record-breaking victory in the 1,500-meter free-style today.
Miami, Fla., borrowed yesterday $7,500,000 on serial bonds to finance various public improvements at an interest cost of 3.419 per cent.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3--The Dodgers and the Braves played ball for ten innings today and proved nothing except that their pitchers were pretty good.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 3 (AP) Israel announced today that she might erect a barbed wire fence along her border with the Gaza Strip to keep out Arab infiltrators and raiders.
Senate investigators are looking into indications of an extensive labor and management racket in the "juke box" and automatic coin machine field.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 3 (UP)--A memorial service was held at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church today for Richard W. Slocum, executive vice president of The Philadelphia Bulletin, who died Sunday at the age of 55.
An angry group of teachers threatened yesterday to hold a mass demonstration at City Hall on "school time" if the city did not grant adequate salary increases to school employes.

In a surprise move, the Government disclosed yesterday that it would attempt a shortcut in its suit to block the proposed merger between the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.
GAZA, April 2--Inability to get the Gaza Strip's citrus crop to market soon enough and in sufficient auantity has created a critical financial problem for Gaza.
THAT Churchillian spirit animates H. M. Tomlinson's new novel, "The Trumpet Shall Sound."" He was born in 1873.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The State Department studied another Egyptian note on the Suez Canal today.
A new form of marine propulsion--the free-piston gas turbine engine--was demonstrated in Cleveland yesterday by its builder, the Cleveland Diesel Engine Division of the General Motors Corporation.
LONDON, April 3--The gold and dollar reserves held by Great Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by $62,000,000. This brought the total to $2,209,000,000.
Sir Eric Bowater, chairman of the Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., London, said here yesterday that the recent $4 a ton increase in newsprint prices was not enough.
WASHINGTON, April 3-Following are President Eisenhower's remarks today before the fifth annual Republican Women's National Conference:

The Province of British Columbia registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday $45,000,000 of debentures of two of its instrumentalities, W. A. C. Bennett, Provincial Premier and Minister of Finance, announced.
Stanley J. Harte, New York investment builder, announced here yesterday his purchase of twelve acres of land in Massena, N. Y., near the Canadian border.
THE annual exhibitions of the American Water-color Society have steadily gained in quality in recent years. The 1957 version, which opens today in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would ask Governor Harriman to veto a measure designed to shift the route of the Brooklyn approach to the Narrows Bridge.

In the "Guys and Dolls" world that is the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the word these days is that Dave Beok and his top aides intend to run for re-election in September even if they stand convicted in Federal courts.
WASHINGTON, April 3-The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that this year's tests of new weapons would begin about May 15 and continue through the summer.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 3 --Wetmore Hodges, an industrialist who played a major role in the development of the frozenfoods business, died in Palo Alto Hospital yesterday after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.
Both the New York Philharmonic-Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera are interrupting their New York seasons next week for performances out of town.
Vassily Smyslov, the challenger, increased his lead over Mikhail Botvinnik in their world chess title series yesterday with out making a move.

Portions of the Masters golf tournament, which begins today in Augusta, Ga., will be televised tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The C.B.S. radio network also will present coverage at various times during a fourday period.
A new volume will be added to the Civil War library when McGraw-Hill publishes on May 6 Frank E. Vandiver's "Mighty Stonewall." It is a revaluation

ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 (AP) --Four states and two of the country's largest cities pledged their support today to a twoyear survey aimed at producing an over-all water resources plan for the Delaware River Basin.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 3--An uneasy peace has settled on this city after thirty hours' rioting and armed clashes.
WASHINGTON, April 3President Eisenhower said today that the United States was concerned about a Communist arms build-up in North Korea.

A SURE sign of spring in the home furnishings world is the rash of crafts shows all over town. Galleries may seem an odd place to go shopping for a cup and saucer or a new rug, but the quality of handcraft work today has elevated such objects to a fine arts level.
TOKYO, April 1--Travelers who have been in North Korea report that the Communist regime there is rebuilding Pyongyang, the capital, into a showcase to impress neutral Asians.

FOR the better part of two decades Billy Meyer had been managing in the minor leagues with such consummate skill that he gained recognition of sorts as an "uncrowned champion." Baseball men regarded him as more talented and better equipped than most major league managers.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The United States accused Hungary today of reverting to "Stalinist terror."

CLEVELAND, April 3 (UP)-- Al Rosen said today his decision not to return to the Cleveland Indians was made because General Manager Hank Greenberg had refused to back an earlier offer made by Bill Veeck, the Indians' public relations man.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --A story written twenty-nine years ago by the late documentary film producer Robert J. Flaherty about a boy and his pet bull was introduced today into the deepening mystery over the authorship of the motion picture "The Brave One."
LONDON, April 3--Early gains in the stock markets on the ending of the shipyard and engineering strikes were not entirely held at the close today.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- The United States and the Netherlands signed an air transport agreement today that gives Dutch airliners the right to begin a new service to Houston, Tex.
LONDON, April 3--The Labor party adopted a resolution tonight demanding postponement of Britain's first hydrogen bomb test.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --Charles Vidor will step in as director of "A Farewell to Arms" to succeed John Huston.
Tonight in a little schoolhouse on East Eleventh Street, art and neighborhood folk are going to bump into each other. Judging by what has happened in the past, they are likely to
Plans are going forward for next Thursday's benefit performance of "A Hole in the Head," which will help The Encampment for Citizenship.
More major New York City banks reported yesterday that their operating earnings for the first three months of 1957 were substantially higher than those of a year before.
The New York Legislature has taken quite a beating from public opinion for its omissions, and deservedly, but for one important benefit conferred by the session at ...
ALBANY, April 3--The Bureau of Motor Vehicles reported today that its evidence indicated almost 100 per cent compliance with the new compulsory automobile insurance law.
Kats Brothers bought the fivestory apartment house at 223-27 Cypress Avenue, corner of East 137th Street, the Bronx, from Oscar Robinson and immediately

HAVANA, April 3-Recent disorders in Cuba have disturbed the political life of the nation but have in no way affected its economic stability, Dr. Joaquin Martinez Saena, president of the National Bank of Cuba, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aprii 3President Eisenhower asked Congress again today to approve United States membership in the Organization for Trade Cooperation. The international association would administer trade and sariff agreements among member countries.

WAYNESBURG, Pa.. April 3 (UP)--Tommy Evans, defending champion and National Collegiata titleholder, took a giant step toward his second Amateur Athletic Union wrestling crown tonight with spectacular victories in the first two rounds of the national championships.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A California bandit who has been under sentence of death for nine years won a Supreme Court hearing today on his ninth petition to the court.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday record sales and increased earnings for the fifty-three weeks ended Feb. 2, compared with the preceding fifty-two-week period. Sales were $430,309,000, up 10 per cent from the $389,573,000 volume a year ago.

An all-star performance, "A Surprise Party," at the Phoenix Theatre on the evening of April 28 will initiate a drive to raise funds for the continuation of the Phoenix Theatre, at Second Avenue and Twelfth Street.
ALBANY, April 10--Governor Harriman approved today a $20,083,801 increase in state spending for the fiscal year that began April 1.

The Seafarers International Union of North America will press its fight against the transfer of United States-flag merchant vessels to other flags, Paul Hall said yesterday. He is the new president of the 100,000member organization.
The Federal Government insisted yesterday that New York City trim its plans for the Lincoln Square redevelopment and defer some other slum-clearance projects.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) --Recent snows and rains in the drought-plagued Great Plains brought about today a 7 per cent increase in the Government's forecast for the 1957 crop of winter wheat.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company continued to show improved revenues and earnings through the first quarter of this year, according to the report issued yesterday.

Patrick B. McGinnis, former president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and now president of the Boston and Maine Railroad, finds that the railroad passenger deficit problem has followed him.

An invitation to a prominent New York Negro to attend a dinner in Richmond for "distinguished Virginians" was withdrawn yesterday as "a mistake." Dr. Clian B. Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver Jr. outlined his plans for the future yesterday. At the same time he indicated his belief that the networks were falling down on the job of providing superior television entertainment because of their scramble for high ratings.

Capt. Jens G. Olsen acted yesterday on advice that his father gave him more than a half century ago. He gave up his seagoing career.

Paper bags have graduated. They now are designed for purposes not dreamed of years ago. The brown paper bag still does its share in transporting merchandise. Retail stores could hardly do without them.
American education must do more to encourage the individual intellectual and creative development of students, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom declared yesterday.

PARIS, April 12--The United States will distribute three types of missiles to nations of the North Atlantic alliance in the fiscal year 1957. It will not, however, share the nuclear warheads for these weapons, this being forbidden by an act of Congress.

Directors of the Grand Union Company yesterday raised the annual dividend rate on the concern's common stock to 72 cents from 60 cents with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 18 cents a share.

Eddie Arcaro won with William Morgan's Grover B. in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The accomplishment was hardly a surprise, inasmuch as the crowd of 22,806 wagered the 8-year-old horse into 3-4 favoritism.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- There will be no regular mail deliveries tomorrow. This became certain as Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield stood firm tonight on his orders to curtail postal services at midnight.

Underwriting commitments of investment houses are still running high. Debt and equity offerings in behalf of corporate enterprises are still crowding the market, and new registrations with the Securities and Exchange Commission are keeping the backlog high.

Herbert Halsey Maass, board chairman of the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J., died Thursday in his home at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel after a long illness. His age was 79.

Movements in prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed yesterday. The close was 5 points higher (25 cents a bale) to 5 points lower than on Thursday, with far months showing the most weakness.

The navigation season in the Great Lakes for European and South American trade got under way yesterday. Subsidies Are Asked
Negotiations are virtually completed for the transfer of the assets of the Ford Foundation's former TV-Radio Workshop to the new production company headed by Robert Saudek.
A basic real estate tax rate of $4 for each $100 of assessed valuation was forecast for 19571958 yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 15 --The Giants sharpened their batting eyes at the expense of five Army pitchers, and scored a 16-to-0 victory at Doubleday Field today before a crowd of about 10,000.

Dr. Frederick B. Flinn, a retired physiologist, industrial toxicologist and educator, died on April 8 in Eden Hospital, Castro Valley, Calif., after a short illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 200 East Sixty-sixth Street.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15--Einar Gerhardsen, Premier of Norway, told the Soviet Union today that Norway's defense was nobody's business but her own.
WASHINGTON, Apri1 15-- The Air Force, in response to Congressional criticisms, has established a new target period for the first flight of an atomic powered airplane.
SETAUKET, L.I., April 15-- About 550 acres of scrub pine and scrub oak in central Suffolk County were burned this afternoon in four different forest fires.

The Saturday Evening Post, mightily encouraged by the results of its venture a year ago in a theatre-style promotional tour of the country, put on yesterday a showing of a presentation the magazine is about to Send on a tour of eighteen major cities over the next twelve weeks.
New York longshoremen and their families last year received benefits totaling $3,922,000 from the New York Shipping Association-International Longshoremen's Association Welfare Fund.
Operation Big Sweep--the latest move in the campaign for a cleaner city--brushed 2,301 litterbugs lightly yesterday.

A committee has been formed under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Nicholas R. Jones and Mrs. Ira H. Washburn to plan a card party and tea for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.
CAIRO, April 15--About 200 students, most of them Jordanians and Palestine Arabs, demonstrated today to denounce King Hussein as a "traitor" to the Arab nation.

IT was in Tampa a little more than a fortnight ago that Pee Wee Reese was felled by a baseball caroming off his shin. When ever the captain of the Dodgers is in a whimsical mood, he always can find a ready foil in the droll Gil Hodges.

Giulio Garl sang the title role in Verdi's "Don Carlo" last night for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House. He replaced Jussi Bjoerling, who was scheduled to take the part but was obliged to relinquish it because of a virus infection.

THE current state of the historical novel takes a turn for the better with Nicholas E. Wyckoff's "The Braintree Mission." This is a comedy of ideas lit with humor and grace. It may remind your alternately of Robert E. Sherwood and George Bernard Shaw.

Igor Marketvitch, who made his New York debut last January conducting the Symphony of the Air, will open the fortieth season of Stadium Concerts on June 24.
DR. HUSSEIN FAKHRI ELKHALIDI is a physician. Yesterday he became Premier of Jordan, seeking to keep that feverish 11-year-old Arab independent country alive for King Hussein I.
The New York Post Office successfully dug itself out from under a mountain of mail yesterday.
Garnet (Sugar) Hart, Philadelphia welterweight, stopped Willie (Pineapple) Stevenson of Boston in the seventh round of the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
Governor Harriman said yesterday that he had decided to order an investigation of the state parole system.

A record attendance of more than 500 stockholders in Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., at the annual meeting in Brooklyn yesterday were told of record first-quarter sales and earnings and favorable prospects for the balance of the year.
New Trend carried the Ellis Farm silks to victory in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. Opposing six others, New Trend scored by a length over Mrs. James Hastie's You Go.

CHICAGO, April 15-- Grain and soybean futures started irregular this morning, but turned weak in slow trading. There seemed to be considerable long liquidation late in the session.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 15--"Why is this night different from all other nights?" At sundown today this question was asked in Jewish homes throughout Israel.
PALESTINE, Tex., April 15 (UP)--Jack (Colby Jack) Coombs, pitcher on some of the late Connie Mack's great Philadelphia Athletic teams, died at his home of a heart attack today. His age was 74.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 --Chances of a reconciliation between Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin, who became a top boxoffice comedy team, appear to be growing dimmer.
DETROIT, April 15 (AP)--Dealers held 762,921 new cars on April 1, compared with 733,008 a month earlier, Automotive News reported today.
BONN, Germany, April 15-- The main outlines of the Defense Ministry's atomic age armament program were disclosed today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 15 --Six Russian scientists who had accepted invitations will not attend an important nuclear physics conference here this week.
MOSCOW, April 15--Nikita S. Khrushchev, in unusually friendly spirits, said tonight that the Communist and capitalist worlds should live and let live.
It will be Whitey Ford against Chuck Stobbs in a duel of southpaws as the Yankees and the Washington Senators launch the 1957 American League pennant race at the Stadium today.

The world sugar contract rose sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar exchange. The volume was the third largest of the year. The near-by positions climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts.
A Columbia University professor was detained two and a half hours in Miami by immigration officials yesterday, then permitted to complete a return trip from Panama.
GALVESTON, Tex., April 15 --Dave Beck asserted tonight that he "might blow the lid right off the Senate" if he testified how he had spent union funds.
In his proposals for a longerrange American foreign aid program Secretary Dulles suggested that we make a sharper distinction between "military" and "economic" aid.
Retailers were warned yesterday that they faced the threat of Government action unless they tightened their policies on consumer credit.

LONDON, April 15--Representatives of the West on the United Nations disarmament subcommittee believe the Soviet Union is moving toward an agreement for limited reductions of both nuclear and conventional arms.
GENEVA, April 15--The United Nations special committee investigating the Hungarian revolt heard the last of its 111 witnesses here today and began to prepare its final report.
Prices of cotton futures moved mostly lower yesterday. The close was 3 points up to 17 points down.
January through March volume of more than a billion dollars enabled the General Electric Company to report record sales and earnings for the period.
IF you would be a gourmet, do not begin by cleaning your plate but by washing pots and pans.
TRENTON, April 15--New Jersey voters will go to the polls tomorrow to nominate the major party candidates for Governor.
LONDON, April 15--Britain is "determined" to contribute to the military, moral and economic force of the Atlantic alliance, Selwyn Lloyd declared today.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- Senator Richard B. Russell warned tonight that Federal encroachment on states rights was a danger "far more insidious than even the Communist conspiracy of subversion."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15-- Navy broke a 3-3 tie by scoring five runs in the fifth inning, and went on to an 8-4 Eastern Baseball League victory over Columbia today.

OTTAWA, April 15--Popular indignation toward the United States over a Senate subcommittee's charges of disloyalty against one of Canada's leading diplomats changed today to criticism of the Canadian Government over its handling of the case.
LONDON, April 15--Most Government securities and oil shares declined on the stock exchange today because of the Mideast situation.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) --General Motors still heads the list of the 100 largest defense contractors but is being pressed by aircraft companies, the Defence Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- Washington officials were puzzled tonight by the composition of the new Jordanian Cabinet.

It was unofficially Ireland's day yesterday at the United States World Trade Fair, made so by Robert Briscoe, Dublin's Lord Mayor. Mr. Briscoe was a bit late in arriving at the Coliseum for a mid-afternoon inspection of Ireland's exhibit. But his tardiness seemed only to produce a larger crowd.
A new low-price American car will be introduced before fall by the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.
WESTKILL, N.Y., April 15 --The first days of trout fishing in the Catskills have again disproved the major axiom upon which philosophers agree. The fact is that man is not a reasoning animal.

A three-alarm fire in the downtown shopping area on Brooklyn yeatersay felled twenty-four firemen and a priest. The blaze also closed the Hoyt Street station of the IRT subway and caused traffic to be diverted from Fulton Street, the borough's principal shopping thoroughfare.
LONDON, April 15--The House of Commons approved tonight the 1957-58 budget presented to Parliament last Tuesday by Peter Thorneycroft, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- Industrial production in March, after seasonal adjustment, was unchanged from the level of January and February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Board of Education yesterday finished an experiment intended to produce better science instruction for thousands of junior high school pupils in the city.

The New York City Housing Authority is calling for bids to be received April 23 on $21,029,000 of short-term notes for the financing of the State-subsidized low-rent project Mariboro Houses, in Brooklyn.
HAVANA, Tuesday, April 16-- Constitutional guarantees were automatically restored at midnight. The Government suspended them forty-five days ago.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. achieved the highest quarterly sales in its history in the first three months this year. This was reflected in increased earnings over the period a year ago, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday.
Jews the world over began their traditional observance of the Passover season at sundown last night.
ALBANY, April 15--Governor Harriman announced today the completion of arrangements to establish a Permanent Mortgage Facilities Corporation.

GENEVA, April 15--Western European plans for a common market and free trade area will probably bestow their benefits unequally among the member nations, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe warns.

WASHINGTON, April 15-- The House of Representatives gave Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield a tongue-lashing today and then approved $41,000,000 for his department to start the mail full blast again.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 16-- Ankara has been buffeted for two days by its worst sandstorm in twenty-two years.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- The House of Representatives approved today a 26 per cent cut in the United States Information Agency's budget despite President Eisenhower's appeals for the full request of $144,000,000.

New York University and City College struggled to a 12-12 eight-inning tie in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Confer ence game at Ohio Field, the Bronx, yesterday. Each team made six errors in a game that was curtailed by cold weather and darkness.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16--Egypt complained to the Security Council today against Israel's "continued acts of provocation and aggression against the inhabitants of the Gaza Strip."
AMMAN, Jordan, April 16-- Jordan's new Government appeared to be in solid control today.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) --A Russian political refugee said today that the Soviet Embassy had been using pressure, including forged letters in an effort to get him to return.

Each of the Internal Revenue districts here had a few stragglers yesterday who filed their Federal income-tax returns after the deadline. The extra month given by the change in filing date from March 15 to April 15 proved for these taxpayers to be a day too short.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 16 --Pablo Casals, world-famous 'cellist, was stricken with a coronary thrombosis here today. He will not be able to direct the Canals Music Festival, which is scheduled to open here next Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- President Eisenhower signed tonight a bill giving the Post Office an additional $41,000,000 of operating money.

The New York Mayoralty election will be held on Nov. 5, 1957--which we suppose is reason enough for Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to make a premature announcement about prospective reduction in the city's real estate tax.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that the city's financial conditions was "probably the healthiest in its long history."

Lane Bryant, Inc., women's apparel store, has renewed its lease on the ten-story store building it occupies at 465 Fifth Avenue, at Fortieth Street, from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee of the William Waldorf estate. The renewal is for twenty-five years, effective May 1. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 --A major technical advance in television--successfully cutting and splicing recorded magnetic tape--apparently will be made in the near future. Heretofore, when the tape was cut, rejoined and replayed, distortions and aberrations appeared on the screen.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) --Republican Congressional lead ers were told today that Federal farms programs would cost the Treasury an average of about $1,000 a farm in the next fiscal year. The fiscal year starts July 1.
The sun stuck to its unwritten agenda yesterday--which calls for it to shine when the circus goes to Bellevue Hospital--by coming out in full brilliance when the big show arrived.

ALONG with spring fever, to most women comes the natural longing for new spring finery. Regardless of budget, every woman is lured by the light, bright spring fabrics of suits, coats and dresses, by frivolous new hats and more expressive accessories.
Standard Pressed Steel Comparty's 190,000-share offering of common stock will be made today at $30 a share by Kidder, Peabody Co. and associates.

World sugar futures opened down sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Overnight selling orders, stop-loss selling and long liquidation depressed the market. Short covering and light new buying steadied-prices later.

Morehead Patterson, chairman and president of American Machine and Foundry Company, told stockholders at yesterday's' annual meeting that firstquarter sales and rentals for the company were about $59,000,000 this year, compared with $43,500,000 in the 1956 period.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 15-- Turkish troops concluded the final phase of Operation Red Pivot on Gallipoli Peninsula today. The exercise was the largest held in the eastern Mediterranean by the North Atlantic alliance.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 17-- French railway workers began a two-day strike for higher wages at midnight last night.

On the market today are $60,000,000 of new first mortgage bonds and preferred stock of the Transcontinental Pipe Line Company, operator of a natural gas transmission system running 1,842 miles from TexasLouisiana Gulf coast to the New York metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Representative Clarence Cannon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, sounded today a battle cry for Democrats against the Administration program for development of atomic power.

PARIS, April 16--No matter how the Suez impasse is eventually resolved it is clear that the entire subject of international waterways must soon come up for review.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation achieved the highest sales for any quarter in the first three months this year, Howard S. Bunn, executive vice president told a record attendance of more than 2,200 stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 16 (AP)-- An eleventh-inning single by Larry Doby sent home Luis Aparicio from second bash and enabled the Chicago White Sox to beat the Cleveland Indians, 3--2, in a season opener today.

PITTSBURGH, April 16--On a damp, dark and dreary afternoon that became darker, damper and more dreary--especially in the eighth inning--the Giants opened the 1957 season today on the wrong end of a 9-2 score.
Consolidated net income of W.R. Grace Co. last year increased to $9,785,020 from $18,780,394 in 1955, the annual report disclosed yesterday. The 1956 net was equal after

SPOKANE, Wash., April 16 (UP)--Willie (Cemetery) Perteet may be too old to caddie for President Eisenhower, but he's just the man the Spokane Athletic Round Table needs.
CHICAGO, April 16--The clam has been pressed into service by scientists to help detect contamination of sea water from atomic explosions and the disposal of atomic waste.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Edgar N. Eisenhower, one of the President's four brothers, said tonight that he would like "to discover what influences are at work" that apparently changed his brother's stand on government spending.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (UP)-- Tom Brewer maintained his mastery over the Orioles today with an assist from Ike Delock as the Boston Red Sox spoiled Baltimores home opener with a 4-2 victory before 2 crowd of 38,227.

Fourteen Peabody awards were made yesterday for "distinguished achievement, by television and radio" during 1956. For the first time in its seventeen-year history, the Peabody committee presented an award for script writing. It went to Rod Serling, author of "Requiem for a Heavyweight," which was televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Department stores in the metropolitan area reported yesterday that business in the Easter selling period has increased substantially above volume for last year's corresponding period.

The new Pete Larsen Memorial Clinic, reportedly the first of its kind in then maritime industry, was dedicated yesterday at Third Avenue and Twentyfirst Street, Brooklyn. The clinic is a joint venture of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the seafarers International Union and its more than seventy contracting comnapanies.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16-- The "affair of the telegraphs" is turning into a showdown between the Government and the Opposition.

YONKERS, April 16--Pearl Creed, a 6-year-old--chestnut mare, owned by Delbert and Wayne Smith, took the lead at the first turn and held on to gain a one-and-a-half-length victory in the $5,500 Bayside Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
MONTREAL, April 16 (AP)-- The Montreal Canadiens won the Stanley Cup, symbol of Na tional Hockey League supremacy, for the second consecutive year tonight, defeating the Bos ton Bruins, 5--1.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Representative James E. Van Zandt, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today the United States' stockpile of materials for atomic-weapons had been estimated at three-and-a-half times that of the Soviet Union's.

Dr. Louis A. Baylin and others sold the seven-story building at 3535 De Kalb Avenue, between 212th Street and Gun Hill Road, in the Bronx, to an investing client of Cranford Linder. Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., was the broker in the sale.
The United States Rubber Company's sales and profits are nearing out company forecasts Eor record 1957 sales and earnings, H.E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 16--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin tonight seconded Nikita S. Khrushchev's view that the world was ready for a little less tension this spring.

Buyer registration at the United States World Trade Fair increased yesterday. The influx of prospective purchasers for retail and distribution concerns could not be tabulated fully late yesterday, but it added substantially to the total.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- President Eisenhower conferred today with Christian A. Herter, Under Secretary of State, on whether the United States should submit the Suez Canal problem to the United Nations Security Council.

The revolt in the Arab world against Communist influence brought into the area by President Nasser, of which the events in Jordan, are the latest manifestation, appears to be spreading, with Egypt's southern neighbor, the Sudan, as a new scene of it.
WESTKILL, N.Y., April 16 --The fast little Westkill River provides several examples of what volunteer effort can do for trout stream conservation, and what the state might, do.

LONDON, April 16--Britain will remain the second military power of the Western alliance, after the United States, even when her scheduled defense cuts have been implemented, Duncan Sandys declared today.
TANGIER ISLAND, Va., April 16--This was about the biggest day for Tangier Island since the British fleet sailed up Chesapeake Bay to attack Fort McHenry in 1812.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 11 points yesterday. Business was moderate.
Apprentice Edward J. Decker beat three top riders in the, Locust Walley, a $7,500 allowance event, at Jamaica race track yesterday. Be guided First Served, the outsider, home ahead of three rivals.
"Wayside" begins its career at 8 o'clock tonight at the Barbi zon-Plaza Theatre. The romantic melodrama, divided into fourteen scenes, is the handiwork of John Duff Stradley, in more ways than one.
DETROIT, April 16--L.L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, reported today that the company's sales in the first quarter of 1957 were in excess of $1,100,000,000.
The state moved yesterday for a contempt citation against Sylvester Cosentino, attorney for Joseph (Socks) Lanza, convicted extortionist.
The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $29,993,000 on temporary loan notes yesterday for the financing of Douglass Houses, a State-subsidized low-rent project on Manhattan's, West Side.

State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes won the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey yesterday. Complete unofficial returns from 4,100 of the state's 4,213-election dis tricts gave Senator Forbes 204,457 votes "to 119,856 for his opponent, State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, charged yesterday that industry groups were seeking national legislation that would ban the union shop "and all other forms of union security."
WASHINGTON, April 16-- Congress decided today that Jacob Burck, Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist, should not be deported to his native Poland because of past membership in the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- President Eisenhotver intervened today for a second time-to get the budget for his overseas propaganda agency increased by 26 per cent, but it is a losing battle.

CHICAGO, April 16--The decline that started in the grain market yesterday was extend de somewhat in early trading today on the Board of Trade. But there was active support later and prices showed a fair recovert. Buying was by shorts land commission houses.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 16-- Tension is mounting among those in Istanbul and Izmir (Smyrna) who are of Greek descent. This coincided with the stepping-up of newspaper criticism directed principally against the Orthodox Church.
WARSAW, April 16--The Polish Government is counting heavily on Communist China's support to forestall renewed Soviet interference in the internal affairs of Poland.

Senator Harry F. Byrd, has announced that the Senate Finance Committee, of which he is chairman, is planning, to make a study of "the financial conditions of the United States," The inquiry will begin, he says, as soon as a staff can be assembled.

LONDON, April 16--Jules Moch, chief of the French delegation to the United Nations Disarmament. Subcommittee, gave four reasons today why a major world disarmament agreement was believed to be impossible now.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- The Republican leader of the Senate stepped in today to try to hold its Judiciary Committee together until action was taken on civil rights legislation.

The Long Island Division of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will benefit from "A Carnival for Animals" dinner dance to be held at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Vaileyf, L.I., on May 17.
A big local of the International Longshoremen's Association and a New York bank joined forces yesterday in a campaign to help drive loan sharks from the piers.
The Government has admitted Leon Trotsky's widow into this country. The intent is to tap her vast knowledge of the inside story of the Soviet Union's early years and of world communism generally.
There was an unscheduled added touch of color at Yankee Stadium yesterday gas major league baseball returned to the local scene.
TRENTON, April 16--Malcolm Stevenson Forbes made up his mind to seek the Governorship as a Princeton undergraduate.

AMONG the abstract paintings in Paul-Brach's first one-man show, at the Castelli Gallery, 4 East Seventy-seventh Street, "Phalanx," a large, nearly square canvas toned with a pale yellow wash, proves to be the most integrated and dramatic.

Earnings reports, dividend announcements and, in at least three cases, hopes for stock splits provided most of the interest in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Despite good gains by a number of favored issues, the market as a whole had a moderate loss.

Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that the Federal Highway Administrator did not believe that the proposed shore approach in Brooklyn for the Narrows Bridge would qualify for Federal highway aid. The bridge will connect Brooklyn and Staten Island.

DAME SYBIL THORNDIKE and Sir Lewis Casson mo mentarily slipped away from their regular chores in "The Potting Shed" yesterday after noon to appear in the American premiere of their program of poetry and classic readings at the Theatre de Lys.
WASHINGTON, April--16 There is a serious deficiency, in United States flag passenger liner service on the North Atlantic routes to Europe, the Maritime Administration reported today.

MIKE WALLACE, television's arch-inquisitor, faced three of his former guests last night on "Entertainment Press Conference" over Channel 5. He replied with dignity and conviction to a series of questions about his tactics as an interviewer and his private life.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16-- Gino Cimoli, who finally won the job of playing left field for the badgers, cemented his hold on it tonight.

LONDON, April 16--A late rally in the stock market today didn't ofset all early losses. Closing prices were mostly irregular with Government securities off and gains outnumbered losses among the industrial issues.

That useful civic agency the Citizens Union holds its sixtieth anniversary dinner tonight and it is a pleasure to offer a birthday salute. Its lifetime spans the existence of the consolidated Greater New York City. It has been in the thick of many a fight for the principles of better government.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 16 --What may be a significant step in understanding nuclear forces was reported today at the seventh annual conference on high energy nuclear physics.
ALBANY, April 16--Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill that would have relaxed requirements for re-examination of accident-prone bus drivers.

It took a little more than two hours at the Stadium yesterday, in the Yankees' first game of the season, for the 1957 American League pennant race to fall into an old and familiar pattern. When the big moment came, it arrived with customary dramatic and noisy effect.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., April 17--Richard H. Long, twice Democratic candidate for Governor of Massachusetts, died last night in Framingham Union Hospital after a brief illness. He was 91 years old. Mr. Long was defeated by Calvin Coolidge in 1918 and 1919.

Corporate news, actual and prospective, ruled movements on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Save for steels, which were mostly weak, and metals, which were mostly strong, the major groups did little. Interest was confined to individual issues scattered throueh the list.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- The Daughters of the American Revolution today supported Richard Arens, director of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, in demanding that the McCarran-Walter immigration law to left intact.
LONDON, April 18--With business volume low on the eve of the Easter holiday, stock market prices showed no decided trend in most sections.
CHICAGO, April 18--Hardening of human artries probably begins in infancy or early childhood and sets the stage for heart failure later.
WASHINGTON, April 18,-- President Eisenhower reduced his appropriations request to Congress by $1,342,000,000 today. The reduction included $500,000,000 in the military portion of foreign aid.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 6 points off yesterday. Fluctuations were extremely narrow.
WASHINGTON, April 18--A hearing examiner of the Federal Trade Commission agreed with Food Fair Stores, Inc., today that the grocery chain is, in fact, a "packer" under the terms of Federal law.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Atomic secrets were guarded in a Federal court here today by a procedure seldom used.

The Bard of Stratford-onAvon will have a 393d birthday party Tuesday. The celebration, to be given by the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy of Stratford, Conn., will be a luncheon in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria.

WASHINGTON, April 18--Another slight increase in the number of college graduates of teaching courses was reported today by the National Education Association. report, "Teacher Supply and Demand," the association said the gain in graduates of the teacher-training courses would amount to 10 per cent this year. There was also a 10 per cent increase last year.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 18-- President Eisenhower played eighteen holes of golf in a warm rain today as he began a long Easter holiday.

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose between March 15 and last Monday to the largest figure reported since Feb. 15, 1855. The latest figure was 3,071,799 shares, compared with 3,002,510 a month earlier.
An ice-scarred veteran of the Polar seas, the Navy's Redbud, sailed from here yesterday to open the 1957 supply season for the nation's defense system in the Far North.

HONG KONG, April 18--Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, chief of state of the Soviet Union, said today that recent talks between his country and other Communist countries had solved all problems of mutual relationships.
VIENNA April 17--Washington's hope that Austria could absorb 20,000 to 30,000 of the Hungarian refugees remaining here seems a doubtful one.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty operator, has purchased the taxpayer containing six stores at the southeast corner of Austin Street and Sixty-fifth Road, in Forest Hills, Queens. The deal was negotiated by Nat Fenold of the Rialto Realty Company, broker.
Sales finance companies increased their borrowings from the larger New York City banks by $71,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, contributing to a $115,000,000 increase in business loans.
Kingmaker of the Happy Hill Farm took the Woodside Open Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The six-furlong event attracted a field of seven. The crowd of 19,056 established Admiral Vee as the favorite.
Columbia University received a medal yesterday--two years late. It was presented by the Polish Committee for the Observance of Mickiewicz Centenary in commemoration of the poet's death in 1855.
MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP)-- Lew Burdette of the Milwaukee Braves, the National League's shutout leader last year with six, today blanked the Cincinnati Redlegs, 1--0, on a home run by Hank Aaron.
WASHINGTON, April 18--The Soviet Union set off Tuesday "one of the largest" nuclear explosions in its current series, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith, co-directors of the American Ballet Theatre, have announced the choreographers who are to contribute fifteen new works to their forthcoming "Festival of New Ballets." The festival will be held at the Phoenix Theatre on the four Monday evenings in May.

LONDON, April 18--Allied diplomatic circles are discussing an arrangement under which nations using the Suez Canal would pay tolls to Egypt on the understanding that the sum retained by her would be subject to international arbitration.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, largest in the country, has been divided by Pope Pius XII into two separate dioceses.
A four-alarm fire in two Harlem tenements yesterday took the lives of three persons and hospitalized five others.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) --Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, announced today an $300,000,000 program to prepare the nation's airports for the advent of the jet age.
HAM and turkey fanciers will find a bonanza of their favorites in food stores this weekend at very reasonable prices. They are being featured by most of the chain stores for the Easter holiday.
Wool prices rose yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. New highs for the life of the contracts were reached by the July and October tops and the July grease wool positions.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 18 (UP)-- Arnold Palmer, the golfers' golfer, and Ed Furgol, a former National Open champion, tied for the first-day leadership in the $40,000 Tournament of Champions today. They fought high winds, rain and cold to post par 72's.
TORONTO, April 18-The first ocean-going freighter reached this port from Europe today and signaled the start of as expected record shipping season there.
OTTAWA, April 18--The latest in a series of Canadian statements in the Norman case indicate that it will become an important issue in the election campaign.
The Rehearsal Club's benefit performance of "New Girl in Town" has been postponed from May 7 to June 24.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- The conviction Marcus Singer, Cornell University zoology professor, for contempt of Congress was upheld today by the Federal Court of Appeals. The vote was 2 to 1.
The weather was bad but Sal Maglie and the Dodgers were good in yesterday's home opening with the Pirates at Ebbets Field.

Health and welfare services for the children of New York City are failing to adapt to the needs of the rapidly shifting young population, the Community Council of Greater New York said yesterday.

Bernie Wefers, a former sprinting star and long a prominent figure in American track and field, died yesterday morning at Frances Schervier Hospi tal in Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 84. He had been suffering from arteriosclerosis.
George Metesky, the so-called "Mad Bomber," was committed to Matteawan Hospital for the Criminally Insane yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court.

There is a group of secondgraders at Public School 66 in the Bronx who, for the life of them, cannot figure out why white and Negro children cannot go to the same schools in some Southern communities. They have put the question to the White House.

Men who can make wise mar keting decisions are needed and the demand is growing steadily, the New-York chapter of the American Marketing Association was told yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel by Charles W. Smith, national president of the group.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Administration officials were at pains today to explain that the United States was under no commitment to use force to help defend Jordan.
ALGIERS, Algeria, April 18-- Increased costs of Government in Algeria as a result of the rebellion are shown in budget figured for the coming fiscal year released here.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) --A new track "phenom" who soon will make his debut in the United States has bettered the world javelin hurling record with a side-arm and underhand delivery, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, April 18--A lid has been clamped on official discussion of the Norman case.
PARIS, April 18--Within ten years the West must be prepared to fight an aggressor with 2,000mile nuclear missiles or with conventional arms, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Congress adjourned this afternoon for a ten-day Easter holiday with most of its work still to be done.
AMMAN, April 19 (UP)--King Hussein said today that his nation would fight "imperialism of all kinds," shun foreign pacts and combat "any imported dogma" such as communism.

The City Housing Authority filed plans yesterday for a $21,524,000 public housing project in Brooklyn. It will be the first in that borough this year.
