Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has resigned from Mayor Wagner's special committee for analyzing the Consolidated Edison Company's offer to buy the city's three rapid transit power plants.
ZURICH, April 21-The price of Interhandel common stock jumped from 1,440 francs to 1,518 here last week.
CHICAGO, April 21--A heavy tone dominated the wheat market much of last week. Crop news, on the whole, was favorable and rallies in new crop futures of wheat were shortlived.
Two second-half goals by Al Sonnenblick enabled Hakoah to defeat Brookhattan, 3-1, in a Lewis Cup soccer match yesterday at Zerega Oval, the Bronx.
Eleven venerable British motor cars arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Parthia and then banged, roared or clattered off to prepare for the second Anglo-American Vintage Car Rally.

ROME, April 21--Pope Pius XII said today that the world was still in the darkness of night, but "even this night in the world shows clear signs of a dawn that will come." The dawn will bring "a new day...

DETROIT, April 21 (AP)--The Ford Motor Company reported today its consolidated net sales for the first three months of 1957 amounted to $1,569,500,000, the highest quarterly sales in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) --The second game of a doubleheader between Washington and Baltimore was called tonight because of a power failure at the end of the fifth inning with Washington leading, 2-1.

HONOLULU, April 21 (AP)-- Pierre Woods of La Habra, Calif., kept his D Jaguar in the lead for all but six of the twenty-eight laps today to win the Gold Cup race in the Hawaii Sports Car Fiesta at Dillingham Air Force Base.
The production staff for "Copper and Brass" has been assembled and plans are under way to begin rehearsals here on Aug. 12.

A certified public accountant and his wife were fined $5,000 and received suspended prison sentences yesterday for income tax evasion growing out of the alleged embezzlement of funds from their employer.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- James R. Hoffa opened his defense against bribery accusations today with fifty pages of legal arguments.
Secretary of State Dulles, with President Eisenhower's blessing, yesterday revived the idea of peaceful liberation of captive peoples as a positive concept.

THINGS were distinctly second-nightish for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and this in spite of the fact that the program included the first new work of the current engagement.
The majority leader of the State Senate last night accused Governor Harriman of directing a smear campaign against "respectable Republicans."

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Supreme Court upheld today, 5-to-3, the argument of the Alleghany Corporation that it is a railroad holding company, subject to the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Leo Bernard Kagan of 115 East Eighty-ninth Street, an attorney, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
NEW HAVEN, April 22--Dr. Richard Swann Lull, retired paleontologist at Yale University and former director of Yale's Peabody Museum, died at his home here today. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) --The long-depressed United States shipbuilding industry now is booming with the biggest backlog of orders in its peacetime history, Maritime Administration officials said today.
WASHINGTON, April 22--A geneticist said today that radioactive fall-out from atomic tests carried no more genetic hazard than did the luminous dials of a wrist watch.
The thirteen-story office building at 607-9 Fifth Avenue, at the southeast corner of Forty-ninth Street, has been leased by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines from the Henry Phipps Estates, Inc.
The Army Air Defense Command yesterday confirmed reports that New York and other large cities would be defended by new missiles equipped with atomic warheads.
The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday it planned action that would prevent further last-minute cancellation of television programs because of jurisdictional disputes between labor unions.

WASHINGTON, April 22--In the current controversy over the budget for the United States Information Agency, the main problem is that this one agency is being blamed for the failure of the Administration as a whole to coordinate its propaganda effort.
LOS ANGELES, April 22-- Senator William F. Knowland asserted tonight that Federal taxes at the present rate would "ultimately undermine and perhaps destroy our free enterprise system."
Dr. Seymour Oppenheimer, retired specialist in ear, nose and throat diseases and in plastic surgery, died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)--It was like Sunday in the park on the White House lawn today as hundreds of children brought their parents along for the annual Easter egg roll.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 22-- The National Security Police announced today that they had closed the largest Greek society in Istanbul and arrested its secretary on charges of being a Greek spy against Turkey.
Qualified American reporters should be permitted to enter Communist China, the board of directors of The Associated Press said yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 22-- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo asked all members of his Cabinet to resign today in order to reconstitute the group along new lines.
Rent control offices in the city expect a 25 per cent upsurge in applications for increases when the new state law becomes effective July 1.

Opening tonight off Broadway are "It's An Ill Wind," at the Royal Playhouse, 62 East Fourth Street, and "The Mikado," at The Shakespearewrights, 264 West Eighty-seventh Street. Both will get under way at 7:45.
There has perhaps been no time in history when so many things were happening so fast and being so fully reported as they are today by so many media of communication to so many people.

LOS ANGELES, April 21-- Millions of dollars in "buried treasure" are being sought by the State of California in a campaign just getting under way.
New York University announced plans yesterday to establish a graduate study center at the Bell Telephone Laboratories this fall.
TAMARIU, Spain, April 22-- The lovely Costa Brava, Spain's, resort coast on the Mediterranean, is in the midst of a fantastic boom.

A strong plea for funds to implement the school integration program was sent to Mayor Wagner last night.

LONDON, April 22--British Communist party leaders decisively defeated a bid for greater freedom of discussion on policy at the final session of the party's annual conference today.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 23 --The British capital viewed Secretary of State Dulles' foreign policy speech yesterday as having fallen far short of its advance publicity. He was held to have said nothing new or illuminating.
ALBANY, April 22--Governor Harriman approved today a twoyear extension of residential rent control.
ALBANY, April 22--Legislation making a Regents scholarship available to one out of every twenty high school graduates within the state was approved today by Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Iranian Embassy confirmed today that the Iranian Governmen had instructed its national oil company not to sell oil to Israel.
Two producers of cigarettes and other tobacco items showed increased sales in the first quarter this year.

OTTAWA, April 22 (Canadian Press)--George Prudham, Minister of Mines, said today that Canada's mineral output would rise in value from about two billion dollars last year to at least three billion by 1960.
Record sales and net earnings were achieved for any first quarter this year by the Republic Steel Corporation.

EVER since he began playing here seven years ago, David Tudor has devoted himself to experimental composers. Recently, too, the young Philadephia pianist has become a sort of liaison performer between the United States and Europe.
The Transport Workers Union called on the Transit Authority yesterday to rescind its rule that requires suspension without pay for employes involved in accidents.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 19--Plans for a modern United States Embassy in the heart of this historic city have provoked a protest from a small group of architectural traditionalists.

The House of Representatives has decided, wisely, the think, not to cut Federal aid for rural libraries. For more than ten years the Library Services Bill wended its way into committee, out on the floor, into one house, then into the other, but somewhere along the line it managed to get snagged.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Secretary of State Dulles' comments in New York today on "liberation" of the Soviet satellite countries was the latest of a controversial series on the subject by himself, President Eisenhower and Republican party platforms.
Under Secretary of the Treasury, W. Randolph Burgess predicted last night continuing progress in reducing the national debt.
Frank H. Bartholomew, president of The United Press, said yesterday that a press association not only must keep pace but must make new developments available to its clients.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges moved irregularly yesterday in featureless trading, Sugar, wool, rubber, zinc and hides advanced, while potatoes, coffee, cocoa, copper and cottonseed oil declined.

Whether any particular reader of The New York Times is or is not acquainted with the difficulties of Cuba today, he must surely have had a shock on seeing a front-page story in the Sunday edition headlined: "Police in Havana Kill 4 Students."
The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for March and for the twelve months ended March 31.

LONDON, April 22--Britain disclosed tonight that she had pleaded with the Soviet Union last fall to recognize the legitimate interests of the nations using the Suez Canal and help the West achieve a settlement with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt.

Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, is one of nine soloists who will be making stadium debuts during this year's concerts. He will be soloist in the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Concerto at the season's first Lewisohn Stadium concert, on Monday, June 24.
Sales rose on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to 2,560,000 shares from 2,482,892 on Thursday, but the movements of the standard issues that make up the market averages were gentle.

CHICAGO, April 22--Further light to heavy rains over the major part of the winter wheat belt and a Washington announcement that the support price for wheat in 1958 would be $1.78 instead of $2, for this year, caused heavy selling of wheat and all new crop deliveries registered new lows. May wheat was relatively strong.

The Swedish-American Line has selected the Travelers Aid Society of New York as the beneficiary of a cruise cocktail dance to be held aboard the Gripsholm on May 27 after the ship's maiden voyage to New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22--Christopher Nash, a senior English major student at the University of California at Los Angeles, was named winner today of the annual Samuel Goldwyn Award for Creative Writing.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 22 (AP) --President Eisenhower today urged the public to honor America's merchant marine on May 22, National Maritime Day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 (AP)--Eddie Cantor and his wife, Ida, picked up their first Social Security check today, and the occasion was turned into a minor Hollywood production.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Supreme Court ruled today, in effect, that lower Federal courts must keep school segregation cases on their dockets until state-imposed discrimination against Negroes had been eliminated.
If the Government bond market is not remembered for the day before Christmas, it will be for the day after Easter.
Three years ago Hinton, Alberta, was a small town of 200 hardy souls scratching out a rugged living on the eastern slope of the snow-capped Canadian Rockies.
The University of Vermont baseball team concluded a sixgame trip yesterday by defeating Columbia, 10-7, at Baker Field. The game was called at the end of the eighth because of darkness.
HAVANA, April 22 (AP)-- President Fulgencio Batista laughed when told that his political opponents called him a "dictator."
Willie Mays and Ruben Gomez combined their talents at the Polo Grounds yesterday to give the Giants a snappy 3-1 victory over the Pirates in the opener of a two-game series.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- William G. Lias, West Virginia gambler, lost a $2,000,000 income-tax case in the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) --Distillers who contend they will have to dump millions of gallons of bonded whisky because they can't afford to pay the Federal tax on their product before selling it failed to win any sympathy from the Supreme Court today.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 22 --The outstanding records compiled by Montclair's baseball and football teams during the past fifteen years can be credited to one man: Clarence Oscar Anderson.
The legality of a law imposing a 20 per cent tax on the total value of advertising published in Canadian editions of United States magazines is to be tested in the courts.
A comet first seen by astronomers last Nov. 8 may be visible in the early evening sky late this week.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP)-- Cincinnati, loser in all four previous starts, entered the National League victory column tonight with a 10-6 verdict over the Cardinals. St. Louis made six errors.
A Kings County prosecutor said yesterday that he could not find any mental disturbance so far in Thomas J. Higgins, who is held on a charge of killing a Brooklyn woman.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Words, not lights, failed the Senators tonight at Griffith Stadium. They were completely nonplussed, unable to explain how the world champion Yankees made only three hits in the sixth inning, yet managed to score seven times in a round so bizarre it was almost incredible.

Two-thirds of the 1,290-footlong Steeplechase Pier, a landmark at Coney Island, was destroyed by fire yesterday.
New York yesterday became the fortieth state to permit state and municipal employes to come under the Social Security Act as well as their own retirement systems.

WILLIE MAYS breezed into the Polo Grounds clubhouse long after most of the other members of the Giants were out practicing for yesterday's game with the Pirates. Five steps in back of him trailed Andre Rodgers, the new shortstop sensation who is a reformed cricketer from Nassau in the Bahamas.

In a programmatic speech fully endorsed by President Eisenhower, Secretary Dulles again expounded and affirmed yesterday the basic concepts that guide American foreign policy in a world menaced by a Soviet imperialism possessing great and growing power of atomic aggression.
A new union strategy was decided on yesterday to block the shift of hat production from Danbury, Conn., once the country's hat capital.

The Climax Molybdenum Company and its major subsidiaries lifted consolidated net earnings in the first quarter to $4,081,552, or $1.58 a common share, Arthur H. Bunker, president, informed stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. In the period a year ago the net was $3,875,724, or $1.50 a share.

BROOKLYN, Conn., April 22 --Mrs. Amasa D. Pierce has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Esther Pierce, to William Averell Brown Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Brown of New York and the late Mr. Brown.

MRS. PHILIP WYLIE is unfair to professional book critics. She is guilty of wonderfully effective competition with us all. Her amiably sardonic critiques of her husband's declamatory manner and exclamatory style leave little to be said about his new book, "The Innocent Ambassadors." However, you have to read it to enjoy the pleasure of her contrapuntal comments on a fiery narrative of their adventures as they flew around the world.

The two five-story apartment buildings at 1374 and 1378 College Avenue in the Bronx have been purchased by Jeremiah C. Ingersoll from Herman, Benjamin and Louis Borax. Nat Rosen and Isidore Davidoff were the brokers.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Shields Co. is offering a new issue of $3,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible debentures of Walter Kidde Co., producer of aircraft accessories, textile machinery and industrial equipment.

The city of Detroit has designated April 30 for the sale of $5,000,000 of sewer bonds. The securities will come due serially on May 1 from 1958 to 1982.

Despite a legislative "freeze" on bank holding company operations, the Marine Midland Corporation should be able to continue its expansion, Baldwin Maull, president, said yesterday. The corporation is New York State's only large bank holding company.

Daisy, a burro-sized donkey, ended her ten days of stardom at Children's Zoo yesterday. Hereafter, for no fault of her own, she goes back to the chorus of the pony ride.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles exchanged greetings today as they met at National Airport.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 30--A special United Nations envoy reported today that India and Pakistan "still are desirous of finding a solution" for the long-disputed territory of Kashmir.

LONDON, April 30--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has written to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union that he appreciates the latter's interest in improving relations between Britain and the Soviet Union.

The conversation was disclosed in the form of questions to Harry Lanza at yesterday's public hearing by the Legislature's watchdog committee.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 30-- King Hussein emphasized today that he had no intention of binding Jordan to any treaty commitment under the Eisenhower Doctrine.

ALTHOUGH the material of James Lee's "Career" is familiar, it is no less sobering on that account. For this joyless chronicle of life in the New York theatre is fundamentally knowledgeable and discerning.

Dr. I. Victor Burger of 44 Gramercy Park North, Assistant Superintendent of Schools in charge of lower Manhattan, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he had been on sick leave since Christmas. His age was 65.

A comprehensive program of Federal aid to higher education was urged yesterday by Senator Jacob K. Javits. The program would consist of loans to needy students and institutions rather than outright grants.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 30 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Ali Abu Nuwar, deposed Chief of Staff of Jordan's Army, was quoted today as having urged King Saud of Saudi Arabia to intervene against "a dirty colonial conspiracy" in Jordan.
Plans to merge the Dixie Cup Company with the American Can Company were approved here yesterday by directors of the two companies.

PARIS, April 30--There are many invisible factors in the Middle East crisis and among these is the personality of a courteous, determined Egyptian diplomatist now serving as special counselor to the King of Saudi Arabia.
City Councilman Edward A. Cunningham resigned yesterday. His action had been expected since a New York County grand jury charged last week that he had "repeatedly abused" his office.

The nine-story building containing thirty-nine apartments at 15 West Seventy-fifth Street, near Central Park West, has been sold by Herman Axelrod to Louis Rosenberg for investment. It is on a plot of 89 by 102 feet. The L.J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company was the broker in the sale.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Navy was invited today to explain an allegation that it had financed a union shakedown of one of its contractors. A Navy spokesman said that a few days would be needed to look into the case.

LONDON, April 30--The Soviet Union recommended today a minimum world disarmament plan. It would include wide aerial inspection of areas in the United States, the Soviet Union and Europe along lines of President Eisenhower's "open skies" proposal.
A FAVORITE story is told on himself by the Dartmouth president, John Sloan Dickey, who has made it a practice to chat briefly with all incoming freshmen.
Don Zimmer brought a disorderly game at Ebbets Field to a favorable conclusion for the Dodgers last night by walloping a tenth-inning homer.
SINGAPORE, April 30--The Legislative Assembly approved today the agreement reached in London on a new Constitution granting full internal self-government to this British Crown Colony.

The creation of a centralized grievance machinery within the union movement to which individual members may apply for redress against abuses by their officers was urged yesterday by Prof. Walter Gellhorn of Columbia University Law School.
Raul Sterling, the leading rider at Jamaica, won the featured Midland Beach there yesterday abroad Pro Bono, who scored by a neck over the favored First Asking before 21,436 fans.
Highlights of a secretly recorded interview between Joseph (Socks) Lanza and his brother Harry were revealed yesterday by the legislative watchdog committee.

Starting today, sports, in the metropolitan area and at New York University in particular, may be in for some changes as the Violets' new director of athletics and physical education assumes his positions.

In the face of continued farm surpluses, drought, dust storms and bickering over parity, the head of the Oliver Corporation stoutly reaffirmed yesterday his belief that farm machinery is one of the true growth industries of the next twenty years.

HAZLETON, Pa., April 30-- Henry Walser, publisher of The Hazleton Plain Speaker and Standard-Sentinel, died at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 81. He was president of the First National Bank of Hazleton.
FIFTEEN chefs and pastry cooks will be at work in the subterranean kitchens of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Monday evening, preparing a classic French dinner that will cost $40 a plate.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 (AP)--Bermuda yachtsmen scored their second and third victories today over the United states in the Amorita Cup series.
MONTREAL, April 30 (UP)-- Cherif Hamia, a featherweight of Algiers and Paris, punched out a unanimous ten-round decision over Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, tonight.
ALBANY, April 30--The state's Republican leadership accused Governor Harriman today of paying off political debts to the Liberal party and selling out the interests of the workers.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- John Foster Dulles appealed from "my heart" to the Senate today to save his budget from deep cuts ordered by the House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, April 30--There was heavy pressure on the Board of Trade today on May deliveries of wheat, rye and oats, while deferred deliveries of these grains showed smaller declines Corn prices rose narrowly.

A public market is to be created today for the common stock of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. Private investors will be enabled to acquire a substantial stake in the intercontinental airline for the first time since before World War II.
The Cities Service Company's sales and earnings set records in the first quarter, W. Alton Jones, chairman, told yesterday's annual meeting at Dover, Del.
LONDON, April 30--The stock markets were quieter today. Industrials made some gains but the general tone was cautious.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) --Sales and earnings of all United States manufacturing corporations set new records in the fourth quarter of 1956, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The New York Legislature, which began its regular 1957 session on Jan. 9 and adjourned on March 30, finds that its work is not completed after all. Governor Harriman's decision to reconvene it in special session will not sit well with Republicans, who control the Legislature.

New bond financing rose in April above $1,500,000,000 for the second successive month. Flotations of housing, local government, World Bank and foreign bonds were substantially higher than a year earlier.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, hides, zinc and copper declined; rubber rose, and price movements for sugar, coffee, potatoes, soybean oil and wool were mixed.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Council of the Organization of American States will take up the Honduras-Nicaragua border dispute tomorrow. The session was requested by Honduras.

American Airlines has been canceling many outgoing flights from La Guardia Airport, citing a slowdown in maintenance work as the reason. The airline grounded thirty flights over the week-end and had canceled fifteen more by late yesterday afternoon.

The Braves moved into the Polo Grounds last night with regal elegance. Victors in nine of their first ten games, they must have regarded the nonetoo-robust Giants as a certain soft touch.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- Gordon Gray, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, defended today his award of special tax incentives to the Idaho Power Company for the construction of two power dams on the Snake River in Idaho. Several Congressional Democrats have assailed the award.
LONDON, April 30--Lord Mills, Minister of Power, said today that a plan had been worked out between British and French electricity authorities for the exchange of electricity by submarine cable.
DETROIT, April 30--The last time the Yankees faced Detroit's Duke Maas they knocked him out of the American League into the American Association.

CHICAGO, April 30--A "conservative" air traffic analyst predicted here today that by 1965 there would be 90,000,000 domestic airline passengers and by 1975 there would be 167,000,000. These are increases of 300 and 700 per cent over 1956 totals.

The three-story building at 322-24 East Forty-fourth Street has been leased by Harry W. Watts, commercial photographer, to the Imperiale Restaurant and Sturgis-Grant Productions, Inc. The restaurant has been a tenant there for many years on a sub-lease, Raymond E. Ryan was the broker.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- The year 1957 seems destined to be one of the most active test periods in the international race to develop new atomic weapons.

One of the country's major steamship lines will send a passenger liner into the Port of New fork this month for the first time in twenty-five years.
One of the country's most respected unions announced yesterday that it was increasing its investment in Government-guaranteed mortgages to $80,000,000.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 (UP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals' sluggers trounced the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9--2, today.

The Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls, which has cared for unfortunate young women for ninety-two years, will receive the proceeds of the May 16 performance of "The Tunnel of Love" at the Royale Theatre.
The Laclede Gas Company raised $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of first mortgage bonds at public sealed bidding.

FROM every point of view Guenter Rutenborn's "The Sign of Jonah" is a remarkable play. In an hour's time it concentrates the passion of mankind.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 1--Honduran troops, assisted by air power, drove Nicaraguan troops out of the town of Mocoron about noon today.
The nation's new civil defense warning network was put into operation yesterday.

A system of delivery permits on export cargo was reactivated yesterday amid a storm of protest from railroads, steamship lines and shippers.
Conflicting views were expressed yesterday on the economic and trade position of Colombia.
Sergi Denham, a former banker who is director of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, was confronted with a problem that was both financial and artistic at the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday night.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)--Minnie Minoso, with a double, two singles and a sacrifice fly, drove across four runs today as the first-place Chicago White Sox gained their ninth triumph in eleven games. They downed the Baltimore Orioles, 9-3.

The price of transit peace next year was quoted yesterday at $62,000,000. The estimate was made by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union. He offered it in announcing his union's full list of demands covering 35,000 employes of the Transit Authority.

Two traffic safety crusaders demonstrating hazardous driving practices ran afoul of the law yesterday. The result was that William J. Toth, radar expert on the staff of the New York University Center for Safety Education, received a summons for driving the wrong way on a one-way street.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (U.P.)-- The Army announced today that it had adopted a standard rifle to replace four types of shoulderfired weapons. It will be issued to the troops in 1960.

Tony Manero is one of the few native New Yorkers who has won a United States open golf championship. Although he is now 52 and the manager of a Greenwich (Conn.) restaurant, Manero is a regular competitor in tournaments in this area.
The dogwood trees are a beautiful sight these days along Route 25A on Long Island, but one passing driver ignored the blossoms yesterday.

In a defense of State Department restrictions against assignment of United States reporters to Communist China, Secretary of State Dulles has declared that the Administration's foreign policy would be impotent if Americans did not accept "certain restraints."
LONDON, May 1--The British Government reiterated today its conviction that Egypt must allow Israeli ships to use the Suez Canal.
LOS ANGELES, May 1--Grant Mitchell, a character actor and a leading stage and screen performer for nearly half a century, died today in Wilshire Sanitarium after a long illness.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Federal Government's housing chief today gave New York City a virtual promise of $30,500,000 in Federal funds for slum clearance between now and June 30, 1958.

Oils and aluminums dominated yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Eight of the fifteen most active issues were oils and all but one rose. Ten oils set new highs for the year. All four aluminums gained.

Net profit of Loew's, Inc., and subsidiaries, including theatre divisions, increased to $2,729,248 in the twenty-eight weeks ended March 14 from $1,889,843 earned in the similar period of the previous year.
CHICAGO, May 1--Wheat was weak today, with new crop futures dropping into new low ground for the season. May was sharply lower on long liquidation.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 1 --The admissions office at Sarah Lawrence College made a good laboratory today for studying the process of admitting students to the Class of 1961.

The Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday made a two-for-two player deal that at first glance will strengthen both teams. Dale Long and Lee Walls moved from Pittsburgh to Chicago in exchange for Gene Baker and Dee Fondy.
ST. JOHNS, Nfld., May 1-- Negotiations expected to result in a multi-million dollar development of iron ore in Labrador by major North American iron and steel companies are reaching their final form.
WASHINGTON, May 1--President Eisenhower carried to the people today his fight with Congress over the budget and the remainder of his stalled legislative program.
DETROIT, May 1--If the twelve hits the Detroit Tigers collected today were placed end to end they might have matched the distance of one that Tony Kubek belted for the Yankees.

WARSAW, May 1--Poland's Communist rulers went through the expected motions this May Day but it was an apathetic 100,000 who marched and an even more apathetic 100,000 who lined the short parade route to stare but not to cheer.
HONG KONG, May 1--The Peiping radio warned today that industrial production in Communist China was "very low" and said it must be raised to realize the Socialist dream of the nation.

WASHINGTON, May 1--A "battle of business giants" and two major agencies of Government resumed today on Capitol Hill. It involves the country's big meat packers and food chains and whether they shall be scrutinized for unfair trade practices and other violations of Federal laws by the Department of Agriculture or the Federal Trade Commission.

CHICAGO, May 1--The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad expects 1957 revenues to equal those of 1956 despite a poor start in the first quarter, Harry C. Murphy, president, said today at the annual meeting. Last year the road had a gross of $212,288,000 and a net income of 521,565,000.

First there were twenty-five Councilmen. Now there are twentythree. Edward A. Cunningham, Democrat of the Bronx, has followed Hugh Quinn, Democrat of Queens, into resignation after investigation on charges of violation of the City Charter.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- A Republican politician from Georgia testified today that he and his wife made a quick stock market profit of more than $2,500 after getting an indication of a secret air route decision by the Government.
The world sugar contract extended its recent decline in active trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower began the annual United Cerebral Palsy drive today at the White House. She was photographed with 2 year-old Sarah Johncox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Johncox of Arlington, Va.

The Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field, of which Senator McClellan is chairman, has so far concentrated almost wholly on the improper activities of labor.

The General Dynamics Corporation, a widely diversified industrial organization, announced yesterday the election of Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army, as president and chief executive officer.
The City Planning Commission yesterday designated three days of public hearings on $160,000,000 worth of proposed metropolitan highways. They will be held May 15, 16 and 17.

The arrival of a big aircraft carrier and fourteen other warships, followed by a ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway, will mark a tribute today to sixtyseven Navy and Marine heroes.

ESSEN, Germany, May 1 (AP) --Archie Moore, the light heavyweight champion, today scored an easy ten-round decision over Hans Kalbfell of Germany in a nontitle fight. Moore weighed 206 pounds. The light heavyweight class limit is 175 pounds.

Inadequate relief pitching spelled the downfall of the Giants again yesterday. The leagueleading Milwaukee Braves beat the New Yorkers, 5-1, with a four-run explosion in the tenth inning against two lower echelon inhabitants of manager Bill Rigney's bullpen.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Senator Harry F. Byrd drew applause from the United States Chamber of Commerce today with a suggestion that Percival F. Brundage, Director of the Budget, be replaced.

The Park Association of New York City called on the Police Department yesterday to provide more protection in the city's parks. It cited the drowning of three boys in a Central Park lake Sunday afternoon. Two of them were 13 years old and one was 12.

Outstanding loans to business by the larger New York City banks increased $43,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with one of $122,000,000 in the like week last year.

If grandmothers want to help their grandchildren, they should do so in the home and not invade schools and strike teachers. That was what three justices of the Court of Special Sessions told a 58-year-old grandmother yesterday as they sentenced her to a ten-day jail term.

A collection of paintings featuring the first showing in this country of a self-portrait by El Greco will be exhibited here Sunday through next Wednesday. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem will benefit from the showing.

AKITA, Japan, May 2 (AP)-- Japan's first two-stage supersonic rocket, the Kappa-3, zoomed to an altitude of thirteen miles today in its first test.

Annie the penguin, the only known survivor of the old Aquarium, will officially open the new Aquarium. According to human plans, the feathered symbol of formal pomp will bite through a ribbon stretched across the front door of the new Aquarium at Coney Island.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3-- The National Association for Practical Nurse Education voted unanimously today to strengthen its program of instructor recruitment for practical nursing schools. The action was taken at the closing session of the group's annual convention here.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The House Appropriations Committee rejected today the $50,000,000 requested by President Eisenhower to start a program of insurance against flood damage. An emergency substitute motion to grant $14,000,000 as a minimum to start the program was defeated by a vote of 19 to 14.

A three-alarm fire yesterday aboard the British freighter Manipur at Pier 26 in Brooklyn caused "considerable damage" to the vessel's cargo. It consisted of jute, burlap, hemp and silicon.

New York City's Police Department has an actual strength of 23,369 men. This includes about 800 men who are in the Police Academy, probationers who will be graduated to active service in June.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Senator William F. Knowland raised warning signals today of possible Senate opposition to the international atomic energy agency proposed by President Eisenhower.

An Austrian steel company, whose iron ore reserves were first exploited to produce armor for the Roman legions, has been granted a $20,000,000 United States credit to help it modernize its facilities.

Municipalities in New York State are not protecting existing housing against deterioration, State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray reported yesterday.

The City Council will tackle tomorrow the job of finding new chairmen for its two most important committees. They are to replace Hugh Quinn of Queens and Edward A. Cunningham of the Bronx. Mr. Quinn and Mr. Cunningham, both Democrats, resigned as Cquncilmen within the last three weeks under charges of violating the conflict-of-interest provisions of the City Charter.
Tickets may still be obtained for the May 13 preopening performance of "New Girl in Town," which will benefit Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

There was a fiesta on Fifth Avenue yesterday as 25,000 New Yorkers of Spanish cultural background paraded under the auspices of the Federation of Hispanic Societies.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The Democratic party's national leaders today labeled Administration foreign policy as one of "appeasement," "posturing' and "slogans."

LOUISVILLE, May 5--Not long before Max Schmeling fought Joe Louis for the first time, Herr Moxie sat at the ringside while the Bomber was destroying Paulino. The German nodded owlishly and made a rather historic announcement.

CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP)-- Jackie Jensen's two-run homer enabled the Boston Red Sox to win the second game of a double-header from the Cleveland Indians today, 4--3, after the Red Sox had captured the opener, 5--1.

A New York attorney and legal publisher yesterday charged that Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, was "suppressing" a report of the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust and Monopoly Legislation because "the Senator doesn't agree with it "

At the last session of Congress $1,000,000 was appropriated to start a scientific survey of the nation's health. The work has now begun. Working through regional offices of the Bureau of the Census, trained interrogaters will visit about 3,000 homes a month. Their findings will be tabulated on the cross-section as well as regional basis.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 4--The United States vied with Communist China for a starring role in the international fair that opened here today. The American and Chinese pavilions drew the largest crowds and the loudest compliments on opening day.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 5 --Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., who won yesterday's tune-up regatta with Susan, scored his second International Class victory of the young season today in the opener of the five-race Stanley Trophy series.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 --A relatively obscure Government agency, the Office of Compliance and Security, is to be the basis of a projected new television adventure series.
Hundreds of persons have been questioned about the shooting of Frank Costello, the police said yesterday, but no motive has yet been established.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP)--Seven Americans in the creative arts received citations tonight from Boston University, as the university's Conference on the Creative Arts ended.

Gordon Sherwood's Introduction and Allegro, which won the twelfth annual George Gershwin Memorial Award of the B'nai B'rith Victory Lodge, received yesterday afternoon the premiere performance by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

GRANITE SPRINGS, N.Y., May 5--Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan of New York, recognizing the "exurbian" growth of his Protestant Episcopal diocese, visited today an outpost forty-five miles north of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

Last week this space was devoted to a discussion of the enormous spread, in recent years, of the pension idea in the United States, and the resultant spectacular rise in importance of the pension fund as an element in the investment market.

Miss Carol Marion Sand was married yesterday at noon to Samuel Isaiah Kaplan in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by the Rev. Eugene Sack of Temple Beth Elohim of Brooklyn. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Sand of Brooklyn. Mr. Kaplan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Kaplan of Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 5--The executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters prepared today an aggressive approach to its hearing before the labor federation's Ethical Practices Committee tomorrow.

Shortly after last June's historic Poznan demonstration in Poland Soviet Premier Bulganin came to Warsaw and demanded that the Polish press be muzzled. That demand was then politely but firmly rejected, and the plain speaking of the Polish press was one of the key forces which permitted last October's peaceful revolution.

BONN, Germany, May 5-- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will arrive here Tuesday with the specific mission of averting an internal crisis in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over the British Government's new defense program.
A fifteen-month study has found that many normal families who need and are eligible for public housing are shunning it because, problem families have given it a "bad name."
FORT WORTH, May 5 (AP)-- Roberto De Vicenzo of Argentina won the $25,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament today.
NEW BRIGHTON, Minn., May 5 (AP)--Sad Sam was carried to 90,000 feet today by a big, shimmering balloon to test high altitude parachute equipment for the Air Force. But Sad Sam refused to "jump."

MARC BLITZSTEIN'S garden is New York. In his new cantata, "This Is the Garden," he sings of the Lexington Avenue Express, a San Gennaro festa in Little Italy, a street accident, a strange birth and the lovers who seek to be alone "in twos."

Dorothy Bullock, pianist, played a debut recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Her program offered MacDowell's Fourth Sonata, Op. 59, Chopin's Ballade in F Minor, Op. 59, that composer's Andante Spianato and Grande Polonaise, Schumann's "Novelette," and works of Ravel, Debussy, Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Powell and Dohnanyi.

In its first change of ownership in thirty-five years, the sixstory apartment house for twenty-four families at 710 East Fifth Street was sold by the Fifth Street Realty Company to Seymour M. Tannenbaum, realty operator. The building contains two stores and is assessed at $30,000. Ralph Marx, broker, arranged the sale for cash.
It has become the custom of this department to look at least once a year into the doings of Jimmy Curran, Mercersburg Academy's fabulous 77-year-old coach.
Israel's ninth anniversary as a nation was celebrated with colorful ceremonies on the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon.
VIENNA, May 5--Vice Chancellor Adolf Schaerf, a Socialist party leader, was elected today the third post-war President of Austria.

OXFORD, England, May 5--The entire world seems plagued by budget troubles. We in the United States are acutely familiar with this exasperating problem. A drive to trim expenses threatens to cut dangerously into defense and foreign aid appropriations.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 5-- The political crisis mounted to a new pitch here today following police clashes with demonstrating students.
The German-American League All-Stars defeated the Kaiserslautern Football Club of West Germany, 1 to 0, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
ZURICH, May 5--A larger volume of stock exchange business was done the last week in Zurich than for some time past.
The Giants and Cubs, for whom the immediate future looms none too bright, spent nearly six hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday helping each other to the best of their ability.

NEW ROCHELLE, May 5-- Current criticisms of subur ban life are, to a large extent true, a group of suburban parents agreed this week-end, but the drawbacks of a commuter's existence and the problems of his family life are more than matched by advantages.

WASHINGTON, May 5-- Budget slashers who are ready to attack the foreign-aid bill will have occasion this week for second thoughts when President Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam arrives Wednesday for a four-day state visit.

WILLIAM MAXWELL AITKEN, first Baron Beaverbrook, statesman, publisher and one of the wealthiest men in England, has always delighted in the unexpected. DEPOSIT, N.Y., May 5--At 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, 1,500 persons were evacuated from Binghamton after a mock airraid alert. They were given shelter in cellars in this small town twenty-eight miles away.

"Religious" living was defined yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. McManus at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He said it was living in the knowledge that "I am a creature--the work of God's hands"...

DETROIT, May 5 (AP)--Frank Lary pitched the Detroit Tigers to their fourth straight victory today. Charlie Maxwell drove in the deciding runs with a seventhinning single for a 3-1 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 --The secondary co-starring roles in "Peyton Place" will be portrayed by Arthur Kennedy and Betty Field. Mark Robson, director, will begin filming the Jerry Wald-Twentieth CenturyFox picture this week on location in Maine.
Bank credit may well take the edge off continuing strong pressures in the market for longterm funds, the Bankers Trust Company says in its. "Investment Outlook for 1957," published today.

The award of twenty-six medals to members of the Police Department for heroism last year was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. Mayor Wagner will present the medals at City Hall later.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 5-- Sloan fellowships have been awarded to thirty-six young business executives for participation in the executive development program of Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, May 5--Adlai E. Stevenson renewed his criticism today of continued testing of large hydrogen bombs by the United States. He said they threatened the rest of the world with "contamination without representation."
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 5--President Eisenhower's special mission to the Middle East has elicited whole-hearted approval of his doctrine in eleven of fourteen countries it has visited.

LOUISVILLE, May 5 (AP)-- Gallant Man's trainer leveled a blast at Churchill Downs today, and said Willie Shoemaker "rode a masterful race" in the Kentucky Derby although he dropped a nose decision to Iron Liege from the Calumet Farm.

Bernard M. Baruch has delivered to Holt the manuscript of the first volume of his memoirs and plans are for publication late this summer. As yet untitled, the memoirs will be in two volumes, the first of which will cover the first part of his...

THE Chinese Chamber of Commerce at 2 Mott Street has researchers out trying to trace the history of the Chinese in New York. The material is to go into a publication to mark the chamber's twentyfifth anniversary.

CHICAGO, May 5--Wheat futures declined last week, with the old-crop May delivery off the most. The chief depressing factor on the May option was a report that the Commodity Credit Corporation had been selling defaulted wheat holdings on the Atlantic Coast and that it was offering additional amounts.

The Polish Falcons of Elizabeth, N.J., defeated the Newark Portuguese, 3--2, yesterday to take first place in the Lewis Cup competition of the American Soccer League. At halftime of the game played at Zerega Oval, the Bronx, the victors led, 2--1.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Monday, May 6--For the first--time in the vast Moslem land from Cairo to Casablanca women shared with men today the right of self-government.
NEWBURGH, May 5--If the laity of the church ever becomes mute the world will lose its strongest weapon against the evils of the contemporary age, Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell declared here today.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 4 (Reuters)--Disregarding the advice of the Brazilian Institute of Engineers that the plan of the Alweg Corporation of Cologne for a rapid transit system was not suitable for Sao Paulo, the Municipal Transport Company has authorized a contract with the West German concern for construction of a metropolitan monorail network.

The recipients of eight fellowship grants at Columbia University for persons in the field of radio and television news and public affairs were announced yesterday by the C.B.S. Foundation, Inc. The foundation was established by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 5--Nicaragua and Honduras agreed tonight to a cease-fire in their border conflict. The agreement, negotiated by a peace mission of the Organi zation of American States, was held up for several hours by unconfirmed reports of a new Honduran attack against a Nicaraguan town.

THIS week Americana is paus ing briefly on its journey from the nation's attics to its gardens. The pause is a biannual antiques show at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. It will last until Saturday and will be open daily...
WASHINGTON, May 5--Senators will get their first chance to cut the President's budget this week when the Appropriations Committee votes on the Treasury-Post Office bill.

Today, in the fifth year of this Republican Administration, our fiscal affairs are approaching a crisis. The failures of the Eisenhower fiscal policies are apparent. The burden of these failures rests heavily on the average American family.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 5 --Linda Thomas, 14, won three blues to lead the Thomas School of Horsemanship, Huntington, L.I., to team honors in the junior Essex horse show today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 5--A showplace food store, the Kroger Company's most modern, will open here Tuesday on the site of a former baseball park.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 5-- Two weary Princetonians limped into the student center here at 3:45 o'clock this afternoon. They had kicked a soccer ball to New York and back in forty-nine hours.

HARRIMAN, N.Y. May 5-- The American Assembly of Columbia University endorsed today a long-range loan program for foreign development. The sixty leaders of business, government and scholarly professions meeting at Arden House...
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 5--Dutch dividends generally have exceeded expectations.

Five young students and Rex Stout, the author, joined yesterday in a discussion of youthful economics on the New York Times Youth Forum. The question was: "Do allowances help youth learn money values?"

ST. LOUIS, May .5 (AP)-Dr. Joseph W. Kennedy, one of four scientists who discovered the element plutonium, essential in making atomic bombs, died today of cancer at his home in suburban Ladue. His age was 40. He had been in ill health since last fall.
LONDON, May 5--The relaxation of tension in Jordan and the relative quiet in the Middle East gave the stock market a cheerful tone last week and there was a broad improvement in prices.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5-- The Rev. Dr. Hugh Halton, Roman Catholic Chaplain of Princeton University, continued today his attack on the American Association of University Professors. He said that group could be held responsible for the "decay of patriotism and morals" in America.

WASHINGTON, May 6--Democrats and Republicans battled today to win credit for keeping "right-to-work" provisions out of the civil rights, program.

At this time, both in the Philippines and in the United States, we are observing the fifteenth anniversary of the fall of Bataan and Corregidor. It is a joint memorial service that once more recalls a joint and gallant effort.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 6-- Mr. and Mrs. Alistair F. Graham-Johnston have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nicole Graham-Johnston, to Charles Gulden Jr. He is the son of Mr. Gulden of Laurel Hollow and the late Mrs. Samatha Gaynor Isham Gulden. The wedding has been planned for June.
DETROIT, May 6--Most of the 40,500 Chrysler workers affected by wildcat walkouts last week returned to their jobs this morning. But two more walkouts harassed the company again today.
Last week the Department of Agriculture reported on a survey of the proposal to substitute the hundred weight for the bushel as the standard measure for grain.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 6--Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, chief of state of the Soviet Union, arrived here today on a state visit.

The spot May potato contract rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume in potatoes was the best of the year and almost all the activity was in the May position. It rose 26 points (hunting)

Willis Delano Wood, partner in the stock brokerage firm of Wood, Walker Co., died yesterday at his winter residence in Coconut Grove, Fla., after a long illness. He was 84 years old. Mr. Wood's New York home was at 635 Park Avenue, and his country home was at Lloyd Neck, L.I.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The United States has proposed to its allies relaxation of the embargo on their trade with Communist China to the extent of about 160 items.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., May 6--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Boorstein of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Edith Boorstein, to Richard Schlesinger Cohen. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Cohen of New Brunswick.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6-- The Writers Guild of America intends to demand separate payments for all story material used for television entertainment that may be presented to a paying audience.

HAVANA, May 6--Congress began consideration today of an election plan that leaders of both Government and Opposition political parties hope will end the revolutionary killings, bombings and sabotage in Cuba.
WHITE PLAINS, May 6--A "Little Hoover Commission" was formed today to modernize the Governmental system of Westchester County, Sitting as a charter revision committee, it will recommend reforms.

Stocks went through a quiet and generally uneventful session on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. They opened almost unchanged and, judged by the averages, barely moved from hour to hour until they sold off at the close.

Cohoes won pretty much as he pleased before 24,207 fans at Jamaica yesterday. The Greentree Stable color-bearer was the 3-5 choice in a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds, and he scored by two lengths over Timely Bull.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Democratic party leaders have been in the capital for the last three days demonstrating once more the woes of a divided party in opposition.
The British pound has staged a "notable recovery" from the speculative pressures generated by the Suez crisis, the Federal

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia won the international tournament at the Stevenson Memorial chess congress at Bognor Regis in Sussex according to a report received yesterday from England.
WASHINGTON, May 6--Canada is keeping alive its vigorous complaints against the sale by the United States of wheat to Poland on "soft" credit terms.
CHICAGO, play 6 (AP)--Practically all grain futures ended lower on the Board of Trade today.
BONN, Germany, May 6--A Government spokesman made an effort today to deflate the propaganda war between Bonn and Moscow over the introduction of atomic weapons in the Nest German Army.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The A.F.L.-C.I.O. Ethical Practices Committee accused the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on eight counts of corruption today and gave the union eighteen days to reply.

The price of zinc dropped 1 cents a pound yesterday, to 12 cents, East St. Louis. Buying continued slack and producers showed increasing uneasiness over the future of Government price support measures.
The city is asking for a loyalty oath from applicants for permits to fish in its reservoirs. It has refused such permits to two leading Communists.
WASHINGTON, May 6--A House inquiry showed today that some farmers received Government payments last year for crop failures on the same land on which they were paid not to grow crops.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Civil Aeronautics Board, in seeking enforcement of subpoenas for documents, need not show that each paper is "relevant and material."

A refresher course on the essentials of world power began yesterday for 500 civilian executives and reserve officers. The National Resource Conference, last held here in 1955, opened at the 107th Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue.
CRESTWOOD, N.Y., May 6 --Bob Watson and George Rudolph of Ardsley registered a 61 today to capture top honors in the Dr. M. H. Buchman Memorial pro-amateur tournament at the Leewood Golf Club.
LONDON, May 6--Most stocK market prices advanced today. Industrials registered gains of as much as 12s ($1.68). Some Government securities closed below their days best prices.

Trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road have threatened to strike May 15.
AMMAN, Jordan,, May 6--The Military Governor of Jordan said today that three former topranking. Jordanian Army officers who fled into exile would be tried for treason.
Senator Karl E. Mundt yesterday described Alger Hiss' book as "the age-old complaint voicing the views of the convict after the court has issued its verdict of 'guilty.' "

ANGLERS are raising a medium--sized clamor against the way the woods were closed to them on Saturday. Their complaints do not appear to be justified, which does not mean they ought to deprive themselves of the pleasure of complaining; it only means that they are wrong.
Once again the people of a LatinAmerican nation are rising against their dictator. This time it is Colombia, and the dictator is President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla.

M-O-T-H-E-R spells Mother. And there are only five shopping days left to get her a gift. For those who have drawn a blank on ideas, Abraham Straus is staging a Mother's Day blouse and sweater style show on Thursday from 5.30 to 7 P. M. in the fourth floor restaurant.
Another unit of the rapidly growing fleet of the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company, the 3,900-deadweight-ton motor ship Themis, is due here today from Holland on her maiden voyage.
A $100,000 "high command" is in the offing for the five city colleges.
The annual Pulitzer awards in the fields of journalism and letters have now been made for 1957, and they are interesting as always.
The witching hour of midnight and Gino Cimoli struck simultaneously at Ebbets Field last night. At exactly 12 o'clock the young outfielder belted a ball on a line into the lower left-field stands.
Construction of the Enrico Fermi atomic power plant at Lagoona Beach, Mich., is "moving forward and up to schedule," Walker L. Cisler, president of the Detroit Edison Company.

Multiplexing, the system by which a frequency modulation radio station can transmit two programs simultaneously on the same channel, has been put into operation here. The system has been used in a few other cities, but WFMX is the first station to operate multiplexing in New York.

THE face is familiar. It sells cigarettes, whisky, shirts, trench coats and shaving cream in a thousand different ads. It belongs to a male model, and if it is the right face, it can make his fortune.

MUNICH, Germany, May 6-- Two of Hitler's most accom-, plished gunmen defended today their key roles in 1934 slaying of Ernst Roehm and six other top Storm Troop leaders. They called the slaying a routine execution of lawful orders.
Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called last night "for the formulation of a new American policy toward the satellites" of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- The staff of a House Appropriations subcommittee, in a report on defense buying, said today it had found "weaknesses," "deficiencies," "delays" and "conflicts." It recommended an overall review, of Army award practices.
DETROIT, May 6 (AP)--The auto industry's weekly car out put is moving up and down within a narrow range.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 6-- Protein intake, and not fats in diet alone, was indicated today to be an important factor in heart and artery afflictions that plague food-rich nations.
BUFFALO, May 6--The $33,000,000,000 mutual savings bank industry set forth on a new course here today. Crawford H.
The State of Texas is planning to sell $12,500,000 of veterans' land purchase bonds'on May 28. The securities will come due serially from 1966 to 1986.

Four hundred professional writers from many parts of the country met at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday for their first "national assembly."
An era of progress and opportunity unequaled in history is just ahead, in the view of Rhys M. Sale, president of the Ford Motor Company of Canada.

VALPARAISO, Fla., May 6--A B-47 Stratojet bomber was put through a "toss-bombing" maneuver at Eglin Air Force Base this afternoon for the first time in public. Then maneuver had been practiced for more than a year.
Details are said to have been agreed upon to bring "Compulsion," a melodrama dealing with the Leopold-Loeb murder case, to Broadway in November.

CRESSON, Pa., May 6--One hundred and fifty stockholders of the Penn-Texas Corporation, a $126,000,000 industrial holding company, came to this little south-central Penn sylvania mining town today for one of the calmest proxy contests in recent corporate history.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The United States plans to station on Taiwan (Formosa) an atomicmissile unit capable of hitting targets several hundred miles within the Chinese mainland.
BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP)-- Montpelier's Nahodah, evenmoney favorite, won the $10,000 Baltimore Spring Handicap at Pimlico's opening today.

Landlords in a thirty-block area on the West Side were sprucing up their premises yesterday to be in line for a free paint job. The one who really scrubs up his place also will have a chance at free window boxes with flowers.
Educationally "lntegration" speaking, "integra a Life tion," a fighting Process word in certain Parts of our country today, means much more than the mixing of racial elements in a school.
An endowment fund of $750,000 was presented last night to Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 6--Strikes directed at the regime of Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla paralyzed, the commercial life of this capital tonight. The Army has been in control of the city since last night.
NAPLES, Italy, May 6-- Western Europe will find it impossible by 1960 to produce or acquire the amount of conven tional fuels it will need, Vittorio De Biasi, an Italian power engineer, said today.

UXBRIDGE, Mass., May 6-- Mr. and Mrs. George Payson Carver Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Payson Carver, to Henry Lansing McVickar Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McVickar of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.
Nassau and Rockland Counties will receive additional state funds between now and 1960 as the result of, a special census just completed.

GENEVA, May 6--The establishment of the International Atomic Energy Agency proposed by. President Eisenhower is an "urgent necessity," Paul Jolles, executive secretary of the agency's preparatory body, said today.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 6-- The nation's steelmaking capacity must be expanded by 50,000,000 tons within the next eighteen years, Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared here today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 6--All roads led to Tel Aviv today as more than 500,000 persons converged here to celebrate the ninth anniversary of Israel's independence.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 6 --The Public Health Service announced today a nation-wide study aimed at preventing tuberculosis in persons exposed to it at home.

LONDON, May 6--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will tell Chancellor Konrad Adenauer that Britain's new defense program is not negotiable. The program involves a reduction in ground and air, forces in Europe.

ALGER HISS these days is a man looking for a job. Friends think that with his administrative experience he might be an asset to any business. With his lawyer's background, he could write or do research. He has special training in foreign affairs and trade.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 6-- Two short operas were presented on one bill tonight in the Eastman School Festival of American Music in Kilbourne Hall.
BOSTON, May 6--Occasionally since 1773, Bostonians have protested against real or fancied abuses by those in power by staging another Tea Party in the harbor.
Shoe production this year is heading for a new high of 600,000,000 pairs, according to Irving Edison, executive vice president of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6--Sam Bender, Hillhouse High's basketball coach, was sitting in a barber shop in Durham, N.H., one day last summer. One of the town's citizens, who was having his hair cut, began talking about high school basketball teams in New England.
Cotton futures made wide gains yesterday. The spot month eased 2 points, or 10 cents a bale; deliveries rose 10 to 31 points, or 50 cents to $1.55 a bale.

LOUISVILLE, May 6 (AP)-- Willie Shoemaker today was suspended for fifteen days "for gross carelessness in misjudging the point of finish" in the eightythird running of the Kentucky Derby. Shoemaker's mount, Gallant Man, finished second in a photo finish with Calumet's Iron Liege.

YONKERS, May 6 (U.P.)-- Winged Guy, owned by Wayne Martin of Circleville, Ohio, and James G. Scileppi of Massapequa, L.I., led all the way in taking the Arden pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Jack Richardson drove the winner.
Merger discussions between the National Cash Register Company and the Underwood Corporation have been terminated "by mutual consent," Fred M. Farwell, president of Underwood, stated yesterday.
Alger Hiss, who was convicted in 1950 of committing perjury to conceal espionage for the Soviet Union, has taken another appeal--this time to public opinion.

ROME, May 6--Premier Antonio Segni and his twenty-twomonth-old Cabinet resigned tonight. The ensuing government crisis is expected to last long and be difficult to settle. It might lead to early general elections.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in the first three months of this year. The report was issued yesterday by E.J. Thomas, president, and P.W, Litchfield, chairman.

A former secretary of Tammany Hall testified yesterday that he had tried to reach Parole Commissioner James R. Stone about the Lanza case within twelve hours of the former extortionist's arrest as a parole violator.
LONDON, May 6--Britain proposed today a series of steps that ultimately would free the world of nuclear-weapons tests.

THE sixty-fifth annual exhibition of painting, sculp ture and prints of the National Association of Women Artists opens today at the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. It will be on view until May 28.

Two Air Force officers were honored last night for a rescue flight in which they shepherded three lost bombers up a snowswept fjord on Greenland.
