Once again the annual figures on foreign trade cargo handled through American ports are a warning to the New York-New Jersey port. The Port Authority announcement published this morning analyzing Federal data shows that total United States ocean-borne export-...
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 12 --Don Matthews snapped Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr.'s string of three straight International Class victories in today's Stanley Trophy regatta off Larchmont Yacht Club.
WARSAW, May 12--A special commission was reported today to have recommended the expulsion from the Communist party of Jakub Berman, for ten years one of the most powerful Polish Communist leaders.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 12-- President Eisenhower and Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery refought the Battle of Gettysburg today and agreed that the Union and Confederate commanders should have been "sacked."
Cotton prices in the domestic market last week rose slightly. For most of the five-day trading period the general tone of the market was firm.
BALTIMORE, May 12--A dis-- gruntled Baltimore fan, with what some might term a sense of humor, hanged Casey Stengel in effigy today at Memorial Stadium.

ROME, May 12--The Mille Miglia (Thousand Mile) automobile race took a toll of at least fourteen lives today. Among those killed was the Marquis Alfonso de Portago, Spanish sportsman, whose Ferrari racer crashed into a crowd of spectators at Guidizzolo, near Mantua.

The fourteen-story apartment building at 2589-95 Broadway, southwest corner of Ninetyeighth Street, has been sold by Emma W. Quigley to an investing client of Walter Scott Co. It is assessed at $1,575,000. They L.J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company was the broker.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 12-- Chris Leonard, a member of the New York Original Celtics professional basketball team, died of a heart attack here yesterday at his home at 18 Country Club Drive. His age was 67.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 12-- The transition from dictatorship to freedom and normality in Colombia is being accomplished with noteworthy speed and smoothness.
In the Hellenic Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity here yesterday afternoon Miss Anastasia Tsamisis was married to Philemon P. Moss. The Rev. P.N. Papageorge performed the ceremony.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 12--The trade balance of the Netherlands for 1956 on a cash basis showed a deficit of 965,000,000 guilders, against only 15,000,000 in 1955.
The Rev. Donald Harrington declared yesterday that this country was "in the throes of its worst internal crisis since the great depression of 1929-31,...
Mireya Arboleda, Colombian pianist who has given recitals in Boston, Philadelphia, and other cities of North and South America, made her New York debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.
CHICAGO, May 12--Grain markets were choppy last week with nervous price swings. There was long liquidation at times and local operators were on both sides of the markets.
Steady progress on all fronts in the fight against cancer was reported yesterday by the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

CHICAGO, May 12 (UP)-- The Cincinnati Redlegs ran their victory streak to twelve today by beating the Chicago Cubs, 7--5 and 7--1. Don Gross hurled four-hit ball in the second game and Don Hoak singled home the winning run in the eighth inning of the opener.

The moon, which most of the year suffers the indifference of all earthbound mortals save weather-conscious farmers, rhymeimpoverished song writers and feverish young lovers, will be a star performer tonight when it goes into...
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 12 (AP)--Jimmy Demaret made six birdies on the first ten holes today to shoot a five-under-par 67 and capture the $20,000 Hot Springs open golf championship.
"MR. BROADWAY," a musical play on the life of George M. Cohan, was another example of television's skill in the use of confusion and ineptitude to produce rounded blah.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 12--The American Horse Shows Association's 1956 horse of the year, Andante, made her 1957 debut today and quickly proved she will be hard to beat this year.

Governor Harriman may ask the Legislature at a special session next month to limit the sick pay that can be excluded from the state income tax. At present all sick pay under an approved disability plan is exempt.

The steel industry is preparing new price increases July 1. Higher prices for the most basic industrial metals are expected to coincide with the introduction of higher labor costs in the second year of the three-year nostrike contracts covering 65,000 union workers.

WASHINGTON, May 12-- Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, said today that the budget could be cut as much as $2,000,000,000 without interfering with "the quality of the services" by the Government.
Will increase leisure foster a nation of gracious livers or graceless loafers? The question was posed yesterday by the annual report of the Twentieth Century Fund.
The Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car-rental agency, yesterday announced record first-quarter sales and earnings.
JERSEY CITY, May 12-- Civic and political progress comes slowly in Jersey City. Nowhere in the country was there stronger support for the New Deal and the Fair Deal.

TOKYO, May 12 (Reuters)-- The Foreign Ministry announced today that Japan had turned down a Soviet proposal that the two countries issue a joint appeal to the United States and Britain for the immediate cessation of nuclear weapons tests.
The magazine industry means business in holding its position and making gains. Good-sized copy breaking today is an example. This is a joint effort worked out by the publishers of Look,...
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 12--The controversy over direction of the Tennessee Valley Authority will reach crisis stage this week.

TOKYO, Monday, May 13-- The United States will furnish atomic weapons to "any country that is attacked by Communist force and desires our help," a member of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy said today.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12--A routine religious freedom clause in a pending treaty with the United States has unexpectedly stirred up a lively constitutional argument here.

HAARLEM, the Netherlands, May 12--At a cost of "a little more than a million dollars," the chemical-pharmaceutical producer, Merck Co., Inc., has opened here the first factory it has built overseas since World War II.

LIME ROCK, Conn., May 12 --Ray Errickson of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and John Norwood of New York placed first and third overall today at the wheel of an Arnolt Bristol Special in a series of acceleration runs at Lime Rock Park, the East's newest sports car track.
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 12--Premier Mustafa ben Halim proclaimed today that Libya would give all the aid in her power to the Algerian nationalist rebels who are fighting French authority.
The special Suffolk County grand jury investigating official protection of gambling will be reconvened soon to question a high-ranking lieutenant of Frank Costello.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 12--The fifty-fifth annual show's of the Long Island Kennel Club, a benefit for the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, will take place here on Sunday on the horse show grounds of the Piping Rock Club.
TOKYO, May 12--The opposition Socialists have decided to take a page from the book of Japan's Premier and go traveling themselves this summer.
The formation of a new organization to promote cooperation between Communist and nonCommunist leftists in this country was announced yesterday.

ROME, May 12 (UP)--Nicola Pietrangeli, Italian Davis Cup player, produced the fourth big upset in the men's singles at Rome's tennis championships today by defeating Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris, 4--6, 9--7, 8--6, 6--4. Patty was seeded third and Pietrangeli sixth.
This is Armed Forces Week. A comprehensive program has been planned in this area and the committee for the celebration is to be congratulated upon its scope and its many excellent features.

Ngo Dinh Diem, President of South Vietnam, came to New York yesterday to pay a visit. The first thing the Roman Catholic leader of the predominantly Buddhist country did after his arrival from ... Washington was to attend high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Governor Harriman indicated yesterday that Arthur L. Reuter, acting State Commissioner of Investigation, had exercised independent judgment in demanding the resignation of Parole Commissioner James R. Stone.
High school students on a New York Times Youth Forum yesterday failed to reach a definitive answer to the question, "Can Labor Clean Its Own House?" But it was not for lack of trying.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 7-- The first-grade pupils, like 6year-olds anywhere, were restless toward the end of a long school day. Spring was in the air.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 --Sir Carol Reed has come from London to discuss a proposed renewal of association with the independent producing firm of Hecht-Hill-Lancaster, for which he directed "Trapeze."
The Fafnir Bearing Company of New Britain, Conn., announced yesterday that it had completed construction of what is believed to be the world's cleanest metal-working factory.

Cornelius Francis Kelley of Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset, L.I., former chairman of the board and president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after an operation. His age was 82.

WASHINGTON, May 12--The Atomic Energy Commission is confronted with the question of whether to offer Government subsidies and incentives to spur construction of American atomic power plants in foreign countries.
MOSCOW, May 12--Communists in the Soviet armed forces have been warned to enforce greater discipline in their own ranks and never to question the decisions of their military superiors.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 12 --Henry De Nyse Brinley of 435 Broadway, an attorney and civic leader, died today in the Monmouth Memorial Hospital.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 12 (UP)--Len C. Eshmont, assistant football coach at the University of Virginia and a former football star at Fordham University, died today at the University of Virginia Hospital. He was 39 years old.

CHICAGO, May 12--Psychoanalysis of adolescence, likened to "running next to an express train," was examined today by a panel of experts who agreed that they had much to contribute if they could catch the train.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., May 12--Arch (Hep) Hepworth is one coach who will admit he's had a successful season even though half his team's schedule remains. Hepworth has been coaching tennis at Williston Academy for twenty years.
RICHLAND, Wash., May 12-- "Partnerships" are building hydroelectric power projects on the Columbia River these days.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 12 --Brig. Gen. Rafael Navas Pardo, member of Colombia's five-man Junta, is a stable military leader.

In a startling but not exactly new maneuver Mr. Khrushchev, the dominant ruler of both the Kremlin and international communism, has in effect proposed a deal between Soviet Russia and the United States for the division of the world.

LONDON, May 12--Britain, with some reason, is not used to the idea of coherent American policy in the Middle East. However, development of Washington's interest in the area is recognized by London as a logical necessity. This does not mean everybody likes it. Nor do the British intend entirely to abandon efforts to influence our statecraft.

A visiting evangelist from Australia declared here yesterday that "America has given itself to the idolatry of anticommunism." The Rev. Alan Walker made the statement at the morning service at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP)-- Rocky Colavito drove in four runs, three with a first inning homer, to help Don Mossi, pitching in relief, post his first victory this season as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 7--4, in the second game of today's doubleheader.
The manager of Chumley's Restaurant, a Greenwich Village landmark, was robbed of more than $3,000 in his apartment yesterday afternoon.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 12-- King Saud's current visit to Iraq is considered a victory for Iraqi Premier Nuri as-Said, who wants a stronger bond among the Arab kingdoms of Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

For Catholics of all rites, the "Bible and tradition constitute the rule of faith," the Rev. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday. But he warned against the "error" of "individualistic" interpretation of Holy Scripture, and asserted that readers of the Bible needed the "unerring guidance of the Catholic Church."

BOSTON, May 12 (AP)--The Red Sox walloped the Senators, 10--0, today in the opener of a twin bill as Tom Brewer spun a two-hitter. However, Pedro Ramos of Washington halted Boston, 6--2, in the nightcap.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) --The police say that a tip from a Paris art collector put them on the trail of a map designer now in custody on charges of stealing valuable paintings and other art objects from museums here and abroad.
HUNDREDS of artists-- young and not so young-- participate in current group exhibitions in the downtown area.
The Dodgers finally caught up with the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They threw their weight around early to grab three runs in the first inning.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) --The Senate Preparedness subcommittee said today that rising defense and civilian needs had resulted in a "serious shortage of nickel" despite a tremendous increase in total supplies.
PARIS, May 12--Socialist party leaders expressed their confidence in Premier Guy Mollet and other Socialist members of the Government by more than 3--1 tonight.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 12 (AP)--The American Civil Liberties Union has asked the Illinois Supreme Court to rule whether Chicago officials infringed on the right of free speech by requiring a permit to show a movie not judged obscene.
A man seated at a desk in Buffalo may soon be guiding kilowatts to New York City.

A week ago today the advisory council of the Democratic National Committee released for publication three official statements, all under the curiously malappropriate designation, "Declaration of Policy."
President Eisenhower's leadership will be strengthened or weakened by the two television appearances he will make this week in defense of his budget, New York's two Senators said yesterday.
LONDON, May 12--The stock market followed an uneven course last week. On Monday, the number of sales reached a peak that had not been equaled in many months.

WHEN a 12-year-old has repeated headaches, he may be suffering from eyestrain or sinus trouble or any one of a number of personal ailments only a doctor can diagnose.
DETROIT, May 12 (AP)--Larry Doby smashed two tremendous home runs and Walt Dropo hit another to account for all the Chicago White Sox' runs in a 5-4 triumph today over the Detroit Tigers.
Sunshine and citizenship were absorbed in equal measure yesterday at the annual I Am an American Day ceremonies in Central Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (AP)--If San Francisco and Los Angeles can deliver commitments on new baseball park plans, the New York Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers are ready to ask National League owners for permission to move to California, Mayor George Christopher reported today.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 12--Merle J. (Jerry) Duryea, a leader in promoting interest in antique motor cars, died today in Springfield Hospital. His age was 61.
DALLAS, May 12 (AP)--A tornado struck central Texas today as thunderstorms dumped more water into flooding streams across wide areas of the state.

Subscribers to New York Blue Shield received 28 per cent more in benefits last year, while net enrollment rose more than 11 per cent. This was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis H. Bauer, chairman of the board, in his annual report for 1956.

The Philharmonic--Symphony ended its season at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon with a concert under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 12--Mitchell May 3d, an 18-year-old singer, won the national handicap trapshooting title today in a shoot-off with Dave Crosby of Concord, Mass.
In search of their own Walden Ponds, latter-day Henry David Thoreaus are tilling the soil in suburban and rural retreats thirty to fifty miles from Manhattan.

The Port of New York last year handled 36,245,503 long tons of export-import cargo worth $7,900,000,000, according to an analysis released yesterday by Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.
One of the port's most ambitious pier projects may be imperiled because of rising construction costs.

Polish Communists have a saying that Central Committee meetings must be postponed three times before they can take place. The reason, of course, is that disputes and problems must be ironed out in advance, and this usually takes longer than expected.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 (AP)--Erich von Stroheim, the actor best known as a monoclewearing, arrogant Prussian Army officer, died today in a hospital near Paris. He was 71 years old.
ANAHID AJEMIAN and George Avakian scored another success late yesterday afternoon in the second of their "Music for Moderns" concerts at Town Hall.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 12-- Although she is getting her feet wet as a professional, Mrs. Pat McCormick, the world's leading woman diver, still has a warm spot in her heart for America's amateur athletes.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11-- An ironical situation colors Laotian politics. Two halfbrothers who are on friendly terms and meet socially are the leaders of the contending forces that have riven the small Indochinese nation with armed clashes.
A State Senate committee has cautioned the Transit Authority against "unilateral" extension of its present contract with the Transport Workers Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12-- The "overwhelming majority of white union members in the South" disagree with labor's official advocacy of desegregation in the public schools, according to a survey made public here today.
WASHINGTON, May 12--The Council for the Advancement of Small Colleges began a threeyear, $3,000,000 campaign today to raise the pay of faculties of the sixty member schools.
WASHINGTON, May 12--The billions may have got out of hand, but the Secretary of the Treasury is watching the pennies.
ZURICH, May 12--Discussion among bankers and stockbrokers in Switzerland last week centered on the continued tightening of funds.

Assemblyman of the Glenelg Stable won the main race at Jamaica yesterday. With Teddy Atkinson doing the riding, the son of Menow led all the way to take the mile-and-a-sixteenth event by three-quarters of a length.
South Vietnam's President, Ngo Dinh Diem, received a warm and open-hearted reception from New Yorkers yesterday.

THE North African Canoeists Club is a patrician sort of organization headed by a sans-culotte. It is made up of Anglo- American warriors who secretly visited the French near Algiers in October, 1942, to make way for the Allied landings in North Africa.
Nine of the twenty-five defendants in court actions involving the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation and Doeskin Products, Inc., suddenly consented yesterday to a permanent injunction.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) --James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, said tonight that the question of permitting newsmen to travel to Communist China was under top-level review at the white House.

WASHINGTON, May 13-- Civil rights legislation met with advances and setbacks in Congress today, Despite new concentration by the Administration on the program it does not appear that it will be passed by Congress at this session.
DETROIT, May 13--George W. Applegate, a 26-year-old amnesia victim at Receiving Hospital here, met his mother for the first time in nearly a year today. He recognized her.
LONDON, May 13--Sir David Eccles, president of the Board of Trade, declared today that Britain should accept the challenge of the European free-trade area with confidence.

WASHINGTON, May 13-- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery admitted today that "the women of the South are after me" because of his comments that Gen. Robert E. Lee should have been "sacked" for his unsuccessful conduct of the Battle of Gettysburg.

LONDON, May 13--Price rises among oil issues in expectation of the resumption of normal traffic through the Suez Canal and the abolltion of gasoline rationing was the feature of the stock market today.
The Brooklyn pier fire blast last Dec.3 was formally ascribed yesterday to the explosion of 37,000 pounds of a detonating fuse called Primacord.
CHICAGO, May 13--A forecast of rain over most of the Corn Belt stimulated buying in that grain on the Board of Trade today, with prices edging upward moderately.

The merger of the Master Electric Company, Dayton, Ohio, and the Reliance Electric and Engineering Company, Cleveland, has been approved by the directors of both concerns, it was announced yesterday.
The story of Jesus de Galindez the Spanish Basque scholar who disappeared from the heart of Manhattan more than a year ago, will be examined in a radio documentary to pe narrated by Edward R. Murrow.
Armed Forces Week opened here yesterday with a blare of musical brass.
Import trade by ship and air, as reflected by duty collected, continued at a high level here in April, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) --Charlie Dressen agreed today to become a talent scout for the talent-starved Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, May 13--The Committee for Economic Development pinpointed today what it called perhaps the nation's most pressing domestic problem.

WASHINGTON, May 13-- Self-employed farmers are retiring about four times as fast as the Social Security Administration estimated when the 1954 Old Age and Survivors Insurance amendment covering this group became law.
CAIRO, May 13--(UP)-- The Government demanded today the death penalty for one Briton and life imprisonment for three others on charges that they had spied against Egypt.
CHICAGO, May 13--President Eisenhower's heart attack was cited today as an example of how medical science is neglecting the health of the country's aging population.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12-- Military intelligence sources reported here today the existence of a strong military build-up of pro--Communist Pathet Lao forces in northern Laos.
Three bond men find themselves in the middle of a $4,600,000,000 business as a result of Government moves to widen the credit resources available to farmers and home buyers.
A pattern of 6 per cent wage increases began spreading through the oil industry yesterday.
COLD cuts, rather than keep the cook cool, are more likely to leave the diner cold unless they are in themselves unusual and presented in appetizing ways.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May l3--The head of the Rabbinical Assembly of America assailed today "the shabby morality' of the United States.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 13--Israel plans to send a ship through the Suez Canal and will consider it an "act of war" if Egypt tries to stop the vessel, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

Jimmy Archer of the Bronx gained a split decision over Tony DiBiase of Astoria, Queens, in the main event of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The setback halted DiBiase's winning string at nineteen.

BALTIMORE, May 13--Gen. Duke, Calumet Farm's star 3year-old, missed the Kentucky Derby because of a sore foot. He also will miss the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. And more than likely be will miss the Belmont Stakes in New York in June.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 13--Conflicting trends characterized economic development in Latin America in 1956 and were dominated by a slackening rate of growth, the Economic Commission for Latin America reported today in its annual survey.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 --The Governnment of Mexico was identified today as financial backer for a motion picture to be made south of the border in which Jack Palance has signed
Tornadoes, thunderstorms and heavy rains continued to slash flood-sodden Texas yesterday and there were widespread storms in other parts of the nation. The Associated Press said.
Pacific Trailer Ships, Inc., is negotiating with American shipyards for the construction of two 600-foot twin-screw trailerships.

World sugar futures fell almost the -cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The volume was the second largest since the contract, for sugar destined to foreign countries, was introduced in January, 1937.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 13 (Reuters)--Andreas Ziartides, leader of the Pan Cypriote Labor Federation, said tonight his union was ready to accept a constitutional settlement of the Cyprus dispute provided it ...

HAMBURG, Germany, May 13 --Reports from Washington that President Eisenhower now favored the eventual demilitarization of a large part of Europe caused a considerable stir this morning at the seventh congress of the Christian Democratic Union.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 13-- King Saud of Saudi Arabia and Premier Nuri as-Said of Iraq have agreed to avoid open conflict with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt over Jordan.
One hundred and five housing authorities plan to borrow $167,219,000 in the short-term market on May 21 to help finance low-rent projects subsidized by the Public Housing Administration.

NEW DELHI, India, May 13-- President Rajendra Prasad told a joint session of Parliament today that the Indian Government did not intend to slow down its industrialization program despite "temporary difficulties."
WASHINGTON, May 13--Federal officials were prepared tonight to seek a Taft-Hartley emergency injunction to halt a strike at the Portsmouth, Ohio, atomic installation.

Representatives of five lay committees at Bellevue Hospital wrote to Mayor Wagner yesterday that they shared the concern of Dr.Dickinson Richards and others that the "high standards of patient care are seriously hampered by deteriorated physical facilities."
"New Girl in Town," the musical based on Eugene O'Neill's waterfront drama, "Anna Christie," will have its Broadway premiere at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
Jim Jennings, a boxing writer on The New York Mirror, died last night of a heart attack in his home, 2518 East Nineteenth Street, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. His age was 68.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-- The Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision today, ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission need not reopen a 1953 case in which two southern utility companies were ordered to divest themselves of nonelectric properties.
LOS ANGELES, May 13-- Three Air Force pilots flew 6,710 miles nonstop from London to Los Angeles today, the longest single-engine jet flight ever made.
PARIS, May 13--The International Press Institute, a useful agency designed to improve the flow among differing peoples of information that will help them to know and understand one another.
WARSAW, May 13--A Polish newspaperman has reported the belief of Mao Tse-tung that "contradictions between the masses and the [class] enemy no longer exist" in Communist China.
RICHLAND, Wash., May 13-- Scientists are optimistic over putting plutonium, a principal ingredient of atomic weapons, at work in the fuel business for peaceful production of power.
Manhattan College's baseball team clinched a tie for the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference title yesterday by defeating Hofstra, 8-3, at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
The Subversive Activities Control Board yesterday opened a hearing into a Government petition to have the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers declared a Communist-infiltrated union.

Opponents of a change in policy at Riverside Church Nursery-Kindergarten School are considering organizing a new school outside the church. They believe that a decision made April 8 by the board of deacons of the church--to include explicit religious teaching-- will destroy the twenty-sevenyear-old church school's emphasis on interfaith, interracial harmony.

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. in its first quarter ended April 30 were up 4.9 per cent over the similar period last year, Theodore V. Houser, board chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
The cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were mostly higher yesterday. The spot month was unchanged and the near July off 3 points. Other contracts rose as much as 16 points.
The state has ordered ten undertakers in this city to pay fines of $100 each or face sixmonth suspensions of their licenses, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.
The mystery of how Joseph (Socks) Lanza could have become heavily suntanned in New York in the dead of last winter challenged state legislators investigating his parole case yesterday.

TRENTON, May 13--Preparations were being completed tonight for Jersey City's most crucial local election since 1949. That city is among a score of Jersey municipalities that will elect their governing officials tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 13-- Architects were urged tonight to stop making "smaller and smaller houses for larger and larger Americans."

LONDON, May 13--Eight Conservative Members of Parliament rebelled tonight against the Government's acceptance of Egyptian terms for passage of British ships through the Suez Canal.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 13-- The aggregate radiation fall-out from the forthcoming Nevada atomic tests will be less than in the 1953 and 1955 series, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 13-- Four defendants pleaded guilty today in the state's investigation of official corruption in Suffolk County.

TOKYO, May 13--Japanese and United States leaders in the peaceful development of atomic energy began a week-long session today on the problems of releasing nature's most powerful force for the uses of homes and industries.
WASHINGTON, May 13-- Congress was urged today to establish a Point Four program for the nation's Indians.

The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City made its annual awards last night for reporting and writing. The presentations Were made by Herbert Bayard Swope at a dinner at the Lambs Club, 128 West Forty-fourth Street.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 13-- French diplomacy in North Africa has become a diplomacy of exits and nonappearances. The object is to avoid official awareness of the North African attitude toward the nationalist rebellion in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, May 13-- Ambassadors of eleven Arab countries plan to call on Secretary of State Dulles this week or next to charge that France is committing atrocities in Algeria and to urge United States intervention.

The Canadian dollar yesterday reached its highest premium over the United States dollar since mid-November, 1933. It was quoted here at $1.04 during the day, which compares with the 1933 peak of 1.05 5/8. Then it eased a bit to close at $1.04 23/32, up 1/32 for the day.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 15 (AP) --Today was G-day at the United States Naval Academy.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark May 15--Denmark's Social Democratic Government resigned today. It had been in power since September, 1953.

WASHINGTON, May 15--Output of factories and mines dipped slightly in April, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today. The biggest reduction was in minerals production, reflecting in part the cutback in oil as Europe's emergency demands faded away.

Lord Mayor Robert Briscoe of Dublin took a plane for home last night after a two-month visit to the United States embellished by many warm memories and more than a half-ton of gifts.

The final round of the fight for representation rights to the crews of American Coal Shipping, Inc., will start this afternoon in Norfolk.

Manhattan College's baseball team routed Columbia, 14 to 2, yesterday at Baker Field. The Jasper nine clubbed three pitchers for fourteen hits. It was Manhattan's sixteenth triumph, in seventeen games.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 --If there is one word that sums up the state of the motion-pictune business that word is "problems."

The State of Washington borrowed $30,703,625 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of highways and public buildings.

Russell Lee Dearmont, 66year-old railroad lawyer, became yesterday the twenty-first president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad. Mr. Dearmont succeeds Paul J. Neff, who has been named chairman, a new office.

Sid Caesar and the National Broadcasting Company announced jointly yesterday that the comedian had terminated his contract with the network. The contract, signed in 1954, would have run another seven years and guaranteed Mr. Caesar an income of about $100,000 annually.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham drew 13,000 persons last night in Madison Square Garden.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 --Jane Powell and George Nader were cash today in Universal's "The Female Animal."

The carpet industry must show better profits if it is to attract necessary outside capital according to Albert Pratt, a partner in Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis. Mr. Pratt expressed this conviction yesterday at the annual spring meeting of the Carpet Institute, Inc. in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 11-- Integration has been introduced in this Southern city on a limited scale. It can best be described as a "token" step toward desegregation.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Friday, May 17--A 7-year-old boy stumbled into a ten-inch-wide well near her a last night and was still trapped twenty-five feet underground--alive and crying--early this morning.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 16 --The United States and Britain pledged financial aid today to the Baghdad Pact alliance as its Economic Committee began its third meeting.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 14-- Iraq's Ministry of Education is halting the hiring of teachers from Cairo.

The challenge of England's Royal Yacht Squadron for an America's Cup match with Twelve-Meter yachts in 1958 was accepted at a meeting of the New York Yacht Club board of trustees yesterday.
Mayor Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati last night urged the nation's educators to place more stress on human relations, languages and economics in building more realistic citizens.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) --John (Bubba) Phillips smashed out five straight hits, including a homer and a triple, to lead the Chicago White Sox to an 8-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight behind Billy Pierce's eight-hit pitching.

LONDON, May 16--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan asserted today that Britain's first explosion in a series of hydrogen bomb tests had given her a "very much better bargaining position" in world disarmament talks.
The Waterfront Commission has taken the initial steps toward smashing a widespread payroll-padding racket in this port.

Relations between the United States and Canada got an international airing last night as high school students on both sides of the border talked to each other by radio on a New York Times Youth Forum.
WASHINGTON, May 16-- Charles E. Wilson today attributed the size of the Administration's budget to inflation and bookkeeping.
IT'S open season for fresh ducks at meat counters this week. Whether it is chosen for roasting or broiling, duck is a good selection for the family Sunday dinner this week-end.

BALTIMORE, May 16--Douglass Burnett, an early research worker in the development of electricity in New York and a friend of Thomas A. Edison, died of a heart attack today in his home in near-by Sparks. His age was 85.
A Stockholm plumber's assistant with a taste for Walt Whitman, Emily Dickinson and Carl Sandburg celebrated his twentyfourth birthday yesterday at the Empire State Building.

LAWRENCE, L.I., May 16-- Will N. Clurman, builder and real eatate owner, died today of cancer in his home at 123 Barrett Road. His age was 63. Mr. Clurman was chairman of the board of governors of Mid-Island Hospital in Bethopage.
CHICAGO, May 16--Sandy Koufax struck out thirteen men today as he hurled the Dodgers to a 3-2 victory over the Cubs at frigid Wrigley Field. Both the Bruins' runs were unearned.
ST. LOUIS, May 16--The Secretary of Labor called on certain unions tonight to "reform" their constitutions immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 16--The plight of the American city, pictured as the "monstrous" result of haphazard growth and redeemable only by assiduous planning of future development, was aired today at the centennial convention of the American Institute of Architects.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 16--The Security Council will meet Monday afternoon to discuss Suez Canal issues.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 18-- George Edward Crothers, an attorney and former Superior Court judge, died of a stroke today at Stanford University Hospital here. He was 86 years old.
YONKERS, May 16--Dottie's Pick, driven by Del Miller, equaled the best time of the Yonkers Raceway meeting--2:01 for the mile pace--in winning the $10,000 Webb Invitation tonight.
The representatives of waterfront employer groups from Maine to Virginia yesterday relaxed their formal neutrality in each other's dock labor problems.
WASHINGTON, May 16--A major reorganization of the State Department's high command was virtually completed today with the resignation of Robert R. Bowie as Assistant Secretary for Policy Planning.

The somewhat sheepish Yankee celebrants of Biily Martin's memorable twenty-ninth birthday were in the spotlight, for one reason or another, as the Bombers registered their second straight 3-0 shutout over the Athletics at the Stadium last night.
WASHINGTON, May 16-- Dave Beck has paid back an additional $100,000 to the Teamsters Union treasuries within the last two weeks, a Senate committee witness testified today.
KANSAS CITY, May 13-- Thomas Hart Benton is putting the finishing touches on his lat est major work, two murals for the New York State Power Authority.
The city's elementary school teachers were offered a "profes sional challenge" yesterday to volunteer for the so-called difficult schools.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 16--Anti-Government forces deposed top officials today in St. Marc, a key port forty-five miles northwest of this capital.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 16 (AP)--Paul Harney, a 27-year-old golfer from Worcester, Mass., toured the par-70 Old White Course in 63 strokes today to lead the first round of the Sam Snead Festival.
CINCINNATI, May 16--The Giants made a noble effort tonight to throw their weight around in the National League flag race.
BALTIMORE, May 16 (UP)-- Bold Ruler and Promised Land today were entered formally for Saturday's Preakness Stakes. Five other 3-year-olds are expected to join the entry list tomorrow.
PARIS, Friday, May 17--The Cabinet of Premier Guy Mollet was closer to a crisis this morning than at any time in its sixteen months in office.

LONDON, May 16--Active trading in oil shares was the feature of the stock market today. Prices advanced throughout the day following strong overnight demand from New York. Industrials moved irregularly and mostly in pennies; gains outnumered losses.

PARIS, May 19--Financial experts in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation are seeking a solution to the problem posed by the regular and growing West German surpluses with the European Payments Union.
ROME, May 19--Adone Zoli formed a new Italian Government today. The new Premier is a 69-year-old Christian Democrat with a left-of-center political philosophy and a record as an anti-Fascist.

BALTIMORE, May 19 (AP)-- Tito Francona's two home runs and five runs batted in paced the Baltimore Orioles to a 10-2 victory over Kansas City today. Rain halted the second game of the scheduled double-header after five and a half scoreless innings.
CHICAGO, May 19--Unfavorable weather conditions stimulated moderately active buying of wheat and coarse grains last week.
The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations plans action to guarantee the democratic rights of its 15,000,000, members.
Programs of regular classroom instruction by television will be started this fall by eight cities and two states under a project announced yesterday by the Fund for the Advancement of Education.
MADRID, May 19--Generalissimo Francisco Franco has taken a potentially important step in the administrative reform of the Spanish Government.
LOS ANGELES, biay 19--Penrhyn Stanlaws, portrait painter and creator of the "Stanlaws Girl" of nearly fifty years ago, burned to death today in his studio. He was 80 years old.
TULSA, Okla., May 19 (AP)-- The Arkansas River's worst flood in thirty-four years passed this northeastern Oklahoma city of 240,000 today, causing far less damage than had been expected.

MACY'S is light-headed about aluminum this spring. This morning its doors will open on a display of aluminum objects that rivals an exhibit at the Coliseum. Its partner in this spectacular, entitled "Live Light With Aluminum," is the Aluminum Company of America. The show, also playing in Macy's branch stores, continues through July.

A Russian emigre who fled the Bolshevik revolution thirty-eight years ago and became by brilliance of mind and strength of character "master of the impossible" was quietly honored at a private dinner last night.
Dick Gurney, the varsity baseball coach at Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., felt chipper last week following his team's 5-4 triumph over the capable Trinity-Pawling nine.
Millions of dollars in welfare funds have "filtered down the drain" through lack of technical knowledge by labor-management trustees honestly seeking to provide maximum protection at minimum cost.
LONG BEACH, L.I., May 19 --Ten years ago in a classroom at City College a group of students sat down and wrote letters to themselves. They tried to foretell what their personal future would hold.
THE curtain-wall or shell type of construction around skyscrapers has brought the metallic look to the skyline. It also has introduced a new sound to the city symphony.
AMSTERDAM, May 19--The birth of the eleven millionth inhabitant last week again draws attention to the Netherlands' population and economic problems. Total population in 1939 was 8,800,000.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane served notice yesterday that persons who dump refuse in vacant lots risk fines as high as $500.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 19 (UP)--E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of St. Louis posted a 62 today to capture the Sam Snead Golf Festival with a 266 total.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham drew his first overflow crowd last night at Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, May 19--The stock market continued to show strength last week and prices rose again.
Properties in the Chelsea section of Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported over the week-end.
SEOUL, Korea, May 19--For the last four months, the wholesale price index in South Korea has held firm. It has been at or near 127, with September, 1955, as the base of 100.
Thomas J. Curran declared yesterday that the reluctance of talented persons to seek public office complicated the selection of a Republican ticket in the city this year.
Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, ignored a telephoned bomb threat yesterday and delivered a forty-five minute talk at the Biltmore Hotel.
The Security Council of the United Nations meets today to resume consideration of a burning issue of transcendent importance to the whole world, and to the Western world in particular.
YONKERS, May 10--John J. Kelley, 125-pound school teacher from Groton, Conn., retained his national Amateur Athletic Union marathon championship today.
WASHINGTON, May 19--Organized labor now has special privileges and legal immunities that should be eliminated, it was asserted today by Roscoe Pound, former Dean of the Harvard University Law School.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., May 19--More than 1,000 Americans of German descent dedicated themselves here today to the proposition that frankfurters; bratwursts, knackwursts and sauerkraut are meant to be eaten, enjoyed and washed down with beer.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (UP)-- A thin piece of cloth torn from a bandage and used to anchor a mutilated tongue was given credit today for Bold Ruler's victory in the Preakness Stakes.
TOKYO, May 19--Premier Nobusuke Kishi leaves tomorrow on a six-nation journey to mend Japan's fences in Asia.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- Two liberal groups urged Congress today to stop cutting President Eisenhower's budget. One said the budget, far from being reduced, should rise to $80,000,000,000 over the next three years.
WASHINGTON, May 19-- Secretary of State Dulles will go up to Capitol Hill Wednesday to begin the first of the four committee go-rounds on the foreign and bill.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 19 --The marriage of Miss Susan Kadison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Kadison, to Dr. Justin L. Richman of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Richman of Providence, R.I., took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony in the home of the bride's parents.
FACED with a national choice of over 200 flavors, 50 per cent of America's ice cream eaters say, "I'll take vanilla."
OMAHA, May 19--Presbyterians studied today a strong new attack on sectarian education.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 19--It will probably be a long time before a Long Island Sound regatta is blessed with as fine a wind as that which pushed the boats today. However, rough water churned up by the spanking breeze discouraged most skippers.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System presented yester day a television account of a visit to the jungle hideout of Fidel Castro, the revolutionary leader who is seeking to oust President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- President Eisenhower is scheduled to send a $3,800,000,000 foreign aid request to Capitol Hill early this week and then gn on television to try to save the program from economy-hungry Congressmen.

MANORVILLE, L.I., May 19 --Benjamin Kent Hooper Jr. responded to antibiotics today and his temperature dropped to 100 degrees. His fever chart had risen to a peak of 102.8 at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, twenty hours after his removal from a twenty-one-foot well. His condition was described as "better."
Fidel Castro, Cuban rebel leader, has appealed to the United States to cease sending arms to President Fulgencio Batista "until the civil fighting that is going on has ended."

FOR twenty years now Conrad Richter has been writing fiction about the American frontier. No contemporary novelist knows more about life in the forests of Ohio at the end of the eighteenth century than Mr. Richter or has written about it as well as he did in "The Trees." None knows more about life in New Mexico seventy-five years ago

NEW ORLEANS, May 19--whooping crane has been hatched at Audubon Park Zoo. The red-brown chick, less than six inches tall, becomes the fourth whooping crane in captivity.
The Jewish Daily Forward paused at the age of sixty yesterday for a backward glance over the years as loyal readers of the Yiddish-language newspaper filled Carnegie Hall for a celebration.
Plans for a record school building program were announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the Board of Education's Committee on Buildings and Sites.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 19 (UP)--Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina roared to an easy victory in the Grand Prix of Monaco today after three of Great Britain's ace drivers were knocked out of the race in a triple crash.
ST. LOUIS, May 19--Breaking a 3-3 tie with seven runs in the ninth inning, the Dodgers today beat the Cardinals, 10-3, at Busch Stadium.
New York gave an orchid welcome yesterday to the merchant marine's latest passenger liner.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 19 (AP) --Five men trying to drift eastward across the Pacific on a raft radioed for help tonight, land the Chilean Navy ordered the frigate Baquedano to go to their aid.
WARSAW, May 19--Wladyslaw Gomulka has renewed his strength as leader of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party.

WASHINGTOPT, May 19--The troubles of the United States Information Agency are not over. The Administration's propaganda bureau has been cut down in the budget fight more than any other agency of the executive, but it now is facing the prospect of losing its independent status by being moved into the State Department.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19 --Vincent Fitzgerald and his guest, Dick Fales of Nassau, won the Walter J. Travis Memorial Golf Tournament today at the Garden City Golf Club.
BARCELONA, Spain, May 19 (AP)--Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., won the fifth Count of Godo tennis trophy by beating Mervyn Rose of Australia, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the singles final today.
SAYRE, Pa., May 19 (AP)-- Erwin Rudolph, former world's pocket billiards champion, died today in a hospital here after a brief illness. He was 63 years. old.
Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver Jr., who is working toward the establishment of a fifteen-city television network, announced yesterday that his first program-- "Ding Dong School"--would start July 1.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 19-- President Eisenhower observed today that "we shall be well advanced toward a just and lasting peace" when the world can feed and clothe all of its people.
MOSCOW, May 19--Many Soviet students are getting poor training in the fundamentals of communism.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 19 --Charles F. Dillon, president of Charles Dillon, Inc., importers and haberdashers at 444 Park Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street, New York, died of a heart ailment at his home, 7 Hill Park Avenue, here today. His age was 84.

This week President Eisenhower will carry to Capitol Hill and to the American public his fight for an adequate foreign aid program. He faces a Congress that is swinging the economy axe with enthusiasm, if not always with discretion.

It was a little more than thirteen months ago--in his budget mesage of April 17, 1956--that Harold Macmillan, then Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, introduced his controversial proposal for what he referred to as a "premium" bond, but which its critics denounced as a "lottery" bond.

CINCINNATI, May 19 (UP)-- Tom Acker gained credit for both victories in relief today as the Cincinnati Redlegs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8--7 and 5--4. The Redlegs now lead the National League by two games.

Tomorrow is Teacher Recognition Day, so proclaimed by Governor Harriman, by Mayor Wagner and other officials throughout the state. In a calendar officially crowded with special days and weeks the teacher came to his or her recognition rather late, 1955 in fact.
Immediate action to more than double the 244-man police force of the New York City Housing Authority has been recommended by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.
Letting the patient walk can be an aid in treating some cases of gangrene of the feet and legs, according to a report in the May issue of Circulation, scientific journal of the

"Showcase" will be presented tonight at the City Center. The intake from the special entertainment will provide a muchneeded fund for the civic house to draw on in carrying out its various activities at bargain prices for devotees of drama, opera, ballet and light opera.

WASHINGTON, May 19--The President's Council of Economic Advisers has raised its estimate of corporate profits in the fourth quarter of last year, and has made a preliminary calculation that profits in the first quarter of this year held about unchanged.
Salvation can be attained only by "vital membership in the Mystical Body of Christ," the Rev. William L. Doty declared yesterday.

Five years ago Puerto Ordaz and Ciudad Pier did not exist -they were just camps. Today, half a billion dollars later, the two miniature cities created on a savanna are in the center of what Venezuelans call their.

Few Western observers have been permitted into Rumania since the Hungarian and Polish revolutions of last fall, so special interest attaches to the reports of this newspaper's Belgrade correspondent, Elie Abel, who has recently completed a brief stay in that country.
BEAUMONT, Tex., May 19 (AP)--John Henry Phelan, oil man, philanthropist and prominent Roman Catholic layman. died today after an illness of several weeks. He was 79 years old.
This is a month when one is urged to think of the tall ships, the gallant liners and particularly those of American-flag registry plying their ways in far waters.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 19 --Dr. Jerry Dederick of Arcola and member Pete d'Esopo took the Westervelt Memorial tournament title at the Englewood Country Club today.

Moslem Friendship Sunday was celebrated yesterday in 300 Universalist Churches over the country. The program, sponsored by the Universalist Service Committee of Boston, was designed to increase cultural and religious understanding between the Christian and the Moslem worlds.

The Oetjen's Restaurant property at 2210 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, a landmark in the Flatbush section of the borough, has been leased to Johnnie Johnson, owner of a chain of steak houses in Manhattan. The lessee plans to alter and use the threestory building for a new restaurant.

Northerners and Southerners joined in praise of Lieut. Gen. Thomas Jonathan (Stonewall) Jackson yesterday at the unveiling of a bust of the Confederate officer. It will be placed in New York University's Hall of Fame.
A new battle over the Lanza parole case broke out yesterday between Republicans and Governor Harriman's Democratic Administration.
Off Broadway seems to be sparking more and more farflung enterprises these days. The impact of this successful theatrical movement here will soon be felt on the summer circuit in Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 19--The first earth satellite will not be launched this September, as hoped for at first. Probably the launching will be delayed at least until the spring of 1958, scientists have indicated to Congress.
ZURICH, May 19--Last week the Swiss National Bank raised the official discount rate from 1 to 2 per cent and the Lombard rate, covering loans on Stock Exchange securities, from 2 to 3 per cent.

MILWAUKEE, May 19--Under conditions that wouldn't have drawn a corporal's guard anywhere else this side of the Aretie Circle, the Braves insisted the Giants play their scheduled game at County Stadium today. Some two and a quarter hours later the Milwaukeeans were wishing they hadn't been so insistent.
The steamship charter market took another serious drop last week, falling back to index levels of eighteen months ago and wiping out the last traces of 1956 and early 1957 gains.
LONDON, May 19--Mrs. Mary Endicott Carnegie, Americanborn widow of Joseph Chamberain, British statesman, died at her home here Friday. She was 13 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) --Duke Maas, gaining his sixth straight decision, limited Washington to five hits today as the Detroit Tigers dealt Chuck Stobbs an eighth successive defeat, 6--1. It was the Senators' fifth loss in a row.
PARIS, May 19--Christian Pineau, who arrives in New York tomorrow to reopen the Suez discussion before U.N., is an indomitably logical man possessed of cold reason.

PITTSBURGH, May 19--Volume of steel orders has been showing some improvement lately, although the trend is not a major upward movement. Part of the better showing is in the depressed flat-rolled steel areas. As expected, some of the increase stems from advance buying to offset the probable price increase in July.
This is the fourth of several articles on the integration of Negro and white students and teachers in the public schools in accordance with the Supreme Court's decision.
The North Atlantic ship travel barometer has swung back to fair and continued good sailing after a squally winter and early spring.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 19 --Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet chief of state, ended today a fourteen-day state visit to Indonesia. He left for Burma on the way home to Moscow.
CINCINNATI, May 19--A warning was sounded here today against public education that trains the mind but fails to build character.
New, high-speed drilling techniques are capable of making dentistry more effective and less painful, dentists at a forum indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Following are the texts of statements by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Council regarding Dave Beck, head of the Teamsters Union, and his statement to the council:

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- Ed Fitz Gerald's pinch single with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning scored Pete Runnels and gave Washington a 2-1 victory over Detroit tonight. Pete Ramos held the Tigers to four hits as the Senators snapped a five-game losing streak.

BONN, Germany, May 20-- Britain's new armament program, the United Nations disarmament talks in London and their probable effect on West Germany will be discussed tomorrow by Gen. Lauris Norstad and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- Public welfare services need dramatizing, the National Conference on Social Welfare was told here tonight.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 20--Trout anglers here at the edge of the Berkshires had a ball for a few days and began to think of themselves as Cinderellas. It is a fact that a lovely little fairy story grew out of some good fishing.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) --Federal Judge Charles F. McLaughlin refused today to strike Government testimony from the record in Arthur Miller's trial for contempt of Congress. The testimony was designed to show Mr. Miller was a Communist in the mid-Nineteen Forties.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- Sponsors of the President's civil rights program won today the first voting test in the full Judiciary Committee of the Senate. The committee, by a 6-to-4 vote, defeated a Southern attempt to kill three-fourths of the White House plan.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 16-- United States aid slightly exceeding $23,000,000 in the current fiscal year will bring the total of assistance received by Libya in less than six years to the equivalent of $100 for every inhabitant.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- There are at least 100,000 persons alive in Thailand today who, on the basis of 1950 mortality rates, would have died of malaria but for the DDT-spraying campaign begun in 1951 with United States aid.
MONTE CARLO, May 20 (AP) --Ten leading automobile racing drivers on the European circuit today banded together, in an association to work for their safety during races.
An investment trust based on the tax-exempt bonds of local government has been set up with the blessing of the Treasury.
LONDON, May 20--Dr. John Bodkin Adams was accused today of fifteen violations of the forgery, larceny, cremation and dangerous drugs laws.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- President Eisenhower will carry the fight for his $3,880,000,000 foreign aid program to the country tomorrow night in the hope that he can influence a critical Congress to approve it.

CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP)-- Stockholders of Gruen Industries, Inc., approved today the sale of $1,800,000 worth of convertible debentures to GrahamNewman Associates of New York. The Gruen board of directors ...
MADRID, May 20--A general tightening up of rules applying to the Roman Catholic clergy of Spain has come into force in the last few days.
CAIRO, May 20--Saudi Arabia reassured Egypt today that she firmly intended to try to keep Israel from sending ships through the Gulf of Aqaba.

ST. LOUIS, May 20--Don Drysdale, with considerable hitting help from his mates, tonight pitched the Dodgers to their fourth straight triumph as they beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 10--4, at Busch Stadium.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- Four specialists disagreed today on the date of origin of the Dead Sea scrolls.
LONDON, May 20--Stock market prices moved irregularly today with losses outnumbering gains. Leading industrials were generally off a shilling (14 cents).

WASHINGTON, May 20--The Interstate Commerce Commission affirmed today its previous authorization permitting the New York Central Railroad to discontinue its ferry service between Weehawken, N.J., and New York.
OMAHA, May 20--A Presbyterian leader denounced parochial education today as "brainwashing" and "a denial of personality."

MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., May 20 (AP)--Twenty-two members of the graduating class of Moundsville High School have been barred from taking part in tonight's commencement because "religious convictions" kept them from baccalaureate services last night.
Although they were rained out of yesterday's scheduled game with the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium the Cleveland Indians were not altogether idle.
TOKYO, May 20--A young American soldier charged in the accidental death by shooting of a Japanese woman will be given a public trial in a smalltown Japanese court near where the shooting occurred.
Attendance at the Billy Graham Crusade in Madison Square Garden reached a total of 100,000 last night.

A bright spot in the city's gloom and dampness was provided yesterday by a gleaming white lifeboat with red sails. It has been moored opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral for a week to serve as a "receiving station" for books for sailors.

WASHINGTON May 20--The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report contended today that savings totaling $2,818,000,000 had resulted from the recommendations of the two Hoover Commissions. The commissions, both headed by former President Herbert Hoover, made numerous proposals to cut back Federal spending.

Japan Air Lines showed a sharp gain in earnings in the six months ended March 31, according to figures released yesterday by Hoshito Kojima, vice president in charge of the airline's American division.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP)--Ten natives of Europe who have been successful as naturalized Americans were honored today by the Immigrants Protective League.
Futures prices closed generally higher yesterday in dull trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, the domestic, sugar contract, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, lead ...
WASHINGTON, May 20--The United States National Committee for the International Geophysical Year said today a phantom satellite would follow the earth satellite on its trip through space.
ST. LOUIS, May 20--James T. Keller, retired treasurer of the Pultizer Publishing Company, publisher of the Post-Dispatch, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 86 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (U.P.) --The National Small Business men's Association called today for a constitutional amendment to limit the Government's power to levy taxes.
The Government's case against Johnny Dio, labor racketeer charged with conspiracy in the acid-blinding of Victor Riesel, all but collapsed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- Raymond Sawyer, a Civil Aeronautics Board official, denied again today that he had leaked information on a supposedly secret decision last August to give Northeast Airlines a New York-Miami route.

A $10,000 reward for the atrest and conviction of anyone implicated in the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez was offered last night by Norman Thomas on behalf of the International League for the Rights of Man. Dr. Galindez disappeared March 12, 1956.
WASHINGTON, May 20--The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower court's ruling that Tennessee had no right to limit admissions to state-operated colleges on the basis of color or race.
ROME, May 20--Pope Pius XII urged some of the world's leading astronomers today to read in the stars a message written by God.
Site-seeking industrial leaders with an estimated $38,000,000,000 in their "pockets" started on a five-day shopping tour in the New York Coliseum yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 24--The National Congress of Parents and Teachers was urged today to become an active pressure group for child and family welfare.
The National Urban League gave its annual American Teamwork Award last night to Mayor Wagner.
Talk of rate increases, the "mad bomber" case and complaints against management dominated yesterday's seventysecond annual meeting of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
LONDON, May 20--Reliable diplomatic sources here reported today that the Bulgarian Government expelled more than 10,000 persons from Sofia recently.

LISBON, Portugal, May 20--In this peninsula of Spain and Portugal, which comprises the Southwestern European flank of NATO, the traveler of inquiring mind will discover in these times a far friendlier attitude than in Britain and France toward the free world leadership that circumstances have thrust on the United States.
The biggest face-lifting job under way in this city is eradicating slum furrows from the Morningside Heights-Manhattanville area.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton ExChange advanced 16 to 23 points (80 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday in a moderate volume of business.
PARIS, May 20--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin proposed to Premier Guy Mollet today that the Soviet Union and France begin bilateral talks as a preliminary step toward big-power disarmament.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- President Eisenhower nominated today a new chief of the Strategic Air Command, a new commander of the United States Air Forces in Europe and an Under Secretary of the Air Force. The appointments were part of a series of major shifts.
A large patroness list has been announced for the Salute to Summer cocktail party-tea dance to take place in the grand ballroom of the Biltmore on Thursday.
CHICAGO, May 20--A generally strong undertone was noted in wheat, corn and oats futures early today, with the coarse grains holding the advances while wheat reacted from the top.
Business news over the weekend was not especially good, and the stock market checked its advance yesterday and paused to look around, The New York Times averages closed virtually; unchanged.
Charges of maltreatment of patients at Bellevue Hospital were denied yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs.

A court officer attached to the mail room in the Chief Magistrate's office charged yesterday that anyone who wrote or called for information on traffic tickets outstanding against him was "just wasting his time."

Emil Lence, who was named last week as promoter of a prospective heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, was checked yesterday in his efforts to sign Jackson.
A bill to outlaw discrimination in private housing was introduced in the City Council yesterday by representatives of the Democratic, Republican and Liberal parties.

Seven men were taken in for questioning yesterday in the shooting of Frank Costello, but all were later released. The police said they had contributed nothing toward a solution of the case.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- General imports in March reached a new high of $1,130,300,000 the Department of Commerce reported today.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 20--Haiti's ruling Executive Council appeared to be collapsing tonight.
WARSAW, May 20--Poland's Communist leaders have reaffirmed their choice of a road to socialism "corresponding to Polish conditions."

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped between April 15 and last Wednesday to the lowest figure since Feb. 15, 1957. The latest figure of 2,964,249 shares compared with 3,071,799 shares the middle of last month.

Arthur A. Boylan, principal of George Washington High School in Washington Heights from 1920 to 1950, died yesterday after a long illness in his home at 3656 Johnson Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 77.

Intensified efforts to preserve the competitive position of the Port of New York were urged yesterday by the Governors of New York and New Jersey.
WINNIPEG, Man., May 15-- Present indications are that the June 10 Federal election will bring little change in the distribution of Manitoba's fourteen seats in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The Textile Workers Union called on Senate investigators today to study what it called corrupt connivance by employers, local politicians and police to defeat union organizing.

ALBANY, May 20 (AP)--The State Conservation Department instituted today a "day-use service charge" of 50 cents to $2 at public camp sites operated by the department in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountain regions.

ALBANY, May 20--A lawyer for Joseph (Socks) Lanza asked the state's highest court today to keep the Legislature's watchdog committee from making public a tape recording of a conversation between the extortionist and an attorney.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The full nine-man bench of the Court of Appeals heard arguments today on constitutional and procedural questions connected with a key section of the immunity statute passed by Congress in 1954.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Tuesday, May 21--At least twenty-eight persons were killed last night in a tornado that struck suburbs south of this city.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 20-- Neighboring Laos will adopt a self-help program this week to bring the rudiments of civilization to remote areas.
WASHINGTON, May 20--The Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court ruling that the Attorney General had no authority to require an alien awaiting deportation to quit the Communist party.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20--France urged the Security Council today to arrange further negotiations for a permanent settlement between Egypt and the principal users of the Suez Canal.
The nation's truckers during the first quarter this year lost some traffic, but their loss was only about one-twenty-fifth as severe as that sustained by the railroad.

IT's a gift in itself--finding the right present. This day, there fore, finds Shop Talk busily engaged in sorting gift ideas for those who are marrying or graduating or are otherwise engaged in pursuits worth commemorating. Week-end hostesses get a tumble here, too.
BONN, May 20--Prof. Karl Friedrich Bonhoeffer, head of the Max Planck Institute for Physical Chemistry, died at Goettingen last week. He was 58 years old.
Trial of charges in connection with sales of stock in the SwanFinch Oil Corporation and Doeskin Products, Inc., has been set down for June 10 by Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 --A new attempt to film the tragic story of the snowbound Donner party will be undertaken by Jerry Wald. The Twentieth Century-Fox producer intends to develop the screen play from the book, "The History of the Donner Party."
An album of memorable scenes from the City Center's fourteenyear history of drama, ballet, opera and light opera productions was presented last night at New York's own theatre.
CHICAGO, May 20--Two United States Senators and spokesmen for thirty professional an business organizations attacked President Eisenhower's $71,800,000,000 budget today.
Today will be observed as Teacher Recognition Day by proclamation of Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner.

Three welfare groups will benefit from the proceeds of a twoday auction on Friday and Saturday at Nevis, the ancestral home of the family of Alexander Hamilton at Irving-on-Hudson, N.Y. Conducted by the Thursday Club it will be a repeat of the club's auction last year.
Archie McBride, who had not fought in five months, upset Willi Besmanoff of Germany in the main event of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 20-- The results of the Baghdad meeting between King Saud of Saudi Arabia and King Faisal of Iraq were hailed by the Government and press here as a reinforcement of Jordan's position within the Arab world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 --An attempt to heal the breach between the Los Angeles Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, and the parent union, will be made Wednesday in New York when a local membership committee meets with James C. Petrillo, A.F.M. president.

A new symbol, "UBX", has joined a famous old one--20 Mule Team. UBX is the stock ticker symbol assigned yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange to the shares of the United States Borax and Chemical Corporation.

THERE will be an exhibition baseball game at Ebbets Field on Thursday night between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers. Since every penny taken in at the gate will go to organizations sponsoring sandlot baseball, the worthiness of the cause should be too obvious to need elaboration. So this is an unashamed plea for support.
TRENTON, May 20--Gov. Robert B. Meyner still declined today, after a meeting with State Senator James F. Murray Jr., to recognize the latter as sole Democratic leader of Hudson County.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 20-- Ezra Taft Benson said today that the world's farmers would be better off if they relied more on their own cooperative action and less on governments to solve their problems.
The speed limit on the 178 miles of parkways and modern expressways within the city will be increased to forty miles an hour on Friday.
The Police Department reported yesterday that it has been unable to uncover evidence to support charges that policemen were shaking down exhibitors and truckers at the New York Coliseum.
Quality rather than quantity is part of the answer to defense economy, Ralph T. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company, suggested last week-end.

We join in extending congratulations to The Jewish Daily Forward on its sixtieth anniversary. These sixty years of The Forward's life have been years of achievement and contribution in many fields; cultural, political and economic.
The hazards and some popular misconceptions of danger in using radioactive material in industry were outlined yesterday by a safety engineer of the Atomic Energy Commission.
James D. Norris and his partner, Arthur M. Wirtz, yesterday sought to forestall a possible Federal decree to sell their stock in the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

Now London has a New York skyline--under glass. The new London office of the Hanover Bank of New York has a decorative window it calls the world's largest sheet of engraved glass. This portrays the city's skyscrapers viewed from south of the Battery, with such realistic
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission raised strong objections today to a bill designed to force disclosure of the true owners of stock voted in proxy contests.
Mrs. George Elder Watson Jr. of 112 East Seventy-fourth Street has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Starr Watson, to Ethelbert Holland Low of New York.
BALTIMORE, May 20--When Irv Biasi went to Patterson Park High as its football and basketball coach in 1944 he had big ideas. He promised himself he wouldn't remain a high school coach very long.

LINCOLN, R.I. May 20 (AP) --Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Paper Tiger, 6-year-old son of Stymie, came from last place in the field of eleven to win the $58,600 Lincoln Special by a length and three-quarters from Mrs. Irving Gushen's Star Rover at Lincoln Downs today.

HAVANA, May 20--News of the television and radio interview broadcast in the United States last night was accepted by the Cuban public as proof that Fidel Castro, rebel leader, is in the Sierra Maestra with an armed group despite Government statements to the contrary.
A metropolitan area comparable to "wrapping today's Los Angeles around New York City" was envisioned for 1975 by the Regional Plan Association yesterday.
BONN, Germany, May 20-- The state government of Lower Saxony has launched a campaign to wipe out the practice of witchcraft in the Lueneberg heath regime.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- House investigators heard another story about foreign trade troubles today--only this time the picture was reversed.

Bunny's Babe held the rail all the way to win the feature sprint at Jamaica yesterday. The track was sloppy, and Ted Atkinson realized that the inside spot was the best place to be in the six-furlong test.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 20 (AP)-- The Calumet Farm's Rosewood, a 4-to-5 shot, did well in the sloppy going today to score an easy victory at Garden State Park in the featured Wildwood Purse.
LONDON, May 20--Dr. Gilbert Murray, Regius Professor of Greek at Oxford University from 1908 until his retirement in 1936, died today at his home in Oxford. He was 91 years old.
CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP)-- The pinch hitting of big Bob Thurman is one reason the Cincinnati Redlegs are at the top of the National League today.

Maxwell Lehman, Deputy City Administrator, said yesterday that racial differences were not in themselves the cause of crime or disorder in public housing projects.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- President Eisenhower predicted today a rapid restoration of American National Red Cross funds, which have been dangerously depleted by disasters.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 20-- Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo, probably Colombia's most influential politician, spoke out again today for the military junta.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- Prospects for approval of the President's Atoms-for-Peace proposal brightened today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee completed its hearings on a treaty setting up an international atomic energy agency.
The haunting desire of men and of bears to see what lies over the hill led two tiny Canadian black bear cubs into wild adventure at Prospect Park yesterday. And it cost the life of their mother.
PARIS, May 20--Vladimir Dedijer, Yugoslav biographer of Marshal Tito, denied today that he had made harmful remarks about his country while on a recent visit to Sweden.

Representative John W. McCormack, House majority leader, said last night there was a "reasonable expectation" that a move by Democratic leaders of Congress to cut taxes would be opened between June 15 and June 20.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission charged a Chicago real estate concern today with offering false encouragement to wouldbe home sellers so as to collect larger fees for listing property.

THE weather has knocked most of the spots out of salt-water fishing hereabouts in the last few days, yet fish have been caught in spite of it and most of the signs look good to those who qualify as Veteran Observers.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 25--The two-century-old Tunisian monarchy appears destined to end soon with hardly a whimper.
Two city blocks that formerly housed Brooklyn trolley cars were sold yesterday to a meat cutters' union, which will build there cooperative apartments for 420 families.
A beautiful nude by Auguste Renoir that had been salvaged in the German invasion of The Netherlands in World War II was presented last night to the America-Israel Cultural Foundation.

The proposal for a second superliner for American-flag operation is not a dead issue, according to leading members of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. The members of Congress were in New York this week following an inspection cruise on the Matson liner Matsonia.

Community-wide efforts to eliminate slum pockets in the Morningside Heights and Manhattanville neighborhoods of upper Manhattan have reached "one plateau of achievement," Dr. John A. Krout said last night.

PARIS, May 21--A political crisis arose in France tonight following a major defeat for Premier Guy Mollet and his Cabinet in the National Assembly.

MOSCOW, May 21--The Soviet Union looked at its western window today and saw an Iron Curtain. The fabric appeared to be Western, the Government said, and it appointed a committee to haul it down.

PAOLI, Ind., May 21--Dr. Arthur Fisher Bentley, political scientist and philosopher, who collaborated with the late Dr. John Dewey on his last book, "Knowing and the Known," died here today in a hospital. His age was 86.

First National City Bank of New York confirmed yesterday reports that it planned to offer 2,000,000 additional shares to stockholders. These will be sold on the basis of one new share for each five held at $60 a share.
