SOUTHOLD, L.I., May 21-- Dr. Haven Emerson, one of America's pioneer public-health physicians and a former Health Commissioner of New York City, died today at a Greenport hospital after a long illness. At his death he was a member of the city's Board of Health. His age was 82.

CAGLIARI, Sardinia, May 21 --The Sardinians traditionally have been the forgotten men of Italy. Today they are astonished and gratified to find themselves at the center of an effort that Italy is making to raise the economic level of her depressed areas.
Indications that "the police are arresting more children on the basis of less evidence" were cited in a report to Mayor Wagner by a special city study group made public yesterday.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 21--More than half of the bicycle-riding pupils in Manhasset's public and parochial schools must leave their bikes at home tomorrow. Mechanical deficiencies and a failure to pass riding-skill and written tests caused 290 out of 549 youngsters to be denied licenses for their two-wheelers here today.

At Cumberland, Md., over the last week-end, on the occasion of the Sports Car Club of America national point races, a police detail counted some 15,000 sports cars. Two hundred and fifty of these were entered in the competition.

THE Fashion Group officiated yesterday at the not-so formal wedding of the clothing and home furnishings fields. At a luncheon given at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel, the tying of the knot was accomplished in room settings populated by smartly dressed mannequins.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., May 21 (AP)--Retired Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy, who presided over the Teapot Dome case during the Harding Administration, died in a hospital here today. He was 83 years old and had been ill since his retirement in 1955.
The Kaiserslautern Football Club of West Germany ended its United States tour last night by defeating the New York Hungarians, 4--1, at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens.
Five apartment houses at 306 to 314 West Forty-fourth Street have been sold by Harry Horwitz, realty operator, to an investing client of Benjamin Pollock, attorney.

CINCINNATI, May 21--The Dodgers backed Johnny Podres' excellent pitching with a twelvehit assault at Crosley Field tonight to beat the Redlegs, 6-1, and run the Brooklyn winning streak to five games.

CHICAGO, May 21--Interest in the grain trade centered in the final activities in the May futures, which expired today. However, for the greater part of the session the trade in these deliveries was slow and featureless.
Consolidated earnings of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation in the first quarter of this year rose to $2,171,680 from $460,739. in the corresponding period last year.
Dr. Warren B. Austin, Assistant Professor of English at City College, was suspended yesterday on a charge of falsely denying membership in the Communist party.

Kaiser Industries Corporation registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a proposed sale of 900,000 shares of outstanding stock to be sold for the account of certain shareholders.

CINCINNATI, May 21--The National Congress of Parents and Teachers is seeking to raise the standards of comics, movies, radio and television through an action program aimed at selfregulation rather than by censorship.

Boys High, a perennial power in local schoolboy track competition, yesterday clinched the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League team title for the sixth time in the borough's eleventh annual track and field championships. The Red and Black scored 67 points, 43 more than its closest rival, Brooklyn Tech.

The free world demand for oil should show a larger increase in the next ten years than in the last ten, according to Albert L. Nickerson, president of Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc. He so informed stockholders of the Company at their annual meeting held here yesterday.
JOSE GRECO brought his company of Spanish danc ers into the Playhouse last night for a three-week engagement.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives cleared President Eisenhower's civil-rights program today for floor action.

WASHINGTON, May 21-- President Eisenhower asserted tonight that a Congressional economy drive that would cripple his reduced $3,865,000,000 mutual assistance program would be a reckless gamble with peace and freedom.
The International Business Machines Corporation will begin today its first public financing in thirty-two years.

PARIS, May 21--The Western World lost a devoted public servant when Lord Ismay, NATO's first permanent Secretary General, retired last week to his farm in England. A large, rumpled man with the face of a benevolent old bulldog (from which derives his nickname), Ismay is known as "Pug" by affectionate admirers in fifteen Allied nations.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 21 (AP)-- Calumet Farm's Barbizon won the mile-and-one-sixteenth $10,000 News Purse at Garden State Park today in easy fashion. He moved to the front early and then beat off the only challenge he received in the five-horse field.

Despite a vigorous rally started by the oils at the beginning of the fifth hour, the New York Stock Exchange list showed a small loss yesterday. The market at the close was exceedingly spotty, with only the glass makers showing a general advance.
Nikita S. Khrushchev, leader of the Soviet Communist party, has agreed to be interviewed for the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Face the Nation" program.
THE American Savoyards got around to the "Yeo men of the Guard" last night at the Shakespearewrights Theatre on West Eighty-seventh Street. It is the fifth in the troupe's current repertory.
CHICAGO, May 21--It seems that Stu Miller, the trim little right-hander with the slow, slow stuff, is never going to catch up with his first victory as a Giant no matter how skillfully he pitches.

THE Caribbean is one of the favorite vacation spots of Ernest Koves, chef at the Woodmere Country Club who, in his free time, is an enthusiastic tourist. On his trips to the islands, the jovial culinarian collects recipes.
ROME, May 21--A "new Atlantism" is being advocated here as Premier Adone Zoli's Government is settling down to work.
The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday what it called a major break through in paint research--the development of a shiny, highgloss latex enamel that can be thinned with water.
ALTHOUGH Langston Hughes is a celebrated poet, don't look for the muses in "Simply Heavenly," which opened at 150 West Eightyfifth Street last evening. He has written a family entertainment.
PARIS, May 21--The Spirit of St. LOUIS II landed at Le Bourget Airport tonight 6 hours 38 minutes after it had left the United States.

TRENTON, May 21.--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, incensed over plans of the Republican-controlled Legislature to trim his $342,463,962 budget by more than $10,000,000, called on his Cabinet today to explain what the cuts would mean to the state.

San Antonio, Tex., announced yesterday plans to borrow $13,920,000 on an issue of water, revenue bonds. The sale will take place June 6. The bonds will come due serially on May 1 from 1966 to 1984.

The Zionist Organization of America denied yesterday that it had any political ties with the General Zionist party in Israel. The organization also assailed a newly established Zionist group, terming it a "Zionist splinter group with a non-Zionist Facade."

WASHINGTON, May 21-- John F. English, secretary-treasurer of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was elected today a vice president and member of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume improved in several markets and cocoa registered the sixth largest number of trades this year and potatoes the tenth.
EAST NORWALK, Conn., May 21--Mrs. Agnes Garvan Cavanagh, widow of John Cavanagh, a founder of the Hat Corporation of America, died today, at her home on Old Saugatuck Road. Her age was 82.
MUSIC NOTES

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 --Patrick Ford has become vice president in charge of production for C.V. Whitney Pictures, Inc. A reorganization of executive personnel was announced today by Mr. Whitney, owner of the independent film production company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21--President Tito of Yugoslavia predicted today that his dispute with the Soviet leadership would be resolved through patience and understanding.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 21-- King Hussein found the former Palestinian part of Jordan calm and welcoming today as he paid his first visit there since the recent political crisis.
WOODMERE, L.I., May 21-- Three professionals tied at 70 to share the lead in the first round of the Long Island open golf championship today.
The Billy Graham Crusade drew 17,500 persons to Madison Square Garden last night. This was the third largest attendance since the crusade opened last Wednesday.
THE most comprehensive exhibition ever put on of work by the most controversial artist of our time will open to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The State Department said today it preferred to study the identification of foreign ownership of American securities on an informal, case-by-case basis, rather than through formal treaties.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The House Appropriations Committee approved today a $2,586,775,000 cut in new funds sought by President Eisenhower to maintain and strengthen the country's military power.

As head of the Senate Finance Committee, which is planning an inquiry into the Administration's "tight money" policy, Senator Byrd has announced that the hearings will be directed against what he describes as a "threat of ruinous inflation."
Simon Brothers, builders and realty investors, who bought the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fifty-fifth Street about two years ago, have resold it.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, May 22--The death toll in the tornado that skirted Kansas City Monday night has risen to thirty-seven, the Red Cross announced early today.
Dentistry contributes little to radiation hazards, it was reported yesterday at the New York State Dental Society's annual meeting.

Billie Burke is planning to return to Broadway after an absence since 1944. Miss Burke has notified Frank J. Hale and Paul Crabtree that she is willing to interpret the role of the widow of a United States Senator in their joint presentation of "Bette Bibb."
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 21 --Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, former Colombian dictator, will be separated from the army and his title of Supreme Chief will be abolished.

Representative Paul A. Fino of the Bronx, one of the leading possibilities for the Republican mayoral nomination, declared himself out of the race yesterday.

QUEHANNA, Pa., May 21 (AP) --A new jet engine so powerful and quiet that its makers say it will enable airliners to use current runways at major airports safely and without noise nuisance was unveiled today by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.
LONDON, May 21--With trading volume small, the stock market finished with minor losses among the industrials today.
The July cotton futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 points (15 cents a bale) yesterday, but other months declined 5 to 16 points (25 to 80 cents a bale).

MADRID, May 21--For the first time since Napoleon's invasion of 1803, Frenchmen in uniform recently gave orders in Spain to Spaniards. But the Spaniards continued to ignore them, the citizens of Madrid blinking in astonishment.

TULSA, Okla., May 17--A teacher at the Daniel Webster High Cchool here took several members of her class, Negroes and whites, to a near-by lunchroom.

ALBANY, May 21--A state Supreme Court Justice ruled today that the New York City Board of Education could not discharge teachers for their refusal to inform on others in regard to Communist party membership.

John Dos Passos received the gold medal for fiction at the annual joint ceremonial of the American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday afternoon.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, May 22 (Reuters)--Arthur Mayger Hind, noted art historian, died here today. He was 76 years old.

Frank Shields maintains an active interest in golf and tennis, among other sports. As a 14year-old Shields won the national boys' tennis title, and automatically entered the national amateur championship.

WOODMERE, L.I., May 22-- Shelley Mayfield, the 32-yearold pro at Meadow Brook, played a smart and deadly accurate game of golf today to win the thirty-third Long Island open tournament.

The Marmion Realty Corporation has sold the five-story apartment house at 788 East 175th Street, the Bronx, to the Danor Properties, Inc. The building is on plot 45 by 140 feet and contains twenty-six apartments. It was sold through Edwards Co., brokers.

It looks as though the appliance slump has deepened. Yesterday the Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation announced it would lay off 2,200 production workers at the end of this month. Frigidaire is a top producer of refrigerators, among other items.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was heavy in many markets. Cottonseed oil, copper, lead, zinc, tin, wool, hides and burlap rose. Potatoes, cocoa and rubber declined, while price movements for sugar and coffee were mixed.

The New York Central Railroad's earnings plummeted 54.5 per cent to $2,315,591 for last month from $5,084,575 in April, 1956. For the first four months of this year, net income was $8,000,494 or $1.23 a share, 41.5 per cent below the $13,674,365, of $2.10 a share, in the like 1956 period.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Eisenhower said today he favored a supreme effort to reach a disarmament agreement with the Soviet Union.

MONTREAL--This city's gigantic annual curtainraiser for summer occurs this year on Monday, June 24. It is the St. Jean Baptiste Day parade, climax of French Canada's regard for its patron saint.

THE Army has given $89,000 worth of endorsement to an unorthodox helicopter that has been puttering along for several years on tenuous private financing. The distinguishing feature of the craft is its use of four--instead of the customary one or two-- overhead rotors.

IN the first forty-five years of its history the United States Children's Bureau had four chiefs. Three were welfare workers, one a pediatrician. All were women, outstanding in their sensitivity to children's needs and in their administrative ability. But no one of them, professional lintpickers have enjoyed pointing out, was a mother. In fact, all four were spinsters.

With one replacement in the eight that captured the Eastern heavyweight sprint title a week ago, the Ithacans scored by a length and a deck over the Quakers at two and one-third miles.
DALLAS, May 25 (UP)--New floods swept Fort Worth and Dallas tonight, leaving 4,000 persons homeless in Fort Worth.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa. May 25-- The engagement of Miss Joyce Bockel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Bockel, to Thomas Montgomery Osborn, son of Prof. and Mrs. James M. Osborn of New Haven, has been announced.
MODESTO, Calif., May 25-- Derek Ibbotson of England captured the mile run in the California Relays tonight. He defeated Merv Lincoln of Australia by about four yards in 4:06.4.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, in an open letter to teenagers urging them to stay in school, encouraged pupils today to believe they could be good students.

HIGHTSTOWN, May 25--St. Benedict's Prep of Newark, placing in twelve of thirteen events, won the eleventh annual New Jersey Headmasters and Coaches invitation state track meet today. The visitors scored 53 points, to 37 each for Lawrenceville and Bordentown Military Institute, the runners-up.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- Forty Texans crowded into a small committee room on the ground floor of the Capitol one day last week. Upstairs, the Senate was approving a $258,000,000 cut in the Commerce Department's budget.
BEANS will probably grow in many home vegetable gardens this summer. They are easy to plant and the varieties produce heavy yields.

RAVENBWOOD, W. Va., May 24--The $216,000,000 aluminum mill and smelter complex under construction down the road a piece might well have turned this little Ohio River village into a jerrybuilt boom town by now.

An electronic control system capable of performing 136,000 mathematical steps in less than a second was demonstrated for the first time last week. It will be used to assist anti-aircraft operations center officers in organizing a defense against approaching enemy aircraft.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 25--Penn State's Rod Perry suffered his first defeat of the season in the low hurdles today as Manhattan turned back the Lion track and field team, 84--47.

Investment bankers came up last week with a new idea to broaden the market for bonds of local government and thereby hold to a minimum the cost of building schools and other essential services.

According to the U.S. Weather Bureau, tornadoes have occurred in every hour of the day, every month of the year, and every state. But most often they occur in May and June, between 4 and 7 P.M., in what has been called "Tornado Alley"--Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri and Iowa.
Mayor Wagner plans to ask all of his current and future appointees to public office to file affidavits disclosing their financial status and business and professional connections.

More DDT to kill gypsy moth caterpillars was sprayed yesterday on 150,000 acres in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The operation may have perturbed some people, but the Department of Agriculture insisted it did not hurt the fish much.

The Port of New York's temporary approval for landing of the Caravelle, a French jet airliner, was seen here yesterday as an indication that the authority would lift its ban on other jet planes. The ban on jets had been placed because of the noise they would cause at city airports.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 26--The head of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted here tonight that the core of anti-Semitism no longer lay in its "vulgar, overt manifestations."

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 26 (AP)--The United States completed a 4--1 victory over Venezuela today in the North American Zone Davis Cup semifinal when Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Bernard Bartzen of Dallas won the final two singles matches.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 26--The Most Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, first Bishop of the new Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, took canonical possession of his new see today.

Ownership of American Overseas Finance Corporation, the first American institution to extend loans of two to five years to foreign buyers of United States goods, is about to pass from the five banks that organized it to non-banking owners.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Most of the increase in corporate profits in the closing quarter of last year went to manufacturing industries, particularly to producers of durable goods, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A point Congressional conference committee begins consideration today of the differences in the bills passed by the House and the Senate for operation of the United States Information Agency this next fiscal year.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 26 --Indonesia, potentially the richest country in Southeast Asia, is struggling through the most serious economic crisis in her short history as a nation.
MERCURY, Nev., May 26-- The delay in starting the atomic tests has now surpassed the tenday wait in the last test series of 1955. But it has not yet set a record.

A WOMAN may now try countless new coiffures without turning a hair on her head. Hair stylist James Caesar of 48 East Forty-ninth Street has patented a paper-doll device that allows his clients to create their own coiffures.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 26-- The garden of her parents' home here was the setting at noon today for the marriage of Miss Susan Rabinowitz to Edwin A. Malloy.

The Dodgers held most of the trumps yesterday. What is more, they played them close to the vest and that was all that was needed to sink the Giants in the series finale at Ebbets Field, 5--3, before 22,971.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) --Pittsburgh battered five Philadelphia pitchers for twenty hits and a 13-5 victory in the opener, but Don Cardwell, a rookie checked the Pirates in the second game as the Phils won, 6--3, for a split in a double-header today.
HARTFORD, May 26--Roman Catholics were asked today to "carefully observe" how their state representatives vote this week on a school-bus bill.
CINCINNATI, May 26 (U.P.)-- An eighth-inning home run by Hal Jeffcoat, their pitcher, enabled the Cincinnati Redlegs to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 7--6, today.
WARSAW, May 26--Polish and Soviet Communist leaders have ended a week-end of discussions, reliably reported here to have taken place in Moscow.
ON June 14, 1856, Dr. William Palmer, an inactive surgeon and notoriously active race-track crook, was hanged in his native town of Rugely, Staffordshire, before an enthusiastic crowd.

KANSAS CITY, May 27 (AP) Gus Zernial's homer and runs batted in by Hal Smith and Milt Graff behind the three-hit pitching of Ned Garver gave the Kansas City Athletics a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
Mickey Rooney has signed a long-term television contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System. Network sources had indicated several weeks ago that such a deal would be made.
LONDON, May 26--Most sections of the stock markets were carried down by the weakness in British Government securities last week.
State Senator MacNeil Mitchell plans to urge Governor Harriman to permit the Legislature to consider the question of a transit union election at the special session next month.
One of the most notorious villains of the railroads, the hotbox, with its long career of delaying trains, and occasionally wrecking them, may soon be just remembered for its stench.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 25--An emotional plea from a bewildered young widow was the principal factor in turning a curious crowd into the raging mob that attacked the United States Embassy here last Friday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 --The Big War," a new novel by Anton Myrer, has been bought by Jerry Wald for filming next year under the producer's contract with Twentieth Century-Fox.
VIENNA, May 26--Hungary is reported to be in the grip of an intensified terror campaign to root out "hidden enemies" of the regime.
RYE, N.Y., May 26--You would have to go a long way to find a better husband-wife sailing combination than Jim and Allegra Mertz of the American Yacht Club.

Neil Mochan, considered to be the hardest kicker in Scottish soccer, scored twice yesterday to give the Glasgow Celtics a 2-to-1 verdict over the Hapoel All-Star team from Israel at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Flowers and flags, symbols of remembrance from the living for the nation's war dead, abounded yesterday in pre-Memorial Day services here.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 26--Pierre Eustache Daniel Fignole, the new provisional President of Haiti, knows well the turbulence in which his country can become involved.

SEVERAL of the arts joined hands Saturday evening at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. A rather unusual program involving literature, the dance and music was given.
PARIS, May 26--(U.P.)--Neale Fraser of Australia upset seventh-seeded Budge Patty today, 9--7, 3--6, 5--7, 6--4, 6--1, to enter the quarter-finals of the French international tennis championships.
ADENAU, Germany, May 26 (AP)--Tony Brooks and Noel Cunningham-Reid of Great Britain drove a new model Aston Martin to victory today in the 1,000kilometer sports car race at the Nuerburgring.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 26--A new Government headed by Daniel Fignole as Provisional President took office today.
THE town of Mauch Chunk, Pa., will dis appear from the map on Memorial Day. There will be nothing cataclysmic about it, however.

LIDICE, Ill., May 26 (U.P.)--Charles Burian, a Czech refugee, came here today to pay homage at an "eternal flame" lighted in memory of the dead of Lidice, Czechoslovakia. Mr. Burian, a survivor of Nazi and Communist jails, found only a patch of dandelioninfested crab grass, a halfdozen scraggly trees and a patched monument.

CLEVELAND, May 26 (U.P.)-- Ray Narleski's shutout relief pitching enabled the Cleveland Indians to score a 4-3 victory today after Billy Pierce had pitched a four-hitter for a 1-0 ten-inning triumph by the Chicago White Sox.
There have been numerous instances in modern history when events have conspired to produce major tide-like movements in the flow of funds between this country and the rest of the world.
THORNWOOD, N.Y., May 26 --Five hundred families in this area have been doing some building lately. The item under construction is a $100,000 swimming pool, long enough for an Olympic race.

The current visit of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany to the United States has wide financial overtones here and in Europe. Industrialists abroad hope that the Adenauer visit will help clear the way for the restoration of important industrial assets seized by the United States during World War II as enemy property.
PARIS, May 26--The latest figures on French foreign trade emphasize the need of a policy to restore its balance.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 26 (U.P.)--Sir Michael Bruce, columnist, author and world traveler, died today at St. Paul's Hospital, where he had been under treatment following three heart attacks. He was 63 years old.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 26--Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom's Government will obtain parliamentary approval this week of the principle of racial segregation in South African universities.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay, New York rector, who was born in Canada, said today that this country and Canada together must preserve the democratic heritage of the continent.

David Merrick apparently was successful in outbidding a couple of formidable competitors, Leland Hayward and Herman Levin, for the privilege of escorting a musical version of "Gypsy, a Memoir" to the stage.

Hot, humid weather sent crowds of only moderate size to near-by beaches yesterday, the first Sunday since the beaches reopened for the season. Partly overcast skies and the prospect of thunderstorms kept the size of the crowds down.

THE Masterwork Chorus of Morristown, N.J., cele brated its second birthday Saturday night with a performance of Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew." It was assisted by the Boy Choir of the Morristown Vail School.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 26--A military solution to the thirty one-month guerrilla war in neighboring Algeria appears no closer today than it was a year ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26--At the current rate of increase of 120,000 a day or 43,000,000 a year, the world's population of 2,700,000,00 may double by the end of this century.
LONDON, May 26--The British Government is moving toward extensive relaxation of the present restrictions on exports to Communist China, qualified sources said today.

The Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., has suffered great losses in the passing--only six weeks apart--of Jack Maher and Jack Fowler. Maher was the school's head football coach for 31 years. Fowler, who went to Choate in 1944, served as Maher's line coach.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 26-- Educational Testing Service announced plans today to help found a center that will introduce American concepts of educational research, testing and selection into Asia.
Protestantism is emerging from divisional differences and entering a new era of unified vitality, according to the Rev. Dr. David W. Barry, director of the New York City Mission Society.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 26--Kathy Whiteside of Hartsdale and Stephanie Kob of Ossining were the major horsemanship winners at the Harrison junior saddle seat horse show today at the Kentucky Riding Stables.

KANSAS CITY, May 26 (AP) --Al Besselink of Grossinger, N.Y., triumphed by three strokes with 279 in the $22,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today. Besselink soared to a 75, three over par, in the final round.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The chief of the adult education section of the Office of Education said today that a lack of teaching materials for fundamental adult education was "embarrassing."
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Lewis L. Strauss said today that he had discussed with President Eisenhower the possibility of calling a world-wide conference of the humanities.
THOMPSON, Conn., May 26-- Thompson Raceway opened its new two-mile course today with six races under the direction of the New England Region of the Sports Car Club of America.

In an effort to stabilize rent increases granted to landlords for rewiring their apartment houses, the State Rent Commission announced yesterday a schedule of flat rates for such improvements. They are effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey suggested today that part of the proceeds from the sales of United States farm surpluses abroad should be earmarked for loans to United States businesses.

Alitalia International Airlines, in its annual report for 1956, reported an increase in gross revenues to $13,676,083 from $11,328,634 the year before . Net profit, however, declined to $78,504 from $203,942 in 1955.
PARIS, May 26--What is said to be the largest and most valuable private art collection ever sent from the United States to Europe will go on view here June 4.

Out of many weeks of tension and some days of destructive rioting in Haiti a 42-year-old teacher of mathematics emerged yesterday as provisional President.

Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that his country's fiveday war with Egypt had brought a dramatic improvement in Israel's fortunes.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Harold E. Stassen, President Eisenhower's disarmament specialist, put the emphasis on caution today as he departed for London with new United States disarmament proposals.

Twice yesterday the Washington Senators sprinted to 6-0 leads over the Yankees in the double-header at the Stadium. But, being in eighth place, the Nats are easily discouraged and in the end they settled for a split in the day's activities.

The Philippine Congress has now concluded its current session with the major part of the Magsaysay reform program still intact. President Garcia has thus passed his first political hurdle since the death of his predecessor.

Morris Karp, realty operator, bought the six-story apartment house at 2805 Grand Concourse, near Bedford Park Boulevard, in the Bronx.

RABAT, Morocco, May 26--If promises of foreign wheat aid materialize, there is expected to be no famine in Morocco this year. A situation that appeared desperate in early spring has now been eased considerably by rains and emergency planning.

WASHINGTON, May 27-- The Supreme Court agreed today to reveiw the conviction of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for contempt. The association was fined $100,000 last July for refusing to produce records ordered by an Alabama court.
LONDON, May 27--The four Western members of the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee began today to discuss the broad outline of new United States proposals for arms cuts and controls.

THE first winner at Belmont Park on that chilly May day in 1905 was a horse named Blandy and nothing could have been more appropriate. After all, Blandy was owned by August Belmont, the man who practically invented the cavalry post that was to bear his name.

Brooms, balloons and printed warnings were used yesterday morning on the upper East Side in an anti-parking campaign by 100 men, women and children. They represented the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean.

Settlement centers and nonsectarian agencies in the city are facing an acute financial crisis, it was reported yesterday. The difficulty is attributed to increased voluntary contributions to financially federated sectarian agencies.

His new fable also is a satire on dictatorship and a celebration of the spirit of freedom essential to the lively pursuit of happiness.

A flicker of hope is to be found in the fact that this must be a joint operation. Neither can leave separately. They depart together or it's no dice.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 28-- Joseph Bruce Perskie, former associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, died early today at his home here, 5 North Plaza Place. He was 71 years old.

Eighteen present or former Municipal Court justices have brought suit against the city. They contend that a 1955 law tailored especially for Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx fits them perfectly.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29--Cary Middlecoff, the United States open champion, established himself today as the man to beat in the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament starting tomorrow at the Wykagyl Country Club. The champion from Dallas tied the course record with a 34, 30--64, seven under par.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- Queen Elizabeth II has been informally invited to visit the United States, the White House said today. Whether she accepts is "entirely up to her Majesty," according to James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary.

NORTHPORT, L.I., May 29-- L. Paul Ahlers, executive assistant to the general manager and director of quality of the Engine Division of the Fairchild Airplane Corporation in Deer Park died today in Washington. His age was 50.

Visitors will be welcomed aboard the square-rigged Norwegian training ship Christian Radich between 2 P.M. and 5 P.M. every day until June 7, an official of the Norwegian-American Seamen's Welfare Fund announced yesterday.
The Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada criticized Conservative Jews yesterday for what the union called a "reported desire to change the Jewish marriage ritual."
WASHINGTON, May 29--A paradox of the Presidency is that he who fills the office associates endlessly with people and is the loneliest of men.

A champion show dog has been missing in the vicinity of New York International Air port, Idlewild, Queens, for almost a week. The dog, a Bedlington terrier, has been seen frequently in different parts of the vast airfield, but so far has eluded capture.
A section of a brick wall of a three-story condemned tenement on the lower East Side collapsed at 3:30 P.M. yesterday. No one was injured.

Members of society attended the opening program yesterday at Belmont Park. Many arrived long before post time of the first race to have luncheon and look over the $3,000,000 improvements that have been made at the historic track since last autumn's meeting.

Outside funds continue to spur industrial development in India. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has granted a loan equivalent to $9,800,000 for expansion of a power plant at Trombay near Bombay.

FORMBY, England, May 29 (AP)--Harold Ridgeley, a 43-yearold United States Air Force master sergeant from Haverford, Pa., won two matches today and was the only American to reach the quarter-finals in the British amateur golf championship.

For some time now it has been less than a secret that George M. Humphrey's stay in Washington as Secretary of the Treasury had substantially exceeded the duration he had originally planned for it and that he has remained in that key post largely in response to the continued persuasion of the man who was not only his boss but his close friend, President Eisenhower.
Governor Harriman's formal call of the Legislature to special session follows generally expected lines. The tone of his proclamation and press conference remarks is, in our opinion, unfortunate.
LONDON, May 29--A royal commission recommended today that laws dealing with the mentally ill be replaced by new legislation.

BETHPAGE, L.I., May 29--One thousand pupils and thirty-three teachers walked out of the Junior-Senior High School here at noon today in protest against the discharge of five probationary instructors. The school has 1,375 pupils and ninety teachers.
Miss Edith Irene Agranovitch and Herbert Baer Brill were married at noon yesterday in Temple Shaari Zedek in Brooklyn, where Mr. Brill is president of the congregation.
WASHINGTON, May 29--A Republican drive to shape the defense appropriation bill more to President Eisenhower's liking collapsed today in the House of Representatives.

ROME, May 29--Premier Adone Zoli told Parliament today that his Government would seek to revamp the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He indicated that a more autonomous and active foreign policy was among the main planks of his platform.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The Administration will continue to oppose a full return of German assets seized in this country during World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee said today that changes in agriculture laws proposed by the administration "would mean bankruptcy for farmers before Christmas."
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- An Administration proposal to increase interest rates on a variety of Government loans stirred some opposition in the Senate today.
ANTIGUA, Guatemala, May 29--Direct negotiations here between Honduras and Nicaragua on their border dispute failed tonight.
SATURDAY, 11:30 A.M.-- "How Winnie the Pooh Was Named" and "Cats for Sale" are stories that will be told to preschool youngsters at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 29 (Reuters)--The United States and the five Baghdad Pact powers announced tonight their intention to combat subversion in the pact area with "greater concentration and vigor."

A. Henry Mosle, lawyer and former president of Lenox Hill Hospital, died yesterday at his home in the Hotel Carlyle, 35 East Seventy-sixth Street, after a long illness. He was 90 years old last Dec. 28.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 29-- French military authorities said today that their violations of the Tunisian-Algerian border in the region of Ghardimaou had been provoked by gunfire from the Tunisian side.

A new phase in Cuba's tormented history appears to be opening. We have no means of knowing where it will lead or how serious it is, but the dynamism that has animated the Cuban scene for months is proof that the situation cannot remain as it is today.

The Belmont Park spring meeting began yesterday, with 20,257 in attendance. Those in charge of operations were not disappointed in the crowd, since it was expected that the opening-day crowd would be more or less a "pre-view" turnout.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 29--Israel charged today that Egypt was making no effort to prevent acts of violence along the borders of the Gaza Strip.
WASHINGTON, May 29--A group of scientists proposed today that an international limit be placed on nuclear test explosions to prevent radioactive contamination of the world.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- Another power controversy plaguing the Eisenhower Administration raised a fresh series of conflicts in the Senate today.

Between $30,000,000 and $35,000,000 will be expended by Schenley Industries, Inc., during the next five or six years to expand its world-wide production and marketing program. This was announced yesterday by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president of Schenley, at a press luncheon in the Empire State Building.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29-- Delegates to the American Baptist Convention were called on tonight to pass resolutions motivated by love on moral issues.
TOKYO, May 29 (UP)--Leftist Japanese students clashed with police outside the American Embassy here today in an angry demonstration demanding that the United States halt its Nevada nuclear tests.
Britain said yesterday that she would construct a new embassy building on Massachusetts Avenue in Washington.
Oarsmen from four nations will compete today in the eighteenth annual International Seamen's Lifeboat Race in the Narrows, off Shore Road, Brooklyn.
LONDON, May 29--King Charles II was hidden in oak branches here today for the 266th time. It was an annual ceremony of gratitude held by the Chelsea Pensioners, elderly veterans of Britain's wars.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- Following are the texts of George M. Humphrey's letter of resignation as Secretary of the Treasury, President Eisenhower's acceptance of the resignation and a statement by Robert B. Anderson on his nomination as Secretary of the Treasury:
ATLANTIC CITY, May 29-- A leading fuel oil marketer today predicted that the nation's inventories of fuel oil would increase considerably with a resultant reasonable decline in prices.
ALBANY, May 29--Individuals and groups interested in influencing the passage or defeat of legislation spent $196,213 during the 1957 session of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, May 29--Official Washington bade a friendly farewell to 81-year-old Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today.

BELLEVUE, Wash., May 29-- Miss Susan Patricia Curtis and Walter F. Robinson Jr. will be married late next month. Mrs. Morris Curtis has announced her daughter's engagement. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. Robinson of Boring, Ore., and the late Mrs. Robinson.

The dissolution of the boxing empire of James D. Norris and his partner, Arthur M. Wirtz, appeared closer yesterday after Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan expressed a tentative conclusion that the combination should be broken up.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 29--Parliament approved today the principle of strict racial segregation in South Africa's universities.
Soybean in the diet may cause goiter even in the presence of normally adequate amounts of iodine, the American Goiter Association was told yesterday.
PARIS, May 29 (AP)--Foreign Minister Christian Pineau said today that France was considering direct negotiations with Egypt to open a way for French ships to resume use of the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Eighty-three House Democratic supporters of the President's civil rights program indicated concern today that crippling amendments might be accepted that would rob the measure of its effectiveness.
TORONTO, May 29 (Canadian Press)--A six-year search for copper ore bodies rich enough to mine in Labrador has ended in failure for Frobisher, Ltd., a mining subsidiary of Ventures, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased about four-tenths of 1 per cent between mid-April and mid May. Higher prices for cattle, melons, apples and cotton were primarily responsible for the increase.
Two textile marketing experts came out in favor of lower cotton prices yesterday as the best way to compete with synthetic fibers and enlarge the market for cotton goods.
In designating today as a national holiday, President Eisenhower has urged again that it be made a day of prayer for peace. This is an emphasis to which all Americans will gladly give assent.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --A Hungarian refugee discovered to have been a member of the Hungarian military intelligence was deported with his wife and two children last Thursday, the Immigration Service said today.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 29--Daniel Fignole, head of Haiti's provisional Government, disclosed today that he would be a candidate in the coming Presidential election. He said he would soon announce the date of the voting.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The United States is considering reducing its overseas forces and the size of its foreign bases, Secretary of State Dulles disclosed today.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 29 (AP)--Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., shot 34, 37--71 today and took a 3-point lead in the opening round of the Virginia Beach round-robin golf tournament.
HAVANA, May 29--Calixto Sanchez, leader of an insurgent group that landed on the north coast of eastern Cuba, has been killed, the Army said today.

A Queens watchmaker is scheduled to be freed tomorrow from the Federal House of Detention as a result of a United States Supreme Court decision that may have a far-reaching effect upon income tax fraud cases.

Weather ships manning the International Civil Aviation Organization's North Atlantic station network rescued forty-seven persons from the sea last year in addition to performing a variety of other vital duties.

The marriage of Miss Anne Mallon, daughter of Mrs. Mary Mallon Foster of New York and Rio de Janeiro and the late Francis Mallon of Philadelphia, to William Bayard Carlin of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday afternoon.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery yesterday stood by his professional views of Confederate and Union strategy at the Battle of Gettysburg.

To Joe Bedenk, who could easily qualify as Casey Stengel's double if Hollywood ever got around to filming the Yankee skipper's exploits, baseball is a game to be played with about as much abandon as chess.

An unconventional type of producing organization, comparable to the Playwrights Company, where the members share in the profits of the group, has been formed by Lester Osterman and Lillian Hellman. Starting June 15, their headquarters will be at 55 West Fifty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, May 29--A weak tone was shown early in the grain market today but on the setbacks investment buying was indicated in wheat and corn. Shorts were uneasy and inclined to even up for over the holiday tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --President Eisenhower today nominated Loftus E. Becker, New York lawyer, to be legal adviser to the State Department.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- The forty-first 500-mile automobile race on the brick and asphalt Indianapolis Speedway tomorrow should be one of the fastest and one of the most thrilling since Ray Harronn scored the first victory here in 1911.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 29-- Chinese Nationalist legislators said today that they hoped last week's anti-American violence would "accelerate" agreement on the legal status of United States forces in Taiwan.
PITTSBURGH, May 29 (UP)-- The Gulf Oil Corporation today dedicated three laboratories, one of them housing a 3,000,000-volt radiation source for use in nuclear research in petroleum.
LONDON, May 29--Defense Minister Duncan Sandys revealed today that West German pressure had not altered Britain's plans for a sizable reduction of her ground forces in Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 29--Joseph M. Swing, the Commissioner of Immigration, and three of his officials have "corrected" expense vouchers they originally filed for trips involving hunting in Mexico.
BOSTON, May 29--A funeral service was held today in Marsh Chapel of Boston University for Alfred H. Avery, a self-effacing philanthropist who died Sunday. His home was in suburban Hingham.

The Union Pacific Railroad felt the impact of lower freight carloadings and increased railway operating costs last month. Through the first quarter this year the company had been one of the few major systems to hold earnings above the level of a year ago.
PARIS, May 29--Pierre Pflimlin, leader of the Roman Catholic Popular Republican Movement, agreed tonight to seek the Premiership.
MOUNT VERNON, Me., May 29--Fishing by plane poses certain problems to add to the customary concerns of weather, tackle, lures and the whereabouts of fish.

Stockholders of American Hard Rubber Company, Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation and Wardell Corporation yesterday approved, at special meetings, the merger of the three companies into a new concern to be called Amerace Corporation.

New York City will make its big pitch to keep the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants here in a meeting next Tuesday with officials of the two baseball clubs.

WASHINGTON, May 29--One Eddie Barnett who had been wondering whether he would get home before Christmas, made it before Memorial Day. Two youths plunged into the East River early yesterday from the Queensboro Bridge. One swam to shore with no more than a sprained ankle and some bruises. His friend was still missing last night and apparently drowned.

ALBANY, May 29--Republican legislative leaders said today that they would pass the same social insurance bills at the special session of the Legislature next month that they did at the regular session two months ago.
Mississippi yesterday gave up for the time being a school financing program.

Two four and five story tenement houses at 484-86 Tenth Avenue have been purchased by James B. Moore. The buyer recently bought 490 and 496 Tenth Avenue and now controls the blockfront on the east side of the avenue from Thirty-seventh to Thirty-eighth Streets.

The Southern Natural Gas Company expects to become an integrated oil and gas company "before it becomes much older," C.T. Chenery, chairman, told yesterday's meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The Government's authority to "pick and choose" among religious groups to determine which are entitled to tax exemption was challenged today by the American Jewish Committee.
Detectives here arrested 135 persons in a city-wide round-up of narcotics peddlers that ended at noon yesterday. Among those seized were a band leader, a subway motorman and a 15year-old boy.

TODAY is the traditional date for scouting for the summer house-to-rent. While some prospective vacationers have to flip a coin to decide on the shore or mountains, others may have resolved the problem by settling on both locales and investing in a trailer.
Two whales and a seal have combined to upset the usual calm prevailing in Suffolk County.

MILWAUKEE, May 29 (AP)-- Bob Buhl, hurling his first complete game in seven starts this season, yielded only four hits and registered eight strikeouts today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6--2.

A shopping center containing eleven stores at Hempstead Turnpike and Merritt Road, Farmingdale, L.I., has been purchased by Louis Jacobs, realty operator, in conjunction with Joseph L. Steinfeld Associates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 --"The Price Is Right," weekday television show that awards prizes to contestants who guess their sales value, will be seen in another version on the National Broadcasting. Company's evening schedule next fall.
Nat Hiken, producer and chief writer of the Phil Silvers television show for two years, disclosed yesterday that he had taken a "leave of absence" to enjoy a "prolonged rest."

A decline of 2,010,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 194,373,000 barrels, compared with 196,383,000 a week earlier and 183,510,000 a year ago.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 29--Marymount College held its thirty-fourth commencement here today. Cardinal Spellman conferred degrees on 140 young women.

Jerry Buchetto of Stamford, Conn., is among thousands of golfers who play on public courses. And, as with many of them, he wishes he had more spare time to play. Last year he became the Metropolitan Golf Association's public links champion. Under the circumstances, that was quite an accomplishment.
WASHINGTON, May 29--The Senate approved tonight a bill authorizing the use of $1,600,000,000 in Government money for a variety of Federal housing programs.
The City Planning Commission has approved the $110,000,000 George Washington Bridge improvements proposed in Manhattan by the Port of New York Authority.
In a continuation of the rally that began late Tuesday, stocks yesterday scored the best gain since April 8. Oils led the advance but steels, chemicals, metals and aircrafts were mostly higher.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the chances of getting a first-step disarmament agreement would be imperiled if the Soviet Union insisted on arms cuts and aerial inspection in central Europe.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP)-- Willie Hartack booted Brookfield Farm's Itobe to a fourlength victory over Nahodah in the $12,200 Wilmington Handicap at Delaware Park today.

LONDON, May 29--Prices of high-class industrial stocks advanced today on a small expansipn in volume. Gains generally were in pennies.

WASHINGTON, May 29--An expert on welfare and pension plans told a Senate committee today that he suspected there was as much waste and corruption in employer-administered funds as in union-run funds.

SOMEDAY jet airliners may reach the other side of the ocean before the press has gone from a passenger's skirt. Meanwhile, the advice to women travelers who want to achieve that band-box look at the end of the line is to plan for at well in advance.

Carl Hans vom Baur, an electrical engineer with wide experience in this country and abroad, died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home at 2 Horatio Street. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 30--In a unanimous ruling that received little national attention, the Supreme Court spoke out emphatically this week against the popular tendency of assuming that a man must be guilty of some wrong-doing if he invokes the Fifth Amendment.

Miss Barbara Carol Florio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Florio of Hamden, Conn., and Indian Neck, Branford, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Alden Denison Hatch, son of Alden R. Hatch of Somerleas, Cedarhurst, L. I., and Mrs. Richard Derby Elwell of Lawrence, L. I.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30-- A 42-year-old prospector who had been insisting since 1936 that there was gold to be found on automobile race tracks, panned close to $100,000 worth of it at the Indianapolis Speedway today. Then he announced his retirement.
WASHINGTON, May 30--The State Department announced today that it had ordered a Hungarian assistant military attache to leave the United States not later than next Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 30-- After they had beaten the Yankees, 5--1, and were flying high on a four-game winning streak --remarkable for an eighthplace outfit--the Senators reverted to form in the afterpiece of a double-header at Griffith Stadium today.
An exiled former President of Venezuela said yesterday that the recent overthrow of the dictator of neighboring Colombia should undoubtedly affect the situation in his country.

PARIS, May 30 (UP)--Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Forest Hills, N. Y., won stiff matches today to gain the men's and women's singles finals, respectively, in the French international tennis championships.
CHICAGO, May 30 (UP)--Dick Donovan and Billy Pierce pitched and batted the Chicago White Sox to two victories over the Cleveland Indians today, 6--4 and 2--1.
WASHINGTON, May 30--The United States is "most disappointed" by Britain's decision to drop the special restrictions on trade with Communist China, the State Department said today.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 30-- The Institute for Advanced Study announced today the appointment of four new faculty members. Three will serve in the School of Mathematics and the fourth in the School of Historical Studies.
GREENVILLE, Me., May 30 --The fat lake trout, or togue as they are called here, are feeding near the top now and anglers are beating the lakes and ponds for them pretty briskly.

GENEVA, May 30.--A long forward step is being taken here toward making real the principle of an international civil service free of national rivalries and political pressures.

CAIRO, May 30--Saudi Arabia was reported today to have proposed formation of an all-Arab company to build a vast network of pipelines. These would run from the oil fields of the Middle East to Arab ports on the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf.
KURE, Japan, May 29--A tanker launched here today brought the total tonnage of seagoing ships built under American management in the former imperial shipyard of Kure past the million mark.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Final Congressional action on the President's estimate of appropriations that will be bedrock essentials for national defense and mutual security (foreign aid) in fiscal '58 will determine the validity of a theory that acquired wide acceptance in the last few years.
Physicians were urged here yesterday to support vigorously efforts that are being made to change Federal laws on the addition of chemicals to foods.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., May 30--Irving Reynolds, a partner in the New York law firm of Meyer, Kissel, Matz, Reynolds Seward, died here today in his home, 220 Douglas Place, after a long illness. His age was 59.

Mills producing corduroys have withdrawn these goods From the market to await more favorable prices. Converters seeking to purchase corduroys in the gray (natural color) for dyeing and finishing reported that just prior to Memorial Day they had been unable to get any price quotations.

Frustration enveloped the Giants in the first game with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Ruben Gomez, pitching one of his better games of the season, allowed only three hits but the Phils won it in ten innings, 2--1.

Business during the balance of 1957 will be better than it has been thus far, it was predicted by a majority of purchasing agents polled on the subject by their national association.

MILWAUKEE, May 30 (AP)-- Turk Lown, a relief pitcher, struck out Felix Mantilla with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today to give the Chicago Cubs a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves and an even break in a double-header. The Braves won the opener, 5--2, as Ray Crone went the distance for the first time since June 26, 1956.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., May 30 (AP)--Col. Paul R. Wing, U. S. A., retired, of Mathews, who fought in the Battle of Bataan in World War II, died yesterday of a heart attack in the naval hospital here. He was 65 years old.

PARIS, May 31--It is the job of Paul-Henri Spaak, NATO's new Secretary General, to see if he can revitalize the alliance. The task requires a mixture of inspiration, obstinacy and harpoon therapy. Spaak seems admirably suited for the role, which sometimes resembles that of Sisyphus.

New York State's "freeze" on bank holding company operations in no way affects the Federal Reserve Board's right to approve creation of a new holding company by the First National City Bank of New York, the bank said yesterday.

VALDELACALZADA, Spain, May 23--Maids are becoming difficult to find in Valdelacalzada. In Washington, London or Paris, this would not be news. But in this once arid, bitterly depressed wasteland of western Spain it is.

WASHINGTON, May 31--A Hoosier inventor wants to let the track officials watch a horse race without craning their necks. He received a patent this week for a revolving judges' stand that always faces the horses. Trueman T. Rembusch of Franklin, Ind., received the patent.
CLEVELAND, May 31--Great Lakes coal shipments are slightly ahead of those in the corresponding period last year even though most vessel operators are giving top priority to the ore trade.

LONDON, May 31--The rise in oil share prices was the feature of the stock market today. Gains were extended in after hours dealing on American buying. Canadian oil issues were strong in the dollar stocks section.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Nikita S. Khrushchev's suggestion that the United States and the Soviet Union withdraw their troops from the areas they occupy in Europe as "a useful first step" in easing tensions bodes ill for the disarmament talks that reopen in London tomorrow, United States officials said today.
Spring is the time for anniversaries, May, and in particular, June. They do not allow anyone to forget this for even a brief moment.

Charles Coon and William Pearson Grieve of Cambridge, Mass., won the Greater New York contract bridge Master Pairs championship yesterday at the Statler Hotel. Gordon Nugent of Ardsley, N.Y., and John Yuan of New York won the NonMasters Pairs event.

Major crime in New York City increased only 2.2 per cent last year, in contrast to the national rise of 13.3 per cent. A seven-year upward trend in traffic accidents involving death or serious injury was reversed.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 2 --A fleet of eighty-seven sloops ran into all kinds of weather today as the Beach Point Yacht Club held the seventh Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship regatta.
A pet female sea lion that ran away from home May 5 in pursuit of a school of fish ended her adventure last night in her owner's automobile.

It was the first inning of the second game at the Stadium yesterday. The Yankees had not been looking or doing well at all. They had dropped the opener, 3--2, to Bill Wight and the Baltimore Orioles and their losing string had stretched to three.

The chaplain of Columbia University told a group of bachelor's degree candidates yesterday that they should try to center their lives on "some great conviction" and their deeds on a great eternal reality."
Five panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum gave an affirmative answer yesterday to the question "Can Children Discuss Word Issues?"

NEW DELHI, India, June 2-- The establishment of cooperative farms in India on an experimental basis has been recommended by an official delegation that made a comprehensive study of the cooperative movement in Communist China.

At the end of Paul Muni's final performance--his 668th--in "Inherit the Wind" on Saturday night the star received an ovation from the audience and cast. It was the longest engagement of the star's career.

The Bank of New York, the oldest in the city, will open its new Fifth Avenue office, between Forty-fourth and Fortyfifth Streets, today. The bank is on the site of the old Fifth Avenue Bank, which was merged with the Bank of New York in 1948.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 2-- Peg's Pride, the pride of Ted Gussenhoven's Hutchinson Stables in Closter, N.J., posted his 113th open jumper championship today. WASHINGTON, June 2--The special House subcommittee set up six weeks ago to investigate the major regulatory agencies still is looking for a chief counsel to direct its inquiry.

Stefan Redl, a Hungarian welterweight now living in Passaic, gained a split decision over Frank Ippolito in a slugging, fast-paced ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 3-- Lebanese opposition leaders called off their general strike today and accepted a facesaving compromise in Lebanon's electoral dispute. It was regarded as a victory for the Western-oriented Government of Premier Sami es-Solh.
WASHINGTON, June 3--A six-member panel of economists unanimously opposed tax cuts today unless Federal spending could be reduced by $3,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000.
"A policeman's lot," as Sir William Gilbert once wrote, "is not a happy one." New evidence was offered yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court in Brooklyn.
LONDON, June 3--Prices were sensitive to quiet trading on the stock exchange today. Government securities recovered part of their early losses but industrials were hesitant and irregular.
New York City is playing host this week to "the biggest medical meeting on earth"--the annual convention of the American Medical Association.

Three of the five major New York City branch system commercial banks increased from 2 to 3 per cent yesterday the interest rate they will pay on savings deposits, effective July 1. A fourth is expected to take action shortly.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 3-- Jesse Merritt, Nassau County historian since 1937, died here today at the Nassau Hospital of pneumonia following an operation. He was 68 years old.
A final decree on the control of championship boxing matches by James D. Norris and his partner, Arthur M. Wirtz, will be issued by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan on June 24.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The new home of Vice President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon is filled with conversation pieces.
CHICAGO, June 3--Hughston M. McBain announced today that he would retire soon as a chairman and chief executive officer of Marshall Field Co. He is 55 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3--A special committee of the General Assembly recommended today another two-year postponement of the long-proposed conference to review the United Nations Charter.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The Administration debated today whether to request the Soviet Union to arrange for a television appearance of President Eisenhower.
Tom Carroll, Fordham Prep senior, became the fastest halfmiler in schoolboy track history yesterday.
VIENNA, June 3--The Peasant wing of the Hungarian revolutionary movement is feeling the iron hand of the Kadar dictatorship.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 3--Sam Snead and Dick Mayer led the qualifiers for the United States Open championship in the sectional trials held at two Westchester County courses today.

WHITE PLAINS, June 3--A motion for an inquiry into the laying of a natural gas pipeline across Westchester County on land now needed for the Cross Westchester Expressway was defeated 29 to 13, this evening by the County Board of Supervisors.

CHICAGO, June 3--A demand by the public to accelerate the development of atomic energy "beyond the dictates of this country's strictly economic considerations" was described today by Kenneth D. Nichols, former general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission.

PASADENA, Calif., June 3-- Dr. Linus Pauling, Nobel Prize biochemist, said today that 2,000 scientists had joined him in urging an international agreement to stop testing of nuclear bombs because of the radiation dangers.
OTTAWA, June 3--Most political observers expect the Liberal Government of Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent to win next Monday's national election, but with its majority severely cut.
Cotton futures advanced 3 to 35 points (15 cents to $1.75 a bale) yesterday. The far off months were strongest.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP)-- Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, complained today that Canadian newsprint companies had failed to expand enough to meet the steadily growing United States demand.
For the first time a giant corporation has been told, in effect, by the United States Supreme Court: "Shoemaker, stick to your last."
